What is surprising are two addition features.

  1. First, the linear \(T\) term often extends to low temperatures of a few Kelvin or even less, if the superconductivity is suppressed by a strong magnetic field. There are experiments that show that this low temperature linear term extends over a range of doping, albeit with a doping dependent slope that may or may not match the high temperature slope. [2,3]
  2. A second feature is that at some special doping, the linear \(T\) term persists over a large temperature range with the same slope all the way to the lowest temperature.

In this paper we shall not address this second feature, but instead focus on the low temperature linear \(T\) phenomenon, which is highly unusual on its own, because the standard expectation is \(T^{2}\) behavior. It is therefore important to ask whether there is a microscopic model that gives rise to the low temperature linear in \(T\) resistivity.

给出微观模型：这个模型的谱函数(spectral function)是\(D(q, \omega)=\frac{q \omega}{\omega^{2}+\left(C q^{3}\right)^{2}}\)

这个谱函数对应到很多重要的模型

  • 铜基超导quantum critical point对应的模型的最可能候选对象
  • twisted bilayer graphene

这个模型是“非费米液体”，因为自能 \(\Sigma(\omega)\sim \omega^{2 / 3}\)

In this paper we consider a model which assumes a two dimensional Fermi sea where the fermions with dispersion \(\epsilon_{ k }\) are being scattered by a critical bosonic mode with the propagator \(P(q, \omega)=1 /\left(C q^{2}-i \omega / q\right)\) so that the spectral function \(D(q, \omega)=\operatorname{Im}[P(q, \omega)]\) is given by \[D(q, \omega)=\frac{q \omega}{\omega^{2}+\left(C q^{3}\right)^{2}} \tag{1}\] To simplify notations, throughout this paper we measure energy, temperature or frequency in units of the nearest neighbor fermion hopping parameter \(t\) and we set the lattice constant to be unity. The fermions are scattered by this mode with a coupling constant \(g .\) Equation (1) has arisen in several contexts.

For example, this equation describes the critical fluctuations at a quantum critical point that separates a Fermi surface with four-fold symmetry to one with two-fold symmetry. This is sometimes called the electronic nematic phase transition or the Pomeranchuk instability. This model is considered to be one of the leading candidates for a quantum critical point in the Cuprates. Nematicity is also known to play a prominent role in the iron based superconductors.[4] It is also worth noting that nematicity, \(T\) -linear resistivity and van Hove singularity are ingredients that are showing up in twisted bilayer graphene as well. [5] Importantly, the singularity is for small momentum \(q\). \([6-8]\) This is very different from a charge or spin density wave or an antiferromagnetic instability, where the singularity occurs at a finite \(q .[9,10]\)

Another example is the scattering of fermionic spinons by \(U (1)\) gauge fluctuations that arise in spin-charge separated models in certain quantum spin liquids. [11] This model has also been discussed in the composite fermion description of the half-filled Landau level. [12] The \(\omega / q\) term in the propagator \(P(q, \omega)\) comes from Landau damping of the mode by the Fermi sea. The mode is over-damped with \(\omega\) that scales as \(q^{3}\). This leads to a fermion self energy \(\Sigma(\omega)\) that goes in leading order as \(\omega^{2 / 3}\), thereby violating the Landau criterion for a well defined quasi-particle. [11] As a result, this model is considered to be an example of a non-Fermi liquid.

We have earlier suggested that this model gives rise to a transport scattering rate that goes as \(T^{4 / 3}\). [11] This was based on the assumption that the bosonic mode equilibrates to the lattice, but this assumption has been rightly criticized on the grounds that the total momentum is conserved in the scattering process and therefore there is no mechanism for relaxing the current. [7,8] Some form of momentum relaxation such as disorder or umklapp scattering needs to be introduced. Ref. [7] considered impurity scattering and concluded that the leading T dependent correction for a singly connected convex \(2 D\) Fermi surface has a power greater than 2 and saturate for higher temperatures. In ref. [8],the problem was worked out for several versions of disorder including a linear coupling to the nematic order parameter. In this paper we focus on umklapp scattering as the mechanism of momentum relaxation. The motivation is the following. In the Cuprates, the Fermi level is close to a van Hove singularity so that the minimum umklapp vector \(\Delta_{q}\) connecting neighboring Fermi surfaces is small near the antinode, as seen in fig 1. Due to the \(q^{3}\) scaling in Eq. \(1,\) the temperature scale when the umklapp scattering kicks in can be very low, being proportional to \(\Delta_{q}^{3}\) It will be interesting to find out what the resistivity is above this low temperature scale. A more general remark is that because the mode is overdamped, the umklapp effect is not exponentially small at low \(T\) as in the case of electron-phonon interaction, but will in general be power-law down to the lowest temperature. As we shall show, what we find is a \(T^{2}\) behavior that crosses over to \(T\) at a very low temperature scale. To see how this come about, we make a quick estimate of the scattering rate \(\tilde{\gamma}\) of a fermion at the umklapp point \((\theta=0)\) with energy \(T\) by emitting a boson mode with momentum \(q\) to reach a final state at \(\phi\) on the umklapp Fermi surface, a seen in the inset of Fig. 1 \[\tilde{\gamma} \approx \int_{0}^{\infty} d \omega \int d \phi\left(n_{0}(\omega)+1\right) D(q, \omega) \approx T \int_{0}^{T} d \omega \int d \phi \frac{q}{\omega^{2}+\left(C q^{3}\right)^{2}}\]

In the second step we replaced the Bose factor \(n_{0}(\omega)+1\) by \(T / \omega\) and the integration limit by \(T\). If \(T>C \Delta_{q}^{3},\) we can first perform the \(\omega\) integration by extending the upper limit to \(\infty\). The integrand is now \(1 / q^{2}\). We approximate \(q^{2} \approx \Delta_{q}^{2}+\left(k_{F} \phi\right)^{2},\) and the \(\phi\) integration gives a constant. This shows that the scattering rate is proportional to \(T / \Delta_{q} .\) In the opposite case of \(T<C \Delta_{q}^{3}\) it is easy to see that the upper limit of the \(\omega\) integral gives an additional factor of \(T,\) leading to a \(T^{2}\) behavior. As mentioned earlier, unlike the electron-phonon problem, the scattering rate is never exponentially activated. A more accurate calculation shown later gives the same result. It is worth remarking than since umklapp scattering involves a final state that carries current in the opposite direction, there is no significant distinction between a transport lifetime which is sensitive to the momentum relaxation of each collision and the collision time, in contrast to the case of forward scattering. [11] On the other hand, since the scattering is concentrated at certain points on the Fermi surface, in order to calculate transport properties it is necessary to determine how the momentum distribution relaxes in the vicinity of these points. We need to solve the Boltzmann equation using the scattering processes as input. This is done in the following sections.

We will calculate the resisitivity, magneto-resisitivty, Hall conductivity and the Hall constant \(R_{H}\). The key physics is that the important scattering process is concentrated near the antinodal point. As such, there is a lot of overlap in the mathematical framework with a different problem involving scattering by antiferromagnetic fluctuations at momentum \((\pi, \pi)\) where strong scattering are concentrated at hot spots. [9] This problem was thoroughly investigated by Rosch [10] and his work was very helpful to us. In particular he found a linear T resistivity and linear B magnetoresistivity in certain parameter range. Just as in his case, we found that while some impurity scattering is needed to restrict the modification of the distribution function to the vicinity of a special point on the Fermi surface, the coefficient of the linear \(T\) term is independent of disorder. In this paper we focus on the relatively low temperature regime where the impurity scattering rate is comparable to the inelastic scattering rate, ie. when the temperature dependent part of the resistivity is comparable to the zero temperature limit. We defer discussion of the high temperature limit, or the clean limit, to a later paper.

2玻尔兹曼方程

The reader may worry whether one can use a Boltzmann equation when there are no quasi-particles in the Landau sense. The answer is that the Boltzmann equation can be derived without assuming the existence of quasi-particles, as long as the self energy depends on \(\omega\) and not on momentum. ( In our problem the leading self energy correction depends only on \(\omega\). While a small \(k\) dependence was discovered in a higher order expansion [13], we do not expect this to affect the argument in a significant way.) The above- mentioned result was shown in a classic paper by Prange and Kadanoff.[14] Their motivation was that in the electron-phonon scattering problem at temperature high compared with the Deybe temperature, the self-energy is \(\pi \lambda \omega\) which can be larger than \(\omega\) and yet the Boltzmann equation was used routinely. We have adopted their method to the composite fermion problem [15] and here we sketch the main idea. The key observation by Prange and Kadanoff is that the electron spectral function takes the form \[A( k , \omega)=\frac{\Sigma^{\prime \prime}(\omega)}{\left(\omega-\epsilon_{ k }-\Sigma^{\prime}(\omega)\right)^{2}+\Sigma^{\prime \prime}(\omega)^{2}}\] where \(\Sigma^{\prime}\) and \(\Sigma^{\prime \prime}\) are the real and imaginary part of the self energy. For \(\Sigma^{\prime \prime}(\omega) \sim \omega^{2 / 3}\) the spectral function is indeed very broad as a function of \(\omega,\) but at a given small \(\omega,\) it is actually a sharp function of \(\epsilon_{k}-\mu .\) This distinction is a familiar one in the modern ARPES literature, where the energy dispersion curve (EDC) is broad and the momentum dispersion curve (MDC) is sharp. The conventional derivation of the Boltzmann equation starting from the nonequilibrium Green's function involves integrating over \(\omega .\) What Prange and Kadanoff proposed to do is to pick a patch of the Fermi surface specified by \(k(\theta)\) which defines a contour along the Fermi surface parametrized by the direction \(\theta\) of the Fermi momentum vector and integrate the perpendicular momentum and hence over \(\epsilon_{k}\) instead. As a result, instead of the usual distribution function \(f( k )\) they introduced the function \(f(k(\theta), \omega) .\) Note that in the usual formulation, the vector \(k\) is decomposed into \(k(\theta)\) and the momentum in the perpendicular direction, which is then represented by \(\epsilon_{k}-\mu .\) Thus we can simply write down the standard Boltzmann equation with the understanding that in the momentum \(k ,\) the component perpendicular to the Fermi surface is replaced by \(\left(\epsilon_{k}-\mu\right) / v_{F}\) and \(\left(\epsilon_{k}-\mu\right)\) is in turn is replaced by \(\omega .\) We next introduce in the standard way the linear perturbation from the equilibrium by writing \(f( k )=f_{0}\left(\epsilon_{ k }\right)-\left(d f_{0}\left(\epsilon_{ k }\right) / d \epsilon_{ k }\right) \tilde{\Phi}( k )=f_{ k }^{0}+f_{ k }^{0}\left(1-f_{ k }^{0}\right) \tilde{\Phi}( k ) / T\) where \(f_{0}\left(\epsilon_{ k }\right)=f_{ k }^{0}\) is the Fermi distribution and \(\tilde{\Phi}( k )\) has the interpretation of a local shift of the chemical potential at patch \(\theta .\) This leads to the linearized Boltzmann equation [7]: \[\left(e v _{ k } \cdot E +e\left( v _{ k } \times B \right) \cdot \partial_{ k } \tilde{\Phi}\right) \frac{\partial f_{0}\left(\epsilon_{ k }\right)}{\partial \epsilon_{ k }}=-I_{e e}-I_{e i}\] where the electron-electron collision term is given by \[\begin{aligned}I_{e e}=& \sum_{ p , q , G } 2\left(g^{2} / T\right)\left|P\left( q , \epsilon_{ k }-\epsilon_{ k - q }\right)\right|^{2}[\tilde{\Phi}( k )+\tilde{\Phi}( p )-\tilde{\Phi}( k - q + G )-\tilde{\Phi}( p + q )] \\& f_{ k }^{0} f_{ p }^{0}\left(1-f_{ k - q + G }^{0}\right)\left(1-f_{ p + q }^{0}\right) \delta\left(\epsilon_{ k }+\epsilon_{ p }-\epsilon_{ k - q + G }-\epsilon_{ p + q }\right)\end{aligned}\] where G denotes a set of reciprocal lattice vectors and the electron-impurity collision term is \(I_{e i}=-\gamma_{0} \tilde{\Phi}( k )\left(d f_{0}\left(\epsilon_{ k }\right) / d \epsilon_{ k }\right)\) where \(\gamma_{0}\) is the impurity scattering rate. Note that we have described the scattering process as a electron-electron scattering via the exchange of the boson propagator \(D(q, \omega),\) rather than the scattering between electrons via the emission and absorption of bosons. The reason is that the conservation of total momentum for the normal scattering \(( G =0)\) is clearly seen in Eq. \(5 .\) The distribution will rapidly equilibrate to a Fermi function with a shifted overall momentum \(\tilde{\Phi}( k ) \propto k . E\) so that its contribution to the collision integral is exactly zero. Had we considered the emission and absorption of bosons, we would have to keep track of the shifted boson distribution function as well, which introduces more complications. Next, we will show that the vanishing of the normal collision term is more general. As long as the scattering is predominantly forward, then in order to conserve momentum and energy, the scattering partner \(p\) must be approximately equal to either \(k\) or \(- k\). In the first case the last two terms in [] in Eq 5 cancel the first two terms to first order in \(q\). In the second case, since \(\tilde{\Phi}(- k )=-\tilde{\Phi}( k ),\) the first two terms in [] in Eq 5 approximately cancel. A similarly argument applies for the next two terms corresponding to the outgoing pair \(p + q\) and \(k - q .\) In the presence of impurity scattering which ensures that \(\tilde{\Phi}( k )\) is smoothly varying, these arguments show that the contribution from normal scattering to the collision integral is negligible. This argument works also in the presence of a magnetic field. The Fermi surface is shifted along an axis that is rotate from the direction of the applied field \(E\) but the relation \(\tilde{\Phi}(- k )=-\tilde{\Phi}( k )\) continues to hold. So from this point on we will keep only the umklapp term \(( G \neq 0)\) in Eq. \(5 .\) On the other hand, in the clean limit, it is necessary to keep the normal scattering because the small residual terms left over from the approximate cancellation control the local equilibration and slow diffusion of the the disturbance of \(\tilde{\Phi}( k )\) along the Fermi surface towards the umklapp points. This is beyond the treatment of the current paper and is the reason why the results of this paper are limited to relatively low temperatures.

Our next step is to integrate out \(p\) and the radial part of \(k\) taking advantage of the fact that \(d f_{0}(\omega) / d \omega\) ) is a sharply peaked function. To be concrete we choose the origin in \(k\) space so that it is completely enclosed by the Fermi surface and we parametrize the Fermi surface by the angle \(\theta\) as shown in Fig \(1 .\) Leaving details to the Appendix, we find \[e v _{F}(\theta) \cdot E +e\left( v _{F}(\theta) \times B \right) \cdot \frac{\partial \Phi(\theta)}{k_{F} \partial \theta}=\int \frac{d \theta^{\prime}}{2 \pi} 2 g^{2} \nu\left(\theta^{\prime}\right) F\left(\theta, \theta^{\prime}\right)\left(\Phi(\theta)-\Phi\left(\theta^{\prime}\right)\right)\] where \(\nu(\theta)=k_{F} /\left(2 \pi v_{F}\right)\) is the density of states factor at angle \(\theta .\) In this equation, all variables are defined on the Fermi surface as parametrized by \(\theta\) and \(\Phi(\theta)\) is defined as \(\tilde{\Phi}(k(\theta), \omega=0) .\) The kernel of the integral equation \(F\left(\theta, \theta^{\prime}\right)\) depends on \(\theta\) and \(\theta^{\prime}\) only via the magnitude of the momentum transfer \(q\left(\theta, \theta^{\prime}\right)\) which connects the points \(\theta\) and \(\theta^{\prime}\) on the umklapp Fermi surface as shown in Fig. \(1 .\) Here we focus on \(\theta\) near zero, and the discussion should be repeated for \(\theta\) close to the other three nearest neighbor umklapp Fermi surfaces. The kernel is given by \[F\left(\theta, \theta^{\prime}\right)=\int n_{0}(\omega)\left(n_{0}(\omega)+1\right)(\omega / T) D(q, \omega) d \omega\] where \(n_{0}(\omega)\) is the Bose function. Note that after integration out the scattering partner, the Boltzmann equation now takes the form of umklapp scattering by emission and absorption of the mode defined by \(D(q, \omega)\). The kernel can be written in the form \(F\left(\theta, \theta^{\prime}\right)=2 q f(a)\) where \(a=C q^{3} / T\) and the scaling function \(f(a)\) is given by \[f(a)=\int_{0}^{\infty} d x \frac{e^{x}}{\left(e^{x}-1\right)^{2}} \frac{x^{2}}{x^{2}+a^{2}}\] where \(f(a)=\pi / 2 a\) for small \(a\) and \(\pi^{2} / 3 a^{2}\) for large \(a\). [9] For our numerical work we find it useful to approximate \(f(a)\) by the form suggested by Rosch [10] which matches the large and small \(a\) limits and is accurate to \(2 \%\) everywhere: \(f(a)=\pi^{2}(2 \pi+a) /\left[a\left(4 \pi^{2}+6 \pi a+3 a^{2}\right)\right]\) The coefficient of \(\Phi(\theta)\) on the right hand side of Eq. 6 can be interpreted as the scattering out rate \(\gamma(\theta)\) for an electron at \(\theta\). \[\gamma(\theta)=\int 2 g^{2} \nu\left(\theta^{\prime}\right) F\left(\theta, \theta^{\prime}\right) d \theta^{\prime} / 2 \pi\] We now estimate \(\gamma(\theta)\) for small \(\theta .\) In Fig 1 the line connecting \(\theta\) to the center of the next Brillouin zone defines \(q_{0}(\theta)\) which is the shortest distance from \(\theta\) to a point on the umklapp Fermi surface. Then \(q\left(\theta, \theta^{\prime}\right)\) can be approximated by \(\sqrt{q_{0}^{2}(\theta)+\left(k_{F} \phi\right)^{2}}\) The \(\theta^{\prime}\) integral can be replaced by an integral over \(\phi .\) For \(T \ll C q_{0}^{3}(\theta),\) we use the form for large a given after Eq. 8 . The integral over \(\phi\) is rapidly convergent and we find \(\gamma(\theta) \propto T^{2} /\left(v_{F} C^{2} q_{0}^{4}(\theta)\right)\). Note that it is a rapidly decaying function of \(q_{0}(\theta)\).

Next we consider the case \(T>C q_{0}^{3}(\theta)\) and use the small \(a\) limit of \(f(a) .\) The \(\phi\) integration is easily done to give \[\gamma(\theta)=\frac{\alpha T}{q_{0}(\theta)}, \quad T>C q_{0}^{3}(\theta)\] where \(\alpha=g^{2} /\left(2 v_{F} C\right) .\) The linear \(T\) dependence of the scattering out rate near the umklapp point which onsets at very low temperature is one of the main results of this paper.

3 方程的解

The difficulty of the solution of the Boltzmann equation comes from the second term in Eq 6 which involves an integral over \(\Phi\left(\theta^{\prime}\right) .\) To make analytic progress, we shall argue that a relaxation time approximation is justified for the resistivity \((B=0)\) at low temperatures, which we verify later with a numerically exact solution. Let us consider an electric field \(E\) along \(x\) and \(B=0 .\) We expect the Fermi surface to be displaced along \(x\) and the displacement will satisfy \(\Phi(\theta+\pi)=-\Phi(\theta) .\) From Fig \(1,\) we expect \(\theta^{\prime}\) to be near \(\pi .\) So we define \(\theta^{\prime \prime}=\theta^{\prime}-\pi .\) Furthermore, since \(F\) is peaked near small \(q,\) we expect \(-\theta^{\prime \prime}\) to be near \(\theta .\) since \(\Phi\) is an even function of \(\theta\) in the absence of \(B,\) and we expect it to be slowly varying on the scale of the relatively short range kernel \(F\left(\theta, \theta^{\prime}\right),\) we can replace \(\Phi\left(\theta^{\prime}\right)\) on the right hand side in Eq 6 by \(-\Phi(\theta) .\) This leads to the relaxation time approximation, with a relaxation time of \(1 /(2 \gamma)\). We obtain \(\Phi(\theta)=e v _{ F } \cdot E /\left(2 \gamma(\theta)+\gamma_{0}\right)\) and the current and conductivity can be computed by averaging the product of \(\Phi(\theta)\) and the x component of the Fermi velocity over the Fermi surface in the standard way. For simplicity we will assume a circular Fermi surface with a constant Fermi velocity in the analytic estimate below.

In the absence of impurity scattering, \(\Phi(\theta)\) is strongly suppressed near the umklapp point where the scattering is strong. The current is mainly carried by nodal electrons and current is no longer controlled by the distribution function near the umklapp points. A similar situation was pointed out by Hlubina et al [9] in connection with the hot-spot problem. Just as in that case, [10] the situation is different once a small amount of impurity scattering is introduced, with scattering rate \(\gamma_{0} \ll 1\). The conductivity (resistivity) saturates to a constant \(\sigma_{0}\left(\rho_{0}\right)\) at zero temperature and we can consider the relative deviation at finite \(T .\) For small deviation \(\left(\rho(T)-\rho_{0}\right) / \rho_{0}=-\left(\sigma(T)-\sigma_{0}\right) / \sigma_{0}=\) \(-\gamma_{0} \int\left(1 /\left(2 \gamma(\theta)+\gamma_{0}\right)-1 / \gamma_{0}\right) d \theta / 2 \pi\) We will use Eq. 10. For \(\Delta_{q} \ll k_{F}, q_{0}(\theta)\) can be approximated by \(\Delta_{q}+2 k_{F} \theta^{2} .\) The integral over \(\theta\) is easily done after extending the integration limits to infinity, a step which is justified as long as \(\left(\rho(T)-\rho_{0}\right) / \rho_{0}<1 .\) We obtain \[\frac{\rho(T)-\rho_{0}}{\rho_{0}}=\frac{\alpha T /\left(\gamma_{0} \sqrt{2 k_{F}}\right)}{\sqrt{\Delta_{q}+2 \alpha T / \gamma_{0}}}\] This equation should be valid for \(T>C \Delta_{q}^{3}\) and when the value of \(\left(\rho(T)-\rho_{0}\right) / \rho_{0}\) is limited to be less than unity. We conclude that the resistivity begins as a constant \(\rho_{0}\) plus a \(T^{2}\) term which quickly changes to a linear \(T\) dependence, and then crosses over to a limited region of \(\sqrt{T}\) behavior for \(T>\Delta_{q} \gamma_{0} / \alpha\) before the limit set by \(\left(\rho(T)-\rho_{0}\right) / \rho_{0}<1\) is reached. Note that the coefficient of the linear \(T\) term in the resistivity \(\rho(T)\) itself is independent of the impurity scattering rate \(\gamma_{0}\) and is therefore intrinsic. It depends weakly on \(\Delta_{q}\) as \(1 / \sqrt{\Delta_{q}}\). At even higher temperatures, the assumption of the conductivity being dominated by small \(\theta\) no longer holds and the resistivity increases faster than linear \(T\).

We next solve the Boltzmann equation numerically without making the relaxation time approximation. This is done by discretizing the \(\theta^{\prime}\) variable in Eq. 6 and converting the integral-differential equation (in the presence of \(B\) ) by a matrix equation. Inverting the matrix numerically gives an accurate solution for \(\Phi(\theta) .\) The results for the resistivity are shown in Fig \(2 .\) We introduce the dimensionless umklapp vector measured in units of the Brillouin zone size \(\Delta=\Delta_{q} / 2 \pi .\) We also re-write \(C \Delta_{q}^{3}\) as \(\tilde{C}\left(\Delta_{q} / k_{F 0}\right)^{3}\) and in the numerical calculations we set \(\tilde{C}=C k_{F 0}^{3}=1\) where \(k_{F 0}\) is the Fermi wavevector along \(\theta=0 .\) We also set \(g=1\) which simply sets the scale of the temperature dependent part of the conductivity. For the band dispersion \(\epsilon_{ k }\) we use the parametrization suggested by Horio et al. [16] for \(Nd\) doped \(LSCO , t^{\prime} / t=-0.136, t^{\prime \prime} / t=0.068\) where \(t^{\prime}\) and \(t^{\prime \prime}\) are the further neighbor hopping integrals. This model has a van Hove singularity at doping \(p \approx 0.22\) beyond which the large hole Fermi surface centered at \((\pi, \pi)\) becomes an electron Fermi surface centered at zero. Near this doping the dimensionless umklapp vector \(\Delta\) is very small. In Fig. 2 we see that the relaxation time approximation works very well at low temperature, but lies above the exact results and deviates from linearity sooner as temperature increases. The linear \(T\) behavior is very clear at low \(T\) from the inset of Fig 2 a. For \(\Delta=0.066\) the initial \(T^{2}\) term is hardly visible, but becomes apparent for the \(\Delta=0.105\) case, as expected from the \(\Delta^{3}\) dependence of the crossover scale. We verify that the resistivity slope is independent of \(\gamma_{0}\) by inspecting Fig \(2 .\) The cross-over to \(\sqrt{T}\) is rather subtle and can be seen as a region of convex curvature in the inset of Fig. 2a. Numerically the linear \(T\) like regime extends to about \(2 \rho_{0}\).

In Fig 3 a we show \(\Phi(\theta)\) for a range of temperatures for a finite impurity concentration. At zero temperature, \(\Phi(\theta)\) is given by the relaxation time approximation due to impurity scattering alone and the dips at \(\theta=0\) and \(\pi\) are due to the smaller Fermi velocity there. In the inset, we see that at low temperature, the \(\Phi\) is further suppressed mainly near the umklapp points at \(\theta=0\) and \(\pi\) so that the current is reduced in a way that is linear in T. As the temperature further increases. the current is increasingly being carried by fermions away from the umklapp points. This is responsible for the eventual deviation from linear \(T\) in the resistivity. We also show Fig \(3 b\) the distribution function \(\Phi_{0}(\theta)\) in the relaxation time approximation. We see that the relaxation time approximation works very well at low temperature, but tends to over-estimate the effect of temperature as \(T\) increases, leading to the upward curvature for the resistivity shown by the red lines in Fig.2.

4 磁场依赖和实验关系

We next discuss the effect of an orbital magnetic field, and compute the Hall effect and magnetoresistance. Our model contains a number of features which have been seen experimentally in a number of Cuprates. Here we show some useful comparisons and also point out a number of inadequacies of our model.

The Hall coefficient \(R_{H}\) is calculated from the linear \(B\) coefficient in the exact solution of the Boltzmann equation and shown by the blue lines in fig. \(4 .\) For comparison we also show the relaxation time approximation result, using the standard Zener-Jones formula. [17] \[\sigma_{x y}=\frac{2 e^{3} B}{h} \int \frac{d \theta}{2 \pi} \frac{v_{y}}{\gamma(\theta)} \frac{d\left(v_{x} / \gamma(\theta)\right)}{d \theta}\] The two results agree exactly at zero temperature where impurity scattering dominates, but to our surprise they deviate strongly at higher temperatures. The zero temperature value is a bit lower than the expected \(1 /(1+p) .\) This is because we assume a constant scattering rate as appropriate for Born scattering. If we assume a constant mean-free path as is appropriate for impurities with a fixed scattering cross-section, we do find \(1 /(1+p) .\) This difference is as expected in the presence of anisotropic Fermi velocities. [17] At finite temperatures our model has inelastic scattering rate which strongly depends on the position on the Fermi surface, being large near the umklapp point. At a given \(T\) its temperature changes from linear \(T\) to \(T^{2}\) as \(\theta\) moves away from the umklapp point, as seen from Eq. \(10 .\) This kind of anisotropic scattering has been used as phenomenological models with considerable success to fit the conductivity and the angle dependent magnetoresistance (ADMR) for the Tl based and other cuprates. [18, 19] They assume an isotropic Fermi liquid like \(T^{2}\) term and a non-Fermi liquid \(T\) term that is concentrated near the anti-node. This kind of model bears a lot of similarity to the relaxation time approximation of our more microscopic model. Therefor the resistivity results are similar. Their calculated Hall coefficient also shows a weak temperature dependence, consistent with the red curves in Fig.4. However, we see that the relaxation time approximation fares poorly for the Hall coefficient, which we find to decrease strongly with increasing temperature. As we can see by comparing Fig. 4 a and b, the decrease is faster and the discrepancy is stronger for smaller \(\Delta .\) This result suggests the following physical picture. Consider an electron near \(\theta=\pm \pi / 2\) in the presence of an \(E\) field along \(x\). The umklapp process scatters the electron to a final state on the Fermi surface in the neighboring Brillouin zone in the \(y\) direction. This is equivalent to near perfect back scattering and the final state has a y component of the Fermi velocity that is opposite in sign to that from a near forward scattering process. This can lead to a reduction and eventually a sign change in the Hall effect as the temperature increases. The information about the final state is encoded in the \(\Phi\left(\theta^{\prime}\right)\) term on the right hand side of Eq. 6 but is absent in the relaxation time approximation. To confirm this picture we have calculated \(R_{H}\) in a model where the umklapp scattering to the neighboring Fermi surfaces located in the \(y\) direction have been removed, leaving only two umklapp points along the electric field direction. As seen from Fig. 5 the Hall coefficient is now increasing with \(T\) and is qualitatively similar to the relaxation time approximation result.

Experimentally \(R_{H}\) that decreases with increasing temperatures was observed in underdoped and optimally doped YBCO in the early days of high \(T_{c}\) research and considered to be a major puzzle. [20,21] It has never been explained by any theory based on the relaxation time approximation and inspired exotic suggestions such as two different lifetimes for \(\sigma_{x x}\) and \(\sigma_{x y} \cdot[22]\) The fact that a strongly temperature dependent \(R_{H}\) shows up due to the breakdown of the relaxation time approximation may give a hint to this long standing puzzle. We should caution that in the experiment \(R_{H}\) is well fitted to a \(1 / T\) form while our results in Fig. 4 is closer to a linearly decreasing function. Furthermore, this behavior is seen most strongly in the underdoped Cuprates, where \(1 / R_{H} \approx p\). This is a feature of the pseudogap which is not captured in our present model, which gives in the limit of low temperature \(1 / R_{H} \approx 1+p\).

We also computed the Hall conductivity \(\sigma_{x y}\) and the magneto-resistivity \(\rho_{x x}\) as shown in Fig. \(6 .\) The magneto-resistivity is initially quadratic in \(B\) as expected, by switches over to a linear dependence. However, \(\sigma_{x y}\) also deviates from linear \(B\) at a similar \(B\) scale. This indicates a breakdown of the weak field condition \(\omega_{c} \tau<1\) where \(\hbar \omega_{c}=e B / m\). In a tight binding model we can roughly set \(m \approx 1 / 2 t\) so that \(B \approx \hbar \omega_{c} / 2 t\) which gives us a sense of the size of the dimensionless parameter \(B .\) For an accessible field of tens of Tesla's, \(B\) is indeed of order \(10^{-2}\) as shown in Fig. \(4 .\) It has been pointed out that a linear \(|B|\) magneto-resistance can happen when a group of carriers is moved by the magnetic field to round a corner at \(\theta=\pm \pi / 2,\) where the x component of the Fermi velocity changes sign. This can be a striking effect when the curvature of the turning point is large.[23] A linear magneto-resistance is also found in a parameter range associated with linear \(T\) resistivity by Rosch \([10] .\) However, it is not known whether \(\sigma_{x y}\) also deviates from linearity in these cases. Experimentally linear \(B\) magneto-resistance have been found to be associated with the low temperature linear \(T\) behavior in both the Cuprates [3,24] and the iron based superconductors \([25] .\) It is often (but not always [24] ) fitted to the form \(\sqrt{B^{2}+T^{2}}\). However, this is observed in the \(\omega_{c} \tau<1\) regime and it is not clear if our theory applies. Recent experiments even indicate that the linear in \(B\) magneto-resistance may have a Zeeman rather than orbital origin. [3] The effect of a magnetic field on the distribution \(\Phi\) is shown in fig. \(7 .\) We can see the distribution being shifted to the right, but its magnitude also becomes asymmetric as the field is increased. Note that the condition that \(\Phi\) is an odd function of \(\theta\) is violated by the magnetic field, and the argument given earlier in support of the relaxation time approximation fails.

5 结论

We have treated a model of fermions scattered by a critical bosonic mode with umklapp scattering being the dominant momentum relaxation mechanism. After introducing a weak impurity scattering, we find that above a very low temperature scale, the resistivity is linear in \(T\). We find that the resistivity is charaterized by a highly anisotropic scattering rate, which is linear in \(T\) near the umklapp points and becoming \(T^{2}\) as we move away from the umklapp point. It should be noted this is happening in a model where inverse life-time of the fermion is large, proportional to \(T^{2 / 3}\) and Landau's criterion for Fermi liquid is violated. Thus the lifetime of the electron as measured by ARPES is totally different from that inferred from transport measurements. We also find a serious breakdown of the relaxation time approximation in the presence of a magnetic field, leading to a Hall coefficient \(R_{H}\) that decreases with increasing temperature. This is a unique feature (or signature) of transport that is dominated by umklapp scattering. While many of these features have be seen in Cuprates, we should caution that our model has made a specific assumption that the boson mode is completely soft, i.e. we are either at the quantum critical point or in a critical phase. Deviation from critically will give a low temperature cut-off of the phenomena we describe. We should also remember that the model assumes a sharp fermi surface in the sense that the electron spectral function is sharp in momentum space at low energy, i. e. the MDC as seen in ARPES is well defined. Thus our model does not have the pseudogap at the antinode, which is a dominant feature in underdoped Cupartes. Recently it was shown that the MDC becomes sharp abruptly for \(p\) greater than a certain \(p_{c}[26]\) and our model may be better suited for this doping range.

附录

We sketch the derivation of Eq. 6 starting from Eqs. 4 and \(5 .\) The idea is to integrate out the variable \(p\) and replace it with the fermion susceptibility. In the case of umklapp scattering, we expect \(p\) to be far from the umklapp points, so that \(\tilde{\Phi}( p )\) is slowly varying and we can drop the term \(\tilde{\Phi}( p )-\tilde{\Phi}( p + q )\) on the right hand side for small \(q\). We also replace \(\delta\left(\epsilon_{ k }+\epsilon_{ p }-\epsilon_{ k - q + G }-\epsilon_{ p + q }\right)\) with \(\int d \omega \delta\left(\epsilon_{ k }-\epsilon_{ k - q + G }-\omega\right) \delta\left(\omega+\epsilon_{ p }-\epsilon_{ p + q }\right) .\) We replace the \(p\) integration by an integration along the Fermi surface and one perpendicular to it. For simplicity we shall assume a quadratic dispersion. The radial integration is replaced by an integral over \(\epsilon_{ p } / v_{F} .\) This integration can be done using the identity \[\int d \epsilon f_{0}(\epsilon-\omega)\left(1-f_{0}(\epsilon)\right)=\omega\left(1+n_{0}(\omega)\right)\] The appearance of the Bose factor on the right signals that we are describing a particle-hole excitation which has Bose statistics. Next we do the integration along the Fermi surface which we can replace by \(k_{F} d \theta_{p}\) where \(\theta_{p}\) specifies a patch on the Fermi surface. For small \(q\) we can write \(\delta\left(\omega+\epsilon_{ p }-\epsilon_{ p + q }\right)=\delta\left(v_{ p } \cdot q -\omega\right) .\) We choose the origin of \(\theta_{p}\) to be the point where \(q\) is tangent to the Fermi surface. The delta function then becomes \(\delta\left(v_{F} q \sin \left(\theta_{p}\right)-\omega\right) .\) Doing the \(\theta_{p}\) integration gives the factor \(\omega / v_{F} q\) for \(\omega<v_{F} q,\) as expected for Landau damping. We obtain \[I_{e e}=\left(g^{2} / \pi T\right) \sum_{ q } \delta\left(\epsilon_{ k }-\epsilon_{ k - q + G }-\omega\right)\left(n_{0}(\omega)+1\right) f_{ k }^{0}\left(1-f_{ k - q + G }^{0}\right)\left(k_{F} \omega / v_{F} q\right)|D(q, \omega)|^{2}[\tilde{\Phi}( k )-\tilde{\Phi}( k - q + G )]\] Finally we integrate Eq. 4 over \(\epsilon_{ k }\) The lefts side gives the left side of Eq \(6 .\) On the right side the fermi factors force \(\epsilon_{ k }-\mu\) to be small and we can replace \(\tilde{\Phi}( k )\) by \(\Phi(\theta)\) as defined in the text. The integration over \(\epsilon_{ k }\) is done by using Eq. 13 again, and we obtain Eq. 6 .

entry.title: 一维费米系统中的量子纠缠熵
entry.content:
[TOC]

模型

Kitaev链：一维系统，N个费米子晶格 \[H=\sum_{j}-w\left(a_{j}^{\dagger} a_{j+1}+a_{j+1}^{\dagger} a_{j}\right)-\mu\left(a_{j}^{\dagger} a_{j}-\frac{1}{2}\right)+\Delta a_{j} a_{j+1}+\Delta a_{j+1}^{\dagger} a_{j}^{\dagger}\] 其中

  • \(w\) 跃迁振幅
  • \(\Delta=|\Delta| e^{i \varphi}\) 超导gap，这里我们只讨论 \(\varphi=0\) 的情况

对于无序(disorder)系统 \[\begin{aligned}\mu^{\prime} &=\mu+\eta u_{j} \\\Delta^{\prime} &=\Delta+\gamma u_{j}\end{aligned}\] 其中

  • \(u_{j}=\operatorname{uniform}\left[-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right]\) 是在这个范围的随机变量
  • \(\eta\) 和 \(\gamma\) 是无序的幅度

Hopping Hamiltonian

对于无相互作用的情况，哈密顿量只有跃迁Hopping \[H=\sum_{j=1}^{N}\left[-w\left(a_{j}^{\dagger} a_{j+1}+a_{j+1}^{\dagger} a_{j}\right)-\mu\left(a_{j}^{\dagger} a_{j}-\frac{1}{2}\right)\right]\] 傅里叶变换 \[b_{k}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}} \sum_{j} a_{j} e^{-\frac{2 \pi i}{N} k j}\] 哈密顿量经过傅里叶变换之后对角化了 \[\begin{aligned}H &=\sum_{k, k^{\prime}}-w b_{k}^{\dagger} b_{k^{\prime}} {\sum_{j} e^{-\frac{2 \pi i}{N} j\left(k-k^{\prime}\right)}\left(e^{\frac{2 \pi i k^{\prime}}{N}}+e^{-\frac{2 \pi i k}{N}}\right)-\mu\left(b_{k}^{\dagger} b_{k}-\frac{1}{2}\right)} \\ &=\sum_{k, k^{\prime}}-w b_{k}^{\dagger} b_{k^{\prime}} {\delta_{k, k^{\prime}}\left(e^{\frac{2 \pi i k^{\prime}}{N}}+e^{-\frac{2 \pi i k}{N}}\right)-\mu\left(b_{k}^{\dagger} b_{k}-\frac{1}{2}\right)} \\&=\sum_{k}\left[-\mu-2 w \cos \left(\frac{2 \pi}{N} k\right)\right] b_{k}^{\dagger} b_{k}+\frac{\mu}{2}\end{aligned}\] 本征值 \[E_{k} \equiv-\mu-2 w \cos \left(\frac{2 \pi}{N} k\right)\] 基态（ground state）是指能量最低的态。

我们可以从积态中得到关联矩阵 \[\left\langle b_{k}^{\dagger} b_{k}^{\prime}\right\rangle=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}\delta_{k, k^{\prime}} & \text { if } E_{k}<0, \text { thus }|k| \leq k_{c} \\0 & \text { if } E_{k}>0\end{array}\right.\] 其中费米动量 \(E\left(\pm k_{c}\right)=0\)。

为了计算纠缠熵（entanglement entropy），我们需要先计算关联矩阵 \[A_{L}=\left\langle a_{m}^{\dagger} a_{n}\right\rangle\] 做逆傅里叶变换 \[\begin{aligned}\left\langle a_{m}^{\dagger} a_{n}\right\rangle &=\left\langle\sum_{k, k^{\prime}} \frac{1}{N} e^{-\frac{2 \pi i}{N}\left(k m-k^{\prime} n\right)} b_{k}^{\dagger} b_{k^{\prime}}\right\rangle\\&=\sum_{k, k^{\prime}} \frac{1}{N} e^{-\frac{2 \pi i}{N}\left(k m-k^{\prime} n\right)}\left\langle b_{k}^{\dagger} b_{k^{\prime}}\right\rangle \\&=\sum_{|k|<k_{c}} \frac{1}{N} e^{-\frac{2 \pi i k}{N}(m-n)}\\&=\sum_{k=0}^{k_{c}} \frac{1}{N}\left(e^{-\frac{2 \pi i k}{N}(m-n)}+e^{\frac{2 \pi i k}{N}(m-n)}\right) \\&=\frac{2}{N} \sum_{k=0}^{k_{c}} \cos \left[\frac{2 \pi k}{N}(m-n)\right]\end{aligned}\] 这个求和在极限下可以等效为积分 \[A_{m n}=\left\langle a_{m}^{\dagger} a_{n}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\pi} \frac{\sin \left(k_{c}(m-n)\right)}{m-n}\]

Kitaev Wire

Kitaev链 可以转到 Majorana算符表示 \[H=\sum_{j}-w\left(a_{j}^{\dagger} a_{j+1}+a_{j+1}^{\dagger} a_{j}\right)-\mu\left(a_{j}^{\dagger} a_{j}-\frac{1}{2}\right)+\Delta a_{j} a_{j+1}+\Delta a_{j+1}^{\dagger} a_{j}^{\dagger}\\\Downarrow\\H=\frac{i}{2} \sum_{j}-\mu c_{2 j-1} c_{2 j}+(w+\Delta) c_{2 j} c_{2 j+1}+(-w+\Delta) c_{2 j-1} c_{2 j+2}\] 傅里叶变换 \[\begin{aligned}H =&\sum_{k}\left[-\left(\mu+2 w \cos \left(\frac{2 \pi k}{N}\right)\right) b_{k}^{\dagger} b_{k}\right]+\frac{\mu}{2} \\&+\sum_{k, k^{\prime}, j} \frac{\Delta}{N}\left[e^{\frac{-2 \pi i}{N}\left(j\left(k+k^{\prime}\right)+k^{\prime}\right)} b_{k} b_{k^{\prime}}+e^{\frac{2 \pi i}{N}\left(j\left(k+k^{\prime}\right)+k\right)} b_{k}^{\dagger} b_{k^{\prime}}^{\dagger}\right]\end{aligned}\] 定义 \(\epsilon_{k} \equiv \mu+2 w \cos \left(\frac{2 \pi k}{N}\right)\)，以及利用关系 \(\frac{1}{N} \sum_{j=1}^{N} e^{2 \pi i j\left(k-k^{\prime}\right) / N}=\delta_{k, k^{\prime}}\) \[\begin{aligned}H &=\sum_{k}-\epsilon_{k} b_{k}^{\dagger} b_{k}+\sum_{k, k^{\prime}} \Delta\left[e^{\frac{-2 \pi i k^{\prime}}{N}} \delta_{k,-k^{\prime}} b_{k} b_{k^{\prime}}+e^{\frac{2 \pi i k}{N}} \delta_{k,-k^{\prime}} b_{k}^{\dagger} b_{k^{\prime}}^{\dagger}\right]+\frac{\mu}{2} \\&=\sum_{k}-\epsilon_{k} b_{k}^{\dagger} b_{k}+\sum_{k} \Delta\left[e^{\frac{2 \pi i k}{N}}\left(b_{k} b_{-k}+b_{k}^{\dagger} b_{-k}^{\dagger}\right)\right]+\frac{\mu}{2}\end{aligned}\] 利用求和关系 \(\sum_{x=-N}^{N} f(x)=\sum_{x>0} f(x)+f(-x)\) \[\begin{aligned}H &=\sum_{k}-\epsilon_{k} b_{k}^{\dagger} b_{k}+\sum_{k} \Delta\left[e^{\frac{2 \pi i k}{N}}\left(b_{k} b_{-k}+b_{k}^{\dagger} b_{-k}^{\dagger}\right)\right]+\frac{\mu}{2}\\&=\sum_{k>0}\left[-\epsilon_{k} b_{k}^{\dagger} b_{k}-\epsilon_{-k} b_{-k}^{\dagger} b_{-k}+\Delta e^{\frac{2 \pi i k}{N}}\left(b_{k} b_{-k}+b_{k}^{\dagger} b_{-k}^{\dagger}\right)\right.\\&\quad+\left.\Delta e^{\frac{-2 \pi i k}{N}}\left(b_{-k} b_{k}+b_{-k}^{\dagger} b_{k}^{\dagger}\right)\right]+\frac{\mu}{2}\end{aligned}\] 粒子数算符为零 \(b_{k}, b_{-k}=b_{k}^{\dagger}, b_{-k}^{\dagger}=0\) \[\begin{aligned}H &=\sum_{k>0}\left[-\epsilon_{k} b_{k}^{\dagger} b_{k}+\epsilon_{-k} b_{-k} b_{-k}^{\dagger}+\Delta\left(e^{\frac{2 \pi i k}{N}}-e^{\frac{2 \pi i-k}{N}}\right)\left(-b_{-k} b_{k}+b_{k}^{\dagger} b_{-k}^{\dagger}\right)\right] \\&\quad+\frac{\mu}{2}-\sum_{k>0} \epsilon_{-k}\end{aligned}\] 定义

  • \(c \equiv \frac{\mu}{2}-\sum_{k>0} \epsilon_{-k}\)
  • \(\xi_{k} \equiv 2 i \Delta \sin \left(\frac{2 \pi k}{N}\right)\)

\[H=\sum_{k>0}\left[-\epsilon_{k} b_{k}^{\dagger} b_{k}-\epsilon_{-k} b_{-k}^{\dagger} b_{-k}+\xi_{k}\left(-b_{-k} b_{k}+b_{k}^{\dagger} b_{-k}^{\dagger}\right)\right]+c\]

写成矩阵形式 \[H=\sum_{k}\left(\begin{array}{c}b_{k} \\b_{-k}^{\dagger}\end{array}\right)^{\dagger}\left(\begin{array}{cc}-\epsilon_{k} & \xi_{k} \\-\xi_{k} & \epsilon_{-k}\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}b_{k} \\b_{-k}^{\dagger}\end{array}\right)+c\] 本征值求得 \[E(k)=\pm \sqrt{\left(\mu+2 w \cos \left(\frac{2 \pi k}{N}\right)\right)^{2}+\left(2 \Delta \sin \left(\frac{2 \pi k}{N}\right)\right)^{2}}\]

数值模拟

结果

介绍两个新概念

  1. entanglement length
  2. maximum entanglement entropy

面积定律

区域A的纠缠熵，正比于区域A的面积。

在1维系统中，因为系统的面积一直不变，所以纠缠熵是常数

如果系统在临界点（critical point），那么系统的纠缠熵是对数定律 \[S(L) \approx \log (L)\] 对数定律对所有维度都成立

Kitaev模型有两个相：

  1. \(|\mu|>|2 w|\) 普通相
  2. \(|\mu|<|2 w|\) Majorana相

参考文献

  • 《Entanglement Entropy in 1 D Noninteracting Fermionic Systems》Von Daniel Weigand

entry.title: 用超导量子比特模拟“动力学量子相变”
entry.content:
[TOC]

Outline

Reference:

  1. PhysRevApplied.11.044080(2019): Observation of a Dynamical Quantum Phase Transition by a Superconducting Qubit Simulation
  2. PhysRevB.97.060304(2018): Dynamical topological invariant after a quantum quench
  3. doi:10.1088/1361-6633/aaaf9a: Dynamical quantum phase transitions: a review
  4. Applied Physics Reviews 6, 021318 (2019): A Quantum Engineer's Guide to Superconducting Qubits
  5. Doctoral Thesis: Experimental research on quantum simulation and quantum optics with superconducting Xmon qubit
  6. Doctoral Thesis: Low dimensional topological states and its dynamics far from equilibrium

1 Theoretical Model

We begin with a two-band model with the Hamiltonian written in momentum space \[H=\sum_{k} \Psi_{k}^{\dagger} h(k) \Psi_{k}\] where

  • \(\Psi_{k}\) denotes a spinor
  • \(h(k)\) can be expanded in \(\hat{\sigma }=\left(\sigma_{x}, \sigma_{y}, \sigma_{z}\right)\) Pauli matrices base

\[h(k)=d_{0}(k)+\hat{d }(k) \cdot \hat{\sigma }\]

This model can describe a variety of physically different many-body systems

  1. SSH model： $ (k)=[(t+t)+(t-t) k,(t-t) k, 0)]$
  2. Kitaev chain: \(\hat{d } (k)=[0, \Delta \sin k,(-\mu / 2-t \cos k)]\)
  3. Transverse field Ising model : \(\hat{d } (k)=[0, \sin k,(h- \cos k)]\)

The eigenvalues of \(h(k)\) are given by \[\epsilon_{\pm}(k)=d_{0}(k) \pm| \hat{d } (k)|\] The corresponding eigenvectors are denoted by \(\left|\phi_{\pm}(k)\right\rangle,\) or written as density matrices \[\begin{aligned}\rho_{\pm}(k)&=\left|\phi_{\pm}(k)\right\rangle\left\langle\phi_{\pm}(k)\right|\\&=\frac{1}{2}[1 \pm \hat{ d }(k) \cdot \sigma]\end{aligned}\]

quench dynamics

  1. we first prepare the system in the ground state of the initial Hamiltonian \(h_{i}(k)\)

\[\begin{aligned}\rho_{i}(k)&=\left|\phi_{i}(k)\right\rangle\left\langle\phi_{i}(k)\right|\\&=\frac{1}{2}\left[1-\hat{ d }_{i}(k) \cdot \sigma\right]\end{aligned}\]

  1. a sudden quench to the final Hamiltonian \(h_{f}(k)\)

  2. Time evolution of density matrices \[i \frac{\partial \rho(k, t)}{\partial t}=\left[h^{f}(k), \rho(k, t)\right]\] the solution \[\begin{aligned}\rho(k, t)&=e^{-i h^{f}(k) t} \rho(k, 0) e^{i h^{f}(k) t}\\&=\frac{1}{2}[1-\hat{d}(k, t) \cdot \sigma]\end{aligned}\]

  3. geometric picture

    Bloch vector \[\begin{aligned}\hat{ d }(k, t) \cdot \sigma&=e^{-i t d _{f}(k) \cdot \sigma}\left[\hat{ d }_{i}(k) \cdot \sigma\right] e^{i t d _{f}(k) \cdot \sigma}\\\hat{ d }(k, t)&=\hat{ d }^{i} \cos \left(2\left| d ^{f}\right| t\right)+2 \hat{ d }^{f}\left(\hat{ d }^{i} \cdot \hat{ d }^{f}\right) \sin ^{2}\left(\left| d ^{f}\right| t\right)+\hat{ d }^{i} \times \hat{ d }^{f} \sin \left(2\left| d ^{f}\right| t\right)\end{aligned}\]

    the spin precession on the Bloch sphere:

    \(\hat{ d }_{i}(k)\) rotating around \(\hat{ d }_{f}(k)\) with period \(\pi /\left| d _{f}(k)\right|\)

dynamical topological invariant

  • In general, the 1D Brillouin zone (BZ) has the topology \(S^{1}\).

  • the topology of time can be viewed as \(S^{1}\)

hence the total momentum-time manifold has the topology \(T^{2}\)

  • If there are two fixed points \(k=k_{1}\) and \(k_{2},\) the corresponding circle contract to a point, then the momentum-time manifold can be reduced to a series of spheres \(S^{2}\).

  • In general, if there are \(N\) fixed points in a BZ, the momentum-time manifold \(T^{2}\) can be reduced to \(N\) sub-manifolds, each of them has the topology \(S^{2}\).

Now we naturally have a map from each momentum-time sub-manifold to the Bloch vector \(\hat{ d }(k, t),\) which is\(S^{2} \rightarrow S^{2},\) and then we can define a Chern number \[\begin{aligned}C_{d y n}^{m}&=\frac{1}{4 \pi} \int_{k_{m}}^{k_{m+1}} d k \int_{0}^{\pi} d t^{\prime}\left(\hat{ d } \times \partial_{t^{\prime}} \hat{ d }\right) \cdot \partial_{k}, \hat{ d }\\&=\frac{1}{2}\left(\cos \theta_{k=k_{m}}-\cos \theta_{k=k_{m+1}}\right)\end{aligned}\] where

  • \(m=1,2, \ldots, N\) denotes the \(m\) th sub-manifold
  • \(k_{m}\) denotes the \(m\) th fixed point
  • \(k_{N+1}=k_{1}+\) \(2 \pi\) is the same point modulo \(2 \pi .\)
  • \(\theta_{k}\) is the included angle between \(\hat{ d }^{i}(k)\) and \(\hat{ d }^{f}(k)\)

Hence the integral is an integer and it measures how many times the Bloch vectors cover the unit sphere.

example：SSH Model

SSH Model Hamiltonian \[H=\sum_{k} \Psi_{k}^{\dagger} h(k) \Psi_{k}\] where

  • \(h(k)=d_{x} \sigma_{x}+d_{y} \sigma_{y}\)
  • \(d_{x}=(1+\delta)+(1-\delta) \cos k\)
  • \(d_{y}=(1-\delta) \sin k\)

topological phase

  • For \(\delta>0\) the half-filled system is topologically trivial
  • For \(\delta<0\) the system is topological

dynamical topological invariant

  • both \(\delta^{i}\) and \(\delta^{f}\) lie in the same phase, have \(C_{d y n}^{1}=C_{d y n}^{2}=0\)
  • if \(\delta^{i}\) and \(\delta^{f}\) are in different phases, dynamical topological invariants are \(C_{d y n}^{1}=-1\) and \(C_{d y n}^{2}=1\)

The evolution of Bloch vector for different momenta

    1. \(\delta^{i}=-0.7\) and \(\delta^{f}=-0.3 ;\) corresponding to topological cases
    1. \(\delta^{i}=-0.7\) and \(\delta^{f}=0.3 ;\) corresponding to topological cases
  • \(( c ) \delta^{i}=0.4\) and \(\delta^{f}=0.2 ;\) corresponding to trivial cases.
  • $( d ) ^{i}=0.4 \(and\)^{f}=-0.2 .$ corresponding to trivial cases.

The black dotted loop represents the distribution of initial Bloch vectors \(\hat{ d }^{i}(k)\)

  • For \(( a )\) and \(( c ),\) both \(\delta^{i}\) and \(\delta^{f}\) lie in the same phase, and the trajectories of different Bloch vectors cancel out each other, giving rise to the dynamical Chern number \(C_{d y n}^{1}=0 ;\)
  • For. \(2( b )\) and \(( d ), \delta^{i}\) and \(\delta^{f}\) lie in different phases, and the trajectories for Bloch vectors of \(k \in(0, \pi)\) cover the whole Bloch sphere, corresponding to \(C_{d y n}^{1}=-1\)

non-trivial dynamical Chern number:

the trajectories for Bloch vectors of \(k \in(0, \pi)\) cover the whole Bloch sphere

2 Superconducting Qubits

LC-oscillator(Quantum Harmonic Oscillator )

In LC-oscillator system, energy oscillates between

  • electrical energy in the capacitor \(C\) \(\rightarrow\) associate the electrical energy with the "kinetic energy"
  • magnetic energy in the inductor \(L\). \(\rightarrow\) the magnetic energy with the "potential energy" of the oscillator

The Hamiltonian of LC-oscillator \[H=\frac{Q^{2}}{2 C}+\frac{\Phi^{2}}{2 L} \equiv \frac{1}{2} C V^{2}+\frac{1}{2} L I^{2}\] where

  • \(Q(t)\) the charge on the capacitor
  • \(\Phi\) the flux on the inductor

this Hamiltonian is analogous to that of a mechanical harmonic oscillator \[H=p^{2} / 2 m+m \omega^{2} x^{2} / 2\] with

  • mass \(m=C\)
  • resonant frequency \(\omega=1 / \sqrt{L C}\)

The Hamiltonian described above is classical. In order to proceed to a quantum-mechanical description of the system, we need to promote the charge and flux coordinates to quantum operators. the quantum operators similarly satisfy a commutation relation: \[[\hat{\Phi}, \hat{Q}]=\hat{\Phi} \hat{Q}-\hat{Q} \hat{\Phi}=i \hbar\] second quantization \[\begin{aligned}\hat{a} &=\left(\hat{\Phi}+i Z_{r} \hat{Q}\right) / \sqrt{2 \hbar \bar{Z}_{r}} \\\hat{a}^{\dagger} &=\left(\hat{\Phi}-i Z_{r} \hat{Q}\right) / \sqrt{2 \hbar Z_{r}}\end{aligned}\] the quantum harmonic oscillator (QHO) Hamiltonian \[H=\hbar \omega_{r}\left(a^{\dagger} a+\frac{1}{2}\right)\]

since many gate operations depend on frequency selectivity, the equidistant level-spacing of the QHO, we need to add an-harmonicity (or nonlinearity) into our system. In short, we require the transition frequencies \(\omega_{ q }^{0 \rightarrow 1}\) and \(\omega_{ q }^{1 \rightarrow 2}\) be sufficiently different to be individually adressable.

Josephson junction

To introduce the nonlinearity required to modify the harmonic potential, we use the Josephson junction, which is consists of two or more superconductors coupled by a thin insulating barrier

modified Hamiltonian \[\hat{H}_{0}=4 E_{C} \hat{n}^{2}-E_{J} \cos \hat{\phi}\] where

  • \(\hat{n}\) is the operator corresponding to the number of Cooper pairs tunneled through the Josephson junctions
  • \(\hat{\phi}\) denotes the gauge-invariant phase-difference operator across the Josephson junctions.

There are three main categories of the quantum superconducting qubit working in different regimes according the ratio of the Josephson energy \(E_{J}\) to the charging energy \(E_{C}:\)

\((1)\) charge qubit with \(E_{J} / E_{C} \sim 0.1 ;\)

  1. flux qubit with \(E_{J} / E_{C} \sim 50 ;\)

  2. phase qubit \(E_{J} / E_{C} \sim 10^{6}\).

In the regime: \(20 \lesssim E_{J} / E_{C} \lesssim 100,\) expanding the potential \[E_{J} \cos (\phi)=\frac{1}{2} E_{J} \phi^{2}-\frac{1}{24} E_{J} \phi^{4}+ O \left(\phi^{6}\right)\] an-harmonic oscillator (AHO). \[H=\omega_{ q } a^{\dagger} a+\frac{\alpha}{2} a^{\dagger} a^{\dagger} a a\] The anharmonicity is big enough for the addressability of the two lowest energy levels and thus constitutes a qubit(a quantum two-level system) \[\hat{H}_{0}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar \omega \hat{\sigma}_{z}\] with

  • \(\omega=2\left(\sqrt{8 E_{J} E_{C}}-E_{C}\right) / \hbar\)
  • \(\hat{\sigma}_{z}=|e\rangle\langle e|-| g\rangle\langle g|\)
  • Here \(|g\rangle\) is the ground state of the transmon
  • while \(|e\rangle\) is its first excited eigenstate.

effectively treat the AHO as a quantum two-level system, thus constitutes a qubit

3 Experimental results

Results 1: dynamical topological invariant

example for demonstration in paper: The transverse-field Ising model \[H_{\text {Ising }}=-\sum_{l} \sigma_{l}^{x} \sigma_{l+1}^{x}+g \sigma_{l}^{z}\] where \(g\) is the transverse-field strength.

The spin model can be mapped to the free-fermion model by using Jordan-Wigner transformation \[\begin{aligned}\sigma_{l}^{z}&=1-2 c_{l}^{\dagger}c_{l}\\\sigma_{l}^{x}&=\prod_{j<l}\left(1-2 c_{j}^{\dagger} c_{j}\right)\left(c_{l}+c_{l}^{\dagger}\right)\end{aligned}\] The Hamiltonian changes to \[H_{\text {Ising }}=-\sum_{l}\left(c_{l}^{\dagger} c_{l+1}+c_{l}^{\dagger} c_{l+1}^{\dagger}+\text { h.c. }\right)+g\left(1-2 c_{l}^{\dagger} c_{l}\right)\] where \(d (k)=[0, \sin k,(g-\cos k)],\) It is well known that the model is

  • in ferromagnetic phase when \(g<1\)
  • in paramagnetic phase when \(g>1\)

In the experiment, we let \(g_{i}=0.2,\) which is in the ferromagnetic phase regime. The system is suddenly quenched to the final Hamiltonian \(h_{f}(k) .\) Here two different strengths of the field are chosen

  1. \(g_{f}=1.5\) corresponding to the paramagnetic phases
  2. \(g_{f}=0.5\) corresponding to the ferromagnetic phases

For each value of \(k,\) the state is rotated for two cycles on the Bloch sphere, representing time evolution for two periods. The rotation axis is determined by the quench Hamiltonian \(h_{f}(k)\). The path of the state time evolution is presented in Fig

Results 2: Rate function

the rate function of the dynamical free energy \[f(t)=-\frac{1}{N} \sum_{k} \log \left|\left\langle\phi_{i}(k)\left|e^{-i t h_{f}(k)}\right| \phi_{i}(k)\right\rangle\right|^{2}\] The nonanalytic behavior of \(f(t)\) corresponds to \(DQPT\)

presents the time-dependent rate functions for different \(g_{f},\) all with initial parameter \(g_{i}=0.2 .\)

  • rate functions \(f(t)\) have sharp peaks at the critical time \(t_{c}\) for \(g_{f}=3.5,2.5,1.5>1 ,\) which leads to discontinuity for derivative of \(f(t)\) at \(t_{c} .\) This phenomenon corresponds to the DQPT.
  • rate functions for \(g_{f}=0.9,0.8,0.7\) are much more smooth and no sharp peak appears, so no discontinuity is expected for derivative of the rate functions. Thus no DQPT happens.

Results of a different number \(N\) of modes for \(k\), corresponding to size \(N\) of the Ising model.

Demonstrating the finite-size effect. As \(N\) increases, it approaches the theoretical value for \(N \rightarrow \infty\) and demonstrates nonanalytic behavior.

Results 3: Skyrmion lattice

the Loschmidt amplitude of a two-band system can be written as \[G(t)=\prod_{k}\left[\cos \left(\left| d _{f}(k)\right| t\right)+i \hat{ d }_{i}(k) \cdot \hat{ d }_{f}(k) \sin \left(\left| d _{f}(k)\right| t\right)\right]\] The DQPT occurs when the Loschmidt amplitude reaches zero at a critical time \(t_{c} .\) the existence of zero of \(G(t)\) requires that there are at least one critical momentum \(k^{*}\) satisfying \[\hat{ d }_{i}\left(k^{*}\right) \cdot \hat{ d }_{f}\left(k^{*}\right)=0\] For clarity, we employ the Ising model to elucidate the condition of DQPT. One has, \[\begin{aligned}d _{i}(k) \cdot d _{f}(k) &=\sin ^{2} k+\cos ^{2} k-\left(g_{i}+g_{f}\right) \cos k+g_{i} g_{f} \\&=0\end{aligned}\] The solution exists when \[|\cos k|=\left|\frac{1+g_{i} g_{f}}{g_{i}+g_{f}}\right|<1\] DQPT​ occurs if and only if the initial Hamiltonian and the final Hamiltonian belong to different phases for the Ising model \[k^{*}=\pm \arccos \left[\left(1+g_{i} g_{f}\right) /\left(g_{i}+g_{f}\right)\right]\] a dynamical Chern number can be defined in momentum-time space in a quench process.

The nontrivial dynamical Chern number indicates the emergence of the Skyrmion lattice in the momentum time space.

the emergence of a Skyrmion lattice in momentum-time space for DQPT

initial parameter \(g_{i}=0.2 .\)

  • \(g_{f}=1.5\) in Fig. \(( c )\) the emergence of the Skyrmion lattice in momentum-time space can be seen obviously, which indicates the nontrivial dynamical Chern number implying the occurrence of DQPT. The time coordinates of the center of Skyrmion is just the critical time \(t_{c} .\)
  • \(g_{f}=0.5\) in Fig. \(( d )\) While if \(g_{i}=0\) and \(g_{f}=0.5\) lie in the same phase, the configuration of the Skyrmion lattice does not appear , the corresponding dynamical Chern number is trivial. There is no DQPT as shown Fig. \(( b )\).

4 Take Home information

  1. Dynamic precession equal to vector \(\hat{ d }_{i}(k)\) rotating in the Bloch sphere
  2. Dynamic Chern number measures how many times the Bloch vectors of \(k \in(0, \pi)\) cover the whole Bloch sphere
  3. Josephson junction is nonlinearity to modify the harmonic potential, the AHO can be effectively treated as a qubit
  4. The nonanalytic behavior of the rate function of the dynamical free energy \(f(t)\) corresponds to \(DQPT\). The results of experiment agree well with theoretical calculations.
  5. The nontrivial dynamical Chern number indicates the emergence of the Skyrmion lattice in the momentum time space.

entry.title: 多体物理中的量子纠缠
entry.content:
[TOC]

动机

最初在量子信息课程学到的概念纠缠，如今和凝聚态物理，冷原子，高能物理，黑洞等广泛领域都产生有趣且深刻的联系。

仅仅在凝聚态领域内，张老师的演讲中有一张图展示了量子纠缠和很多领域的联系

量子纠缠就像一个很中心的概念，为此我去查阅一些文献，我的一开始目标是想了解

  1. 在凝聚态系统中，是如何计算系统的量子纠缠？
  2. 量子纠缠和拓扑序，相变等物理量是如何对应或联系？
  3. 如果系统是时间演化的，量子纠缠是如何演化？

文献导览

量子线路由一系列量子门组成以实现幺正变换操作。一般用来做量子计算， 譬如可以进行量子 Fourier 变换。

在做经典信息处理时，一些随机算法得到 大量应用，人们自然会想在处理量子信息时，随机量子态及随机幺正变换会有什么帮助，于是对随机量子线路的研究应运而生。

  • 臂如 R. Oliveira 等发现可以用随机量子门在多项式时间内有效地得到纠缠态。
  • C. Dankert 等用随机量子线路设计出刻画量子信息处理保真度的有效且无偏的方法, 对 \(n\) 量子比特，只需要 \(O(n)\) 规模的量子线路且无需任何辅助比特;
  • P. Hayden 及 W. Brown 等发现随机量子线路中存在快速的量子信息 scrambling 。

近来人们在随机量子线路中研究算符的演化, 探讨其中纠缠的传播 引入随机测量等，我们接下来对此做简要介绍。

模型

我们所要考虑的随机量子线路如图所示

一维开边界的格点模型，格点长度为 \(L\), 每一格点处拥有一个量子比特。在相邻格点上施加两量子比特的量子门操作，于是在时间方向上可以把两层看作一个周期，每层有 \(L / 2\) 个量子门。 这些量子门分为两类

  • 灰色的表示做幺正操作 \(U,\) 即

\[|\psi\rangle \rightarrow U|\psi\rangle\]

  • 蓝色的表示做幺正操作之前先做投影测量 \(P_{\alpha},\) 称为幺正-投影量子门

\[|\psi\rangle \rightarrow U \frac{P_{a}|\psi\rangle}{\| P_{\alpha}|\psi\rangle \|}\]

其中 \(\left\{P_{\alpha}\right\}\) 为正交完备的投影算符，即 \(P_{\alpha} P_{\beta}=P_{\alpha} \delta_{\alpha \beta}\)，$ {} P{}=1$ 。这两类量子门中的幻正操作 \(U\) 一般从随机 Haar 或随机 Clifford 群中随机选取，而这两类群是用来研究混屯不可积系统的最小模型。

结果

幺正-投影量子门在空间和时间上以概率 \(p\) 随机出现，即对任一方块，其为幺正-投影量子门的概率为 \(p,\) 为幺正量子门的概率为 \(1-p\)。当 \(p=0\) 时此模型回到幺正随机量子线路。

纠缠熵在幺正演化中的volume law

在对幺正随机量子线路的研究中，人们发现随系统的演化， 纠缠熵先随时间线性增长，随后按照体积律（volume law）达到饱和 \(^{[265-268]} 。\)

  • [265] Nahum A, Ruhman J, Vijay S, et al. Quantum entanglement growth under random unitary dynamics. Physical Review \(X, 2017,7(3): 031016\).
  • [266] von Keyserlingk C W, Rakovszky T, Pollmann F, et al. Operator hydrodynamics, OTOCs, and entanglement growth in systems without conservation laws[ \(J\) ] . Phys. Rev. X, 2018,8 : 021013
  • [267] Khemani V, Vishwanath A, Huse D A. Operator spreading and the emergence of dissipative hydrodynamics under unitary evolution with conservation laws[J $]$. Physical Review \(X, 2018\), \(8(3): 031057\)
  • [268] Nahum A, Vijay S, Haah J. Operator spreading in random unitary circuits[J]. Phys. Rev. X, 2018,8: 021014

纠缠熵在投影量子门演化中的area law

尚若 \(p=1,\) Y. \(Li\) 等发现测量强烈抑制纠缠熵的增长，使其以面积律 (area law) 达到饱和，他们称此时系统处于量子 Zeno 相 \(^{[271]}\) 。

[271] Li Y, Chen X, Fisher M P. Quantum Zeno effect and the many-body entanglement transition [J]. Physical Review B, \(2018,98(20): 205136\).

纠缠熵相变

自然地，我们可以发现 \(p\) 从 0 逐渐增加到 1，纠缠熵将从以体积律趋于饱和，变成以面积律趋于饱和，中间在某 一 \(p\) 值处发生相变 \(^{[269-272]}\) 。

  • [269] Chan A, Nandkishore R M, Pretko M, et al. Unitary-projective entanglement dynamics[J]. arXiv preprint arXiv:1808.05949v3, 2018.
  • [270] Skinner B, Ruhman J, Nahum A. Measurement-induced phase transitions in the dynamics of entanglement [J] arXiv preprint arXiv:1808.05953, 2018 .
  • [271] Li Y, Chen X, Fisher M P. Quantum Zeno effect and the many-body entanglement transition [J] Physical Review \(B , 2018,98(20): 205136\)
  • [272] Li Y, Chen X, Fisher M. Measurement-driven entanglement transition in hybrid quantum circuits [J] arXiv preprint arXiv:1901.08092, 2019.

量子纠错观点下的纠缠熵相变

近来人们用量子纠错的观点来理解此相变

  • 将随机测量看作量子信息出错
  • 随机幺正演化对此信息起保护作用

但随着 \(p\) 的增 加，错误率达到某一间值，抑制了信息 scrambling，从而发生量子相变 \(^{[273]}\) 。

[273] Choi S, Bao Y, Qi X L, et al. Quantum error correction and entanglement phase transition in random unitary circuits with projective measurements[J]. arXiv preprint arXiv:1903.05124, 2019

非幺正随机量子线路

随机量子线路较离散量子行走拥有更多的物理自由度，因而也蕴含更丰富的物理现象。特别地，我们可以在随机量子线路中考虑非幺正演化，研究其中纠缠熵的传播等基本物理学问题。目前人们对这方面的认识还不够深入，其中的一个原因或许是我们还不能分析清楚非幺正演化在其中所起的作用，以及其与量子测量、量子相干性、量子纠缠等基本量子力学问题之间的关系。我们希望通过 在此类系统中构建一套完整的非幺正量子力学理论，类似我们介绍过的双正交基量子力学，来系统地描述其中波函数的演化，然后讨论其中纠缠熵的传播。

Quantum Error Correction in Scrambling Dynamics and Measurement-Induced Phase Transition

Quantum Error Correction in Scrambling Dynamics and Measurement-Induced Phase Transition

We analyze the dynamics of entanglement entropy in a generic quantum many-body open system from the perspective of quantum information and error corrections. We introduce a random unitary circuit model with intermittent projective measurements, in which the degree of information scrambling by the unitary and the rate of projective measurements are independently controlled. This model displays two stable phases, characterized by the volume-law and area-law scaling entanglement entropy in steady states. The transition between the two phases is understood from the point of view of quantum error correction:

  1. the chaotic unitary evolution protects quantum information from projective measurements that act as errors.
  2. A phase transition occurs when the rate of errors exceeds a threshold that depends on the degree of information scrambling.

We confirm these results using numerical simulations and obtain the phase diagram of our model. Our work shows that information scrambling plays a crucial role in understanding the dynamics of entanglement in an open quantum system and relates the entanglement phase transition to changes in quantum channel capacity.

从这篇文章中认识到Information Scrambling的重要性，但是什么是Information Scrambling我并不了解，因此我搜索到以下文献

  1. Information Scrambling in Quantum Many-Body Systems
    • 加州理工一个中国留学生2020的博士论文
    • out-of-time-ordered correlators (OTOC)
  2. Information Scrambling in Quantum Neural Networks
    • 尤亦庄，沈汇涛，翟荟
  3. Information Scrambling and Loschmidt Echo
    • Loschmidt Echo
  4. Quantum scrambling and the growth of mutual information
    • out-of-time-ordered correlators (OTOC)

Information Scrambling in Quantum Neural Networks

Information Scrambling in Quantum Neural Networks

The quantum neural network is one of the promising applications for near-term noisy intermediate-scale quantum computers. A quantum neural network distills the information from the input wavefunction into the output qubits. In this Letter, we show that this process can also be viewed from the opposite direction:

  • the quantum information in the output qubits is scrambled into the input.
  • This observation motivates us to use the tripartite information, a quantity recently developed to characterize information scrambling, to diagnose the training dynamics of quantum neural networks.
  • We empirically find strong correlation between the dynamical behavior of the tripartite information and the loss function in the training process, from which we identify that the training process has two stages for randomly initialized networks.

In the early stage, the network performance improves rapidly and the tripartite information increases linearly with a universal slope, meaning that the neural network becomes less scrambled than the random unitary. In the latter stage, the network performance improves slowly while the tripartite information decreases. We present evidences that the network constructs local correlations in the early stage and learns large-scale structures in the latter stage. We believe this two-stage training dynamics is universal and is applicable to a wide range of problems. Our work builds bridges between two research subjects of quantum neural networks and information scrambling, which opens up a new perspective to understand quantum neural networks.

Measurement-Driven Phase Transition within a Volume-Law Entangled Phase

Measurement-Driven Phase Transition within a Volume-Law Entangled Phase

We identify a phase transition between two kinds of volume-law entangled phases in non-local but few-body unitary dynamics with local projective measurements.

  1. In one phase, a finite fraction of the system belongs to a fully-entangled state, one for which no subsystem is in a pure state,
  2. while in the second phase, the steady-state is a product state over extensively many, finite subsystems.

We study this "separability" transition in a family of solvable models in which we analytically determine the transition point, the evolution of certain entanglement properties of interest, and relate this to a mean-field percolation transition. since the entanglement entropy density does not distinguish these phases, we introduce the entangling power (which measures whether local measurements outside of two finite subsystems can boost their mutual information) as an order parameter, after considering its behavior in tensor network states, and numerically studying its behavior in a model of Clifford dynamics with measurements.

We argue that in our models, the separability transition coincides with a transition in the computational "hardness" of classically determining the output probability distribution for the steady-state in a certain basis of product states. A prediction for this distribution, which is accurate in the separable phase, and should deviate from the true distribution in the fully-entangled phase, provides a possible benchmarking task for quantum computers.

Information Scrambling in Quantum Many-Body Systems

Information Scrambling in Quantum Many-Body Systems

A closed quantum system never forgets its initial state, but the encoded information can get scrambled and become inaccessible without measuring a large fraction of all the system degrees of freedom.

This scrambling can be diagnosed by studying the spatial spreading of initially local operators under the Heisenberg time evolution, and the decay of the out-of-time-ordered correlators (OTOC).

  1. What insights can OTOCs provide to understand the dynamics of quantum many-body systems?
  2. What are the characteristic behaviors of OTOCs during the time evolution?
  3. How is information scrambling affected by the dissipation in open quantum many-body systems?

  1. The length of the energy splitting oscillation \(\left(\pi / k_{F}=13.6 nm ight)\) is consistent with the Fermi momentum \(k_{F}\) of the Dirac cone.
  2. The length of the exponential decay \(( u / \Delta=13.9 nm ),\) where \( u\) is the Fermi velocity of \(\quad\) surface Dirac cone and \(\Delta\) is the superconductor gap.

How to control Majorana distance?

The only controllable parameter is magnetic field strength (B).

  • Intervortex distance \(\quad R \propto 1 / \sqrt{B}\)
  • More than two vortices

1.3 Majorana modes toward quantum computing

A big gap between the reality and Majorana quantum computing

DiViencenzo Criteria for Universal Quantum Computing

  1. Long decoherence time
  2. An ability to measure qubits one by one, without distributing the others.
  3. A universal set of quantum gates
  4. An ability to initialize the qubits
  5. A scalable physical system with well characterized qubits
1 Long decoherence time

Majorana decoherence time in the iron-based superconductors \[ egin{array}{cll} ext {Majorana distance } & ext { Splitting Energy} & ext { Decoherencetime } \ ext { 50nm } & ext { 10 } \mu eV & T=0.7 n s \ ext { 150nm } & ext { 7neV } & T=1 \mu ext { s } \ ext { 250nm } & ext { 5peV } & T=1 ms \end{array}\] Exponential Majorana protection \(d \propto e^{-R / \lambda}\) 距离越远，寿命越长

Three essential quantum gates for universal quantum computing

  1. Hadamard
  2. T-gate
  3. CNOT

  • Majorana braiding leads to Hadamard gates and CNOT gates. These gates called Clifford gates have topological protection

  • Majorana braiding不能构造出T-gate

  • To realize T-gate, the topological protection must be scarified by fine tuning Majorana hybridization

4. An ability to initialize the qubits

With the combination of Hadamard-gate (H) and T-gate (T), We can get any single qubit state single qubit transformation \[\left( egin{array}{l}a \b\end{array} ight) \approx T^{n_{1}} H^{n_{1}} T^{n_{2}} H^{n_{2}} \cdots\left( egin{array}{l}1 \0\end{array} ight)\]

  • Another evidence of Majoranas

    Spin-down donut-shaped states as Majorana modes

  • Using Majorana for quantum computing is a long way to go

2 Majorana零模和具有拓扑保护的量子计算

报告人 (Speaker)：刘东 清华大学

报告摘要：Topological materials provide a protection from decoherence at the hardware level by using emergent non-Abelian anyons. The simplest non-Abelian anyon involves a defect that binds a Majorana zeroenergy mode. predicted to appear quite naturally in certain superconducting systems. I will review recent progress in the Majorana search, and the challenges in the validation of Majorana devices. Later I will introduce a simple measurement scheme to overcome the problem, and show robust, clear, and universal experimental signatures of Majorana zero modes. I will also discuss a serious type of errors in general topological quantum computation and Majorana qubit. Diabatic corrections only vanish as a power-law function with the length of time for the braid. This power-law behavior can wash out the advantages of topological quantum computation. We found that such diabatic errors can be detected and corrected by applying a sequence of parity measurements.

    • 理论：Z Wang et al. Phys. Rev. B(2015)​ 和 S. C. Zhang et al Phys. Rev. Lett. (2016)
