entry.title: 一维Ising模型：经典与量子
entry.content:
[TOC]

1920 年, Wilhelm Lenz 为描述铁磁相变，提出一个简单的统计模型，并将此模型交给他的学生 Ernst Ising, Ising 求解此模型的一维情形，后来人们将此模型称作经典 Ising 模型。

  1. 一维经典Ising模型没有相变
  2. Onsager 的工作及重整化群的结果都表明二维经典 Ising 模型存在相变。
  3. \(d+1\) 维的经典 Ising 模型等价于一个 \(d\) 维的横场量子 Ising 模型。因此，二维经典 Ising 模型存在相变意味着一维横场量子 Ising 模型也存在相变。

二维经典 Ising 模型存在相变是热涨落与格点间相互作用竞争导致的结果，这是一种温度驱动的相变。而横场量子 Ising 模型的相变则是格点间相互作用使体系位形趋于有序这一因素，与横场导致格点翻转的无序这另一因素间的竞争导致的结果，这是一种描述系统的基本相互作用参量间的竞争，属于量子相变。

经典ising模型

哈密顿量

一维经典 Ising 模型哈密顿量 \[H =-J \sum_{\langle i, j\rangle} \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}-h \sum_{i} \sigma_{i}\] 其中：

  • 一维 \(N\) 个格点的链，晶格上每个格点 \(i\) 有一个自旋 $ _{i}$
  • 自旋 $ _{i}$ 可以取向上 \(\left(\sigma_{i}=+1\right)\) 或向下 \(\left(\sigma_{i}=-1\right)\)
  • \(J\) 是由于相互作用强度，\(-J\) 前面负号表示铁磁性耦合
  • \(h\) 表示外场强度。

当每个格点的状态 \(\sigma_{i}\) 确定下来，系统状态 \(\sigma\) 就确定下来 \[\sigma=\left\{\sigma_{1}, \sigma_{2}, \cdots, \sigma_{N}\right\}\] 每个格点可取两个独立状态，对于有 \(N\) 个格点的系统，就有 \(2^{N}\) 种状态。

转移矩阵解法

考虑周期性边界条件，即 \(\sigma_{N+1}=\sigma_{1},\) 这样体系哈密顿量可写为如下对称形式 \[H =-J \sum_{i=1}^{N} \sigma_{i} \sigma_{i+1}-\frac{h}{2} \sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(\sigma_{i}+\sigma_{i+1}\right)\] 系统配分函数为 \[\begin{aligned}Z &=\sum_{\sigma_{1}=\pm 1} \cdots \sum_{\sigma_{N}=\pm 1} \exp \left[\beta \sum_{i=1}^{N}\left\{J \sigma_{i} \sigma_{i+1}+\frac{h}{2}\left(\sigma_{i}+\sigma_{i+1}\right)\right\}\right] \\&=\sum_{\sigma_{1}=\pm 1} \cdots \sum_{\sigma_{N}=\pm 1}\left\langle\sigma_{1}|P| \sigma_{2}\right\rangle\left\langle\sigma_{2}|P| \sigma_{3}\right\rangle \cdots\left\langle\sigma_{N-1}|P| \sigma_{N}\right\rangle\left\langle\sigma_{N}|P| \sigma_{1}\right\rangle\end{aligned}\] 其中 \(P\) 是一个算符，其矩阵元为 \[\left\langle\sigma_{i}|P| \sigma_{i+1}\right\rangle=\exp \left[\beta\left\{J \sigma_{i} \sigma_{i+1}+\frac{h}{2}\left(\sigma_{i}+\sigma_{i+1}\right)\right\}\right]\] \(P\) 矩阵 \[\begin{aligned}(P)&=\left(\begin{array}{cc}\langle 1|P| 1\rangle & \langle 1|P|-1\rangle \\\langle-1|P| 1\rangle & \langle-1|P|-1\rangle\end{array}\right)\\&=\left(\begin{array}{cc}e^{\beta(J+h)} & e^{-\beta J} \\e^{-\beta J} & e^{\beta(J-h)}\end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\] 因此配分函数 \[\begin{aligned}Z &=\sum_{\sigma_{1}=\pm 1}\left\langle\sigma_{1}\left|P^{N}\right| \sigma_{1}\right\rangle \\&=\operatorname{Tr}\left(P^{N}\right) \\&=\lambda_{1}^{N}+\lambda_{2}^{N}\end{aligned}\]

本征值

其中 \(\lambda_{1}\) 和 \(\lambda_{2}\) 是矩阵 \(P\) 的本征值，可以用久期方程求出来： \[\left|\begin{array}{cc}e^{\beta(J+h)}-\lambda & e^{-\beta J} \\e^{-\beta J} & e^{\beta(J-h)}-\lambda\end{array}\right|=0\] 即 \[\begin{aligned}\left[e^{\beta(J+h)}-\lambda\right]\left[e^{\beta(J-h)}-\lambda\right]-e^{-2 \beta J} &=0 \\\left[e^{2 \beta J}-e^{-2 \beta J}\right]-\lambda\left[e^{\beta(J+h)}+e^{\beta(J-h)}\right]+\lambda^{2} &=0\\\lambda^{2}-2 \lambda e^{\beta J} \cosh (\beta h)+2 \sinh (2 \beta J)&=0\end{aligned}\] 上面关于 \(\lambda\) 的一元二次方程解为 \[\begin{aligned}\lambda_{\pm}&=\frac{2 e^{\beta J} \cosh (\beta h) \pm \sqrt{4 e^{2 \beta J} \cosh ^{2}(\beta h)-8 \sinh (2 \beta J)}}{2} \\&=e^{\beta J} \cosh (\beta h) \pm\left[e^{2 \beta J} \cosh ^{2}(\beta h)-2 \sinh (2 \beta J)\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}\\&=e^{\beta J}\left\{\cosh (\beta h) \pm\left[\cosh ^{2}(\beta h)-2 e^{-2 \beta J} \sinh (2 \beta J)\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}\right\}\end{aligned}\] 那么配分函数就可以表示为（记 \(\lambda_{+}=\lambda_{1}, \lambda_{-}=\lambda_{2},\) 即 \(\lambda_{+}>\lambda_{-} ）\) \[Z=\lambda_{+}^{N}+\lambda_{-}^{N}=\lambda_{+}^{N}\left(1+\frac{\lambda_{-}^{N}}{\lambda_{+}^{N}}\right)\] 在热力学极限下， \(N \longrightarrow \infty\) 那么 \(\frac{\lambda_{-}^{N}}{\lambda_{+}^{N}} \longrightarrow 0\) : \[\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N} \ln Z \approx \ln \lambda_{+}=\beta J+\ln \left\{\cosh (\beta h)+\left[\cosh ^{2}(\beta h)-2 e^{-2 \beta J} \sinh (2 \beta J)\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}\right\}\]

热力学性质

有了配分函数就可以计算体系

  • Helmholtz 自由能

\[F=-\frac{\ln Z}{\beta}\]

  • 磁化强度 \(M=-\left(\frac{\partial F}{\partial h}\right)_{T}\)

\[M=-\left(\frac{\partial F}{\partial h}\right)_{T}\]

这两个量都是连 续的。因此，一维经典 Ising 模型没有相变。但是 Onsager 的工作及后来重整化群的结果都表明二维经典 Ising 模型存在相变。

量子ising模型

一维量子横场 Ising 模型 \[\begin{aligned}H &=-\sum_{i}\left[h \sigma_{i}^{x}+J \sigma_{i}^{z} \sigma_{i+1}^{z}\right]\\&=-\sum_{i}\left[\sigma_{i}^{x}+\lambda \sigma_{i}^{z} \sigma_{i+1}^{z}\right]\end{aligned}\] 其中 \(\lambda=\frac{J}{h}\)

对哈密顿量做如下变换下 \[\sigma^{x} \longrightarrow \sigma^{z}\\\sigma^{z} \longrightarrow-\sigma^{x}\] 哈密顿量在如下变换下不变 \[H =-\sum_{i}\left[\sigma_{i}^{z}+\lambda \sigma_{i}^{x} \sigma_{i+1}^{x}\right]\]

升降算符

升降算符为 \[\begin{aligned}\sigma_{i}^{+} &=\frac{1}{2}\left(\sigma_{i}^{x}+i \sigma_{i}^{y}\right) \\\sigma_{i}^{-} &=\frac{1}{2}\left(\sigma_{i}^{x}-i \sigma_{i}^{y}\right)\end{aligned}\] 对易性质

  • 对于 \(i \neq j\)

\[\left[\sigma_{i}^{-}, \sigma_{i}^{+}\right]=0\]

  • 对于 \(i = j\)

\[\begin{array}{c}\left\{\sigma_{i}^{-}, \sigma_{i}^{+}\right\}=1 \\\left\{\sigma_{i}^{-}, \sigma_{i}^{-}\right\}=\left\{\sigma_{i}^{+}, \sigma_{i}^{+}\right\}=0 .\end{array}\]

硬核玻色子

由对易性质可以推出 \[\left(\sigma_{i}^{+}\right)^{2}=0\] 即 \[\sigma_{i}^{+}\left[\sigma_{i}^{+}|F\rangle\right]=0\] 即 \(\sigma_{i}^{+}\) 不能在同一个格点上产生两个个玻色子激发。这是所谓的硬球条件。 \(\sigma_{i}^{+}\) 和 \(\sigma_{i}^{-}\) 被视为硬核玻色子。

处理 1 维硬核玻色子的标准过程是使用 Jordan-Wigner 变换将自旋算符变为费米子。

Jordan-Wigner 变换

定义 Jordan-Wigner 变换 \[\begin{array}{l}c_{1}=\sigma_{1}^{-} \\c_{1}^{\dagger}=\sigma_{1}^{+}\end{array}\]

\[\begin{aligned}c_{i}&=\prod_{j=1}^{i-1} \exp \left[i \pi \sigma_{j}^{+} \sigma_{j}^{-}\right] \sigma_{i}^{-} \\c_{i}&=\sigma_{i}^{+} \prod_{j=1}^{i-1} \exp \left[i \pi \sigma_{j}^{+} \sigma_{j}^{-}\right]\end{aligned}\]

新的费米子算符有性质 \[\left\{c_{i}, c_{j}^{\dagger}\right\}=\delta_{i j}\\\left\{c_{i}, c_{i}\right\}=0\] 不同于玻色子，即使在不同格点费米子算符也反对易，这是源于下面的非局域因子 \[K_{i}=\exp \left[i \pi \sum_{j=1}^{i-1} \sigma_{j}^{+} \sigma_{j}^{-}\right]=\exp \left[i \pi \sum_{j=1}^{i-1} n_{j}\right]\] 这称作无序项或孤子项

考虑周其边界条件 \[\sigma_{1}^{\alpha}=\sigma_{N+1}^{\alpha}, \quad \alpha=x, y, z\] Jordan-Wigner 变换后的哈密顿量可写为下面形式 \[H =N-2 \sum_{i} c_{i}^{\dagger} c_{i}-\lambda \sum_{i}\left[c_{i}^{\dagger}-c_{i}\right]\left[c_{i+1}^{\dagger}+c_{i+1}\right]\]

动量空间

经过傅里叶变换 \[\begin{aligned}c_{q}&=\left(\frac{1}{N}\right)^{1 / 2} \sum_{j=1}^{N} c_{j} \exp \left(i q R_{j}\right) \\c_{q}^{\dagger}&=\left(\frac{1}{N}\right)^{1 / 2} \sum_{j=1}^{N} c_{j}^{\dagger} \exp \left(-i q R_{j}\right)\end{aligned}\] 哈密顿量变为 \[H =N-2 \sum_{q}(1+\lambda \cos q) c_{q}^{\dagger} c_{q}-\lambda \sum_{q}\left(e^{-i q} c_{q}^{\dagger} c_{-q}^{\dagger}-e^{i q} c_{q} c_{-q}\right)\] 波矢完备集是 $q=2 m / N $，对所有 \(q>0\) 的模式进行求和，并写成矩阵形式 \[\begin{aligned}H &=N+\sum_{q>0}\left[-2(1+\lambda \cos q)\left(c_{q}^{\dagger} c_{q}+1-c_{q} c_{-q}^{\dagger}\right)+\lambda\left(\left(e^{i q}-e^{-i q}\right) c_{q}^{\dagger} c_{-q}^{\dagger}-\left(e^{i q}-e^{-i q}\right) c_{-q} c_{q}\right)\right] \\&=\sum_{q>0}\left[-2(1+\lambda \cos q)\left(c_{q}^{\dagger} c_{q}-c_{-q} c_{-q}^{\dagger}\right)+2 i \lambda \sin q\left(c_{q}^{\dagger} c_{-q}^{\dagger}-c_{-q} c_{q}\right)\right] \\&=-2 \sum_{q>0}\left(\begin{array}{cc}c_{q}^{\dagger} & c_{-q}\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}1+\lambda \cos q & -i \lambda \sin q \\i \lambda \sin q & -1-\lambda \cos q\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}c_{q} \\c_{-q}^{\dagger}\end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\]

对角化

用波戈留波夫变换将 \(c_{q}, c_{q}^{\dagger}\) 转换成 \(\eta_{q}, \eta_{q}^{\dagger}\) \[\begin{aligned}\left(\begin{array}{c}\eta_{q} \\\eta_{-q}^{\dagger}\end{array}\right)&=\left(\begin{array}{ll}u_{q} & i v_{q} \\i v_{q} & u_{q}\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}c_{q} \\c_{-q}^{\dagger}\end{array}\right)\\&=\left(\begin{array}{c}u_{q} c_{q}+i v_{q} c_{-q}^{\dagger} \\i v_{q} c_{q}+u_{q} c_{-q}^{\dagger}\end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\] 哈密顿量经过波戈留波夫变换 \[\begin{aligned}H &=-2 \sum_{q>0}\left(\begin{array}{cc}c_{q}^{\dagger} & c_{-q}\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}1+\lambda \cos q & -i \lambda \sin q \\i \lambda \sin q & -1-\lambda \cos q\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}c_{q} \\c_{-q}^{\dagger}\end{array}\right)\\&=-2 \sum_{q>0}\left(\begin{array}{cc}\eta_{q}^{\dagger} & \eta_{-q}\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}u_{q} & i v_{q} \\i v_{q} & u_{q}\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}1+\lambda \cos q & -i \lambda \sin q \\i \lambda \sin q & -1-\lambda \cos q\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}u_{q} & -i v_{q} \\-i v_{q} & u_{q}\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}\eta_{q} \\\eta_{-q}^{\dagger}\end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\] 为了让哈密顿量有对角形式，需要让 \(\left(u_{q},-i v_{q}\right)^{T}\) 是哈密顿矩阵的本征矢 \[\left(\begin{array}{cc}1+\lambda \cos q & -i \lambda \sin q \\i \lambda \sin q & -1-\lambda \cos q\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}u_{q} \\-i v_{q}\end{array}\right)=-\omega_{q}\left(\begin{array}{c}u_{q} \\-i v_{q}\end{array}\right)\] 求解本征方程得到

  • 本征向量

\[\begin{aligned}u_{q}&=\frac{\lambda \sin q}{\sqrt{2 \omega_{q}\left(\omega_{q}+1+\lambda \cos q\right)}}\\v_{q}&=\frac{\omega_{q}+1+\lambda \cos q}{\sqrt{2 \omega_{q}\left(\omega_{q}+1+\lambda \cos q\right)}}\end{aligned}\]

  • 本征值

\[\omega_{q}=\sqrt{\left(1+2 \lambda \cos q+\lambda^{2}\right)}\]

哈密顿量就可以写成对角化的形式 \[\begin{aligned}H& =2 \sum_{q>0} \omega\left(\eta_{q}^{\dagger} \eta_{q}-\eta_{-q} \eta_{-q}^{\dagger}\right)\\&=2 \sum_{q} \omega_{q} \eta_{q}^{\dagger} \eta_{q}+E_{0}\end{aligned}\] 其中无自旋费米子的基态能量为 \(E_{0}=-\sum_{q} \omega_{q}\)

参考文献

《基于神经网络量子态的横场 Ising 模型研究》2019

entry.title: The Gaussian Integral
entry.content:
[TOC]

1 fundamental

the Gaussian integral \[\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-x^{2}} d x=\sqrt{\pi}\] Proof: \[\begin{aligned} \left(\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-x^{2}} d x\right)^{2}=&\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-x^{2}} d x \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-y^{2}} d y\\=&\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)} d x d y\end{aligned}\] By polar coordinates \(e^{-\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)}=e^{-r^{2}}\) \[\begin{aligned} \iint_{\mathbf{R}^{2}} e^{-\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)} d(x, y) &=\int_{0}^{2 \pi} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-r^{2}} r d r d \theta \\ &=2 \pi \int_{0}^{\infty} r e^{-r^{2}} d r \\ &=2 \pi \int_{-\infty}^{0} \frac{1}{2} e^{s} d s \\ &=\pi \int_{-\infty}^{0} e^{s} d s \\ &=\pi\left(e^{0}-e^{-\infty}\right) \\ &=\pi \end{aligned}\] thus \[\left(\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-x^{2}} d x\right)^{2}=\pi \quad \rightarrow \quad \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-x^{2}} d x=\sqrt{\pi}\]

scaled

\[\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{ a x^{2}} d x=\sqrt{\frac{ \pi}{a}}\]

proof: \[\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{a x^{2}} d x=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{(\sqrt{a} x)^{2}} d x\] scale \(\sqrt{a} x \rightarrow y\), then \(d x=\frac{1}{\sqrt{a}}d y\) \[\begin{aligned} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{(\sqrt{a x})^{2}} d x&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{a}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{a y^{2}} d y\\&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{a}}\sqrt{\pi}\\&=\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}}\end{aligned}\]

shift

\[\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-a(x+b)^{2}} d x=\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}}\]

proof:

replace \(x+b=y\), then \(d x= d y\) \[\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-a(x+b)^{2}} d x=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{a y^{2}} d y= \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}}\]

Generalizations

\[\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-a x^{2}+b x+c} d x=\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}} e^{\frac{b^{2}}{4 a}+c}\]

proof: \[\begin{aligned} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-a x^{2}+b x+c} d x&=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-a(x+\frac{b^{}}{ a})^{2}+\frac{b^{2}}{4 a}+c} d x\\&=e^{\frac{b^{2}}{4 a}+c} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-a(x+\frac{b^{}}{ a})^{2}} d x\\&=\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}} e^{\frac{b^{2}}{4 a}+c}\end{aligned}\] special case：

  1. \(\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \exp \left(-\frac{1}{2} a x^{2}+J x\right) d x =\left(\frac{2 \pi}{a}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \exp \left(\frac{J^{2}}{2 a}\right)\)
  2. \(\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \exp \left(-\frac{1}{2} a x^{2}+i J x\right) d x=\left(\frac{2 \pi}{a}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \exp \left(-\frac{J^{2}}{2 a}\right)\)

Application: 1

We now want to introduce interactions，the scalar field interact with an external potential. This potential is described by a function known as a source current \(J(x) \phi(x)\)

Application: 2

the Hubbard-Stratonovich transformation \[\exp \left\{-\frac{a}{2} x^{2}\right\}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{2 \pi a}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \exp \left[-\frac{y^{2}}{2 a}-i x y\right] d y\]

complex

\[\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \exp \left(\frac{1}{2} i a x^{2}+i J x\right) d x=\left(\frac{2 \pi i}{a}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \exp \left(\frac{-i J^{2}}{2 a}\right)\]

proof: \[\begin{aligned} \left(\frac{1}{2} i a x^{2}+i J x\right)&=\frac{1}{2} i a\left(x^{2}+\frac{2 J x}{a}+\left(\frac{J}{a}\right)^{2}-\left(\frac{J}{a}\right)^{2}\right)\\&=-\frac{1}{2} \frac{a}{i}\left(x+\frac{J}{a}\right)^{2}-\frac{i J^{2}}{2 a}\end{aligned}\]

Application: 1

Relation between Schrödinger's equation and the path integral formulation of quantum mechanics

The transition probability amplitude \[\begin{aligned} \langle F | \psi(T)\rangle&=\left\langle F\left|\exp \left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} \hat{H} T\right)\right| 0\right\rangle\\&=\left\langle F\left|\exp \left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} \hat{H} \delta t\right) \exp \left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} \hat{H} \delta t\right) \cdots \exp \left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} \hat{H} \delta t\right)\right| 0\right\rangle\end{aligned}\] over each small time-interval, we can ignore the noncommutativity of kinetic energy and potential energy operators \[\begin{aligned} \exp \left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} \hat{H} \delta t\right) &=\exp \left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} [\frac{\hat{p}^{2}}{2 m}+V(\hat{q})] \delta t\right)\\&\approx \exp \left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} \frac{\hat{p}^{2}}{2 m} \delta t\right) \exp \left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} V\left(q_{j}\right) \delta t\right)\end{aligned}\]

2 multiple dimensions

Gaussian integrals in higher dimensions \[\int \exp \left(-\frac{1}{2} x \cdot A \cdot x+J \cdot x\right) d^{n} x=\sqrt{\frac{(2 \pi)^{n}}{\operatorname{det} A}} \exp \left(\frac{1}{2} J \cdot A^{-1} \cdot J\right)\] This integral is performed by [diagonalization] of symmetric matrix A with an [orthogonal transformation] \(\boldsymbol{x}=\boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{y}\)

proof； \[\begin{aligned} \boldsymbol{x} &=\boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{y} \\ d \boldsymbol{x} &=\boldsymbol{S} d \boldsymbol{y} \\ d x_{1} d x_{2} \ldots &=|\boldsymbol{S}| d y_{1} d y_{2} \ldots \end{aligned}\] where a determinant of unity \(|\boldsymbol{S}|=1\) . The integral \[\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \ldots \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \exp \left(-\frac{1}{2} \boldsymbol{x}^{T} \boldsymbol{A} \boldsymbol{x}\right) d x_{1} d x_{2} \ldots d x_{n} = \int \exp \left(-\frac{1}{2} \boldsymbol{y}^{T} \boldsymbol{S}^{-1} \boldsymbol{A} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{y}\right) d y_{1} d y_{2} \ldots d y_{n}\] we demand that the matrix \(\boldsymbol{S}\) be a diagonalizing matrix, \[\boldsymbol{S}^{-1} \boldsymbol{A} \boldsymbol{S}=\left[\begin{array}{cccc}{d_{1}} & {0} & {0} & {\cdots} \\ {0} & {d_{2}} & {0} & {\cdots} \\ {0} & {0} & {d_{3}} & {\cdots} \\ {\vdots} & {\vdots} & {\vdots} & {\ddots}\end{array}\right]\] changes the integral to \[\begin{aligned} \int \exp \left(-\frac{1}{2} \boldsymbol{y}^{T} \boldsymbol{S}^{-1} \boldsymbol{A} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{y}\right) d y_{1} d y_{2} \ldots d y_{n}&=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2}\left(d_{1} y_{1}^{2}+d_{2} y_{2}^{2}+\ldots d_{n} y_{n}^{2}\right)\right] d y_{1} d y_{2} \ldots d y_{n}\\&=\sqrt{\frac{2 \pi}{d_{1}}} \cdot \sqrt{\frac{2 \pi}{d_{2}}} \cdots \sqrt{\frac{2 \pi}{d_{n}}}=\frac{(2 \pi)^{n / 2}}{|\boldsymbol{A}|^{1 / 2}}\end{aligned}\] where \(\prod_{n=1}^{2} \lambda_{n}=|\boldsymbol{A}|=\operatorname{det}(A)\)

with linear term

\[\begin{aligned} -\frac{1}{2} \boldsymbol{x}^{T} \boldsymbol{A} \boldsymbol{x}+\boldsymbol{J}^{T} \boldsymbol{x} &\rightarrow-\frac{1}{2} \boldsymbol{y}^{T} \boldsymbol{D} \boldsymbol{y}+\boldsymbol{J}^{T} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{y}\\&=-\frac{1}{2}\left(d_{1} y_{1}^{2}+d_{2} y_{2}^{2}+\ldots d_{n} y_{n}^{2}\right)+J_{a} S_{a 1} y_{1}+J_{a} S_{a 2} y_{2}+\ldots J_{a} S_{a n} y_{n}\\&=\sum_i -\frac{1}{2} d_{i}\left(y_{i}-\frac{J_{a} S_{a i}}{d_{i}}\right)^{2}+\frac{\left(J_{a} S_{a i}\right)^{2}}{2 d_{i}}\end{aligned}\]

where \(-\frac{1}{2} d_{1} y_{1}^{2}+J_{a} S_{a 1} y_{1}=-\frac{1}{2} d_{1}\left(y_{1}-\frac{J_{a} S_{a 1}}{d_{1}}\right)^{2}+\frac{\left(J_{a} S_{a 1}\right)^{2}}{2 d_{1}}\)

making the substitution \(y_{i} \rightarrow y_{i}-J_{a} S_{a i} / d_{i}\) \[\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \exp \left(-\frac{1}{2} \boldsymbol{x}^{T} \boldsymbol{A} \boldsymbol{x}+\boldsymbol{J}^{T} \boldsymbol{x}\right) d^{n} x=\frac{(2 \pi)^{n / 2}}{|\boldsymbol{A}|^{1 / 2}} \exp \left[\frac{\left(J_{a} S_{a i}\right)^{2}}{2 d_{i}}\right]\] the exponential term can be put into a more recognizable form \[\frac{\left(J_{a} S_{a i}\right)^{2}}{2 d_{i}}=\frac{J_{a} S_{a i}\left(J_{b} S_{b i}\right)^{T}}{2 d_{i}}=\frac{J_{a} S_{a i} S_{i b}^{-1} J_{b}}{2 d_{i}}\] where \(S^{T}=S^{-1}\) give \(S_{a i} S_{i b}^{-1}=\delta_{a b}\) \[\frac{J_{a} S_{a i} S_{i b}^{-1} J_{b}}{2 d_{i}}=\frac{1}{2} J_{a} S_{a i} \cdot \frac{1}{d_{i}} \cdot S_{i b}^{-1} J_{b}\] t the diagonal matrix defined \(\boldsymbol{S}^{-1} \boldsymbol{A} \boldsymbol{S}=\boldsymbol{D}\) allows a expression \(S^{-1} A^{-1} S=D^{-1}\) in n matrix summation notation \[S_{i k}^{-1} A_{k b}^{-1} S_{b i}=D_{i i}^{-1}=\frac{1}{d_{i}}\] Plugging this \(\frac{1}{d_{i}}=S_{i k}^{-1} A_{k b}^{-1} S_{b i}\) into equation \[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2} J_{a} S_{a i} \cdot \frac{1}{d_{i}} \cdot S_{i b}^{-1} J_{b} &=\frac{1}{2} J_{a} S_{a i} S_{i k}^{-1} A_{k b}^{-1} S_{b i} S_{i c}^{-1} J_{c} \\ &=\frac{1}{2} J_{k} A_{k c}^{-1} J_{c} \\ &=\frac{1}{2} J^{T} A^{-1} J \end{aligned}\] The Gaussian integral \[\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \exp \left(-\frac{1}{2} \boldsymbol{x}^{T} \boldsymbol{A} \boldsymbol{x}+\boldsymbol{J}^{T} \boldsymbol{x}\right) d x_{1} d x_{2} \ldots d x_{n}=\frac{(2 \pi)^{n / 2}}{|\boldsymbol{A}|^{1 / 2}} \exp \left[\frac{1}{2} \boldsymbol{J}^{T} \boldsymbol{A}^{-1} \boldsymbol{J}\right]\]

Application

  1. In quantum field theory, the matrix \(\boldsymbol{A}^{-1}\) is related to what is known as a propagator, and it’s akin to the term in the probability amplitude

\[\partial^{2}+m^{2}\]

It is essentially a Green’s function that describes the physical propagation of a particle created at the source \(\boldsymbol{J}\)and annihilated at the “antisource” or sink \(\boldsymbol{J}^{T}\). The matrix identity \(\boldsymbol{A}^{-1} \boldsymbol{A}=\boldsymbol{I}\) gets transcribed into \[\left(\partial^{2}+m^{2}\right) D(\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{y})=\delta^{4}(\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{y})\] or the path integral, where the quantity \(D(\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{y})\) is the propagator.

  1. In quantum field theory n-dimensional integrals of the form \[\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \exp \left(-\frac{1}{\hbar} f(q)\right) d^{n} q\]

For small values of Planck's constant, f can be expanded about its minimum \[\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \exp \left[-\frac{1}{\hbar}\left(f\left(q_{0}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(q-q_{0}\right)^{2} f^{\prime \prime}\left(q-q_{0}\right)+\cdots\right)\right] d^{n} q\] neglect higher order terms this integral can be integrated explicitly. \[\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \exp \left[-\frac{1}{\hbar}(f(q))\right] d^{n} q \approx \exp \left[-\frac{1}{\hbar}\left(f\left(q_{0}\right)\right)\right] \sqrt{\frac{(2 \pi \hbar)^{n}}{\operatorname{det} f^{\prime \prime}}}\]

Example in 2d

The Gaussian integral in two dimensions \[\int \exp \left(-\frac{1}{2} A_{i j} x^{i} x^{j}\right) d^{2} x=\sqrt{\frac{(2 \pi)^{2}}{\operatorname{det} A}}\] where A is a two-dimensional symmetric matrix with components specified as \[A=\left[\begin{array}{ll}{a} & {c} \\ {c} & {b}\end{array}\right]\] Diagonalize the matrix \[A_{i j} x^{i} x^{j} \equiv x^{T} A x=x^{T}\left(O O^{T}\right) A\left(O O^{T}\right) x=\left(x^{T} O\right)\left(O^{T} A O\right)\left(O^{T} x\right)\] where, since A is a real symmetric matrix, we can choose O to be orthogonal, and hence also a unitary matrix. O can be obtained from the eigenvectors of A. We choose O such that: \[D=O^{T} A O=\left[\begin{array}{cc}{\lambda_{-}} & {0} \\ {0} & {\lambda_{+}}\end{array}\right]\] is diagonal.

Eigenvalues \[\left[\begin{array}{ll}{a} & {c} \\ {c} & {b}\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l}{u} \\ {v}\end{array}\right]=\lambda\left[\begin{array}{l}{u} \\ {v}\end{array}\right]\] The eigenvalues are solutions of the characteristic polynomial \[\begin{array}{l}{(a-\lambda)(b-\lambda)-c^{2}=0} \\ {\lambda^{2}-\lambda(a+b)+a b-c^{2}=0}\end{array}\] The eigenvalues are \[\begin{aligned} \lambda_{ \pm} &=\frac{1}{2}(a+b) \pm \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{(a+b)^{2}-4\left(a b-c^{2}\right)} \\ \lambda_{ \pm} &=\frac{1}{2}(a+b) \pm \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{a^{2}+2 a b+b^{2}-4 a b+4 c^{2}} \\ \lambda_{ \pm} &=\frac{1}{2}(a+b) \pm \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{(a-b)^{2}+4 c^{2}} \end{aligned}\] Eigenvectors

Substitution of the eigenvalues back into the eigenvector equation \[v=-\frac{\left(a-\lambda_{ \pm}\right) u}{c}, \quad v=-\frac{c u}{\left(b-\lambda_{ \pm}\right)}\]

\[\frac{a-\lambda_{ \pm}}{c}=\frac{c}{b-\lambda_{ \pm}}\]

The eigenvectors can be written as: \[\left[\begin{array}{c}{\frac{1}{\eta}} \\ {-\frac{a-\lambda_{-}}{c \eta}}\end{array}\right], \quad\left[\begin{array}{c}{-\frac{b-\lambda_{+}}{c \eta}} \\ {\frac{1}{\eta}}\end{array}\right]\] where normalizing factor \[\eta=\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{a-\lambda_{-}}{c}\right)^{2}}=\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{b-\lambda_{+}}{c}\right)^{2}}\] two eigenvectors are orthogonal to each other \[\left(\frac{1}{\eta}\quad -\frac{a-\lambda_{-}}{c \eta} \right)\left(\begin{array}{c}{-\frac{b-\lambda_{+}}{c \eta}} \\ {\frac{1}{\eta}}\end{array}\right)=\frac{a-\lambda_{-}}{c \eta^2}+\frac{b-\lambda_{+}}{c \eta^2}=1\] orthogonal matrix

The orthogonal matrix is constructed by assigning the normalized eigenvectors as columns in the orthogonal matrix \[O=\left[\begin{array}{cc}{\frac{1}{\eta}} & {-\frac{b-\lambda_{+}}{c \eta}} \\ {-\frac{a-\lambda_{-}}{c \eta}} & {\frac{1}{\eta}}\end{array}\right]\] note \(\operatorname{det}(O)=1\) and \(O^{-1}=O^{T}\)

3 moment average

\[I_{n}(a) \equiv \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-a x^{2}} x^{n} d x\]

setting \[\begin{aligned} x & \equiv a^{-1 / 2} y \\ d x &=a^{-1 / 2} d y \\ y^{2} &=a x^{2} \end{aligned}\] then \[\begin{aligned} I_{n}(a) &=a^{-1 / 2} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-y^{2}}\left(a^{-1 / 2} y\right)^{n} d y \\ &=a^{-(n+1) / 2} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-y^{2}} y^{n} d y \end{aligned}\] for \(n=0\) this is the usual Gaussian integral, \[I_{0}(a)=\frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2} a^{-1 / 2}=\frac{1}{2} \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}}\] For \(n=1\), the integrand is integrable by quadrature, \[I_{1}(a)=a^{-1} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-y^{2}} y d y=a^{-1}\left[-\frac{1}{2} e^{-y^{2}}\right]_{0}^{\infty}=\frac{1}{2} a^{-1}\] for \(n>1\) use the identity \[\begin{aligned}-\frac{\partial}{\partial a} I_{n-2}(a) &=-\frac{\partial}{\partial a} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-a x^{2}} x^{n-2} d x \\ &=-\int_{0}^{\infty}-x^{2} e^{-a x^{2}} x^{n-2} d x \\ &=\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-a x^{2}} x^{n} d x \\ &=I_{n}(a) \end{aligned}\]

even

\(n=2 s\) \[\begin{aligned} I_{n}(a) &=\left(-\frac{\partial}{\partial a}\right) I_{n-2}(a) \\ &=\left(-\frac{\partial}{\partial a}\right)^{2} I_{n-4} \\ &=\ldots=\left(-\frac{\partial}{\partial a}\right)^{n / 2} I_{0}(a) \\ &=\frac{\partial^{n / 2}}{\partial a^{n / 2}} I_{0}(a) \\ &=\frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2} \frac{\partial^{n / 2}}{\partial a^{n / 2}} a^{-1 / 2} \end{aligned}\] then \[\begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{\infty} x^{2 s} e^{-a x^{2}} d x &=\frac{\left(s-\frac{1}{2}\right) !}{2 a^{s+1 / 2}} \\ &=\frac{(2 s-1) ! !}{2^{s+1} a^{s}} \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}} \end{aligned}\]

odd

\(n=2 s+1\) \[\begin{aligned} I_{n}(a) &=\left(-\frac{\partial}{\partial a}\right) I_{n-2}(a) \\ &=\left(-\frac{\partial}{\partial a}\right)^{2} I_{n-4}(a) \\ &=\ldots=\left(-\frac{\partial}{\partial a}\right)^{(n-1) / 2} I_{1}(a) \\ &=\frac{\partial^{(n-1) / 2}}{\partial a^{(n-1) / 2}} I_{1}(a) \\ &=\frac{1}{2} \frac{\partial^{(n-1) / 2}}{\partial a^{(n-1) / 2}} a^{-1} \end{aligned}\] then \[\int_{0}^{\infty} x^{2 s+1} e^{-a x^{2}} d x=\frac{s !}{2 a^{s+1}}\] the general solution \[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-a x^{2}} x^{n} d x=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}{\frac{(n-1) ! !}{2^{n / 2+1} a^{n / 2}} \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}}} & {\text { for } n \text { even }} \\ {\frac{\left[\frac{1}{2}(n-1)\right] !}{2 a^{(n+1) / 2}}} & {\text { for } n \text { odd }}\end{array}\right.\] The first few values are \[\begin{array}{l}{I_{0}(a)=\frac{1}{2} \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}}} \\ {I_{1}(a)=\frac{1}{2 a}} \\ {I_{2}(a)=\frac{1}{4 a} \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}}} \\ {I_{3}(a)=\frac{1}{2 a^{2}}} \\ {L_{4}(a)=\frac{3}{8 a^{2}} \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}}} \\ {I_{5}(a)=\frac{1}{a^{3}}} \\ {I_{6}(a)=\frac{15}{16 a^{3}} \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}}}\end{array}\]

Related Integral

\[H_{n}(a) \equiv \frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-a x^{2}} x^{n} d x=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}{\frac{2 I_{n}(a)}{\sqrt{\pi}}} & {\text { for } n \text { even }} \\ {0} & {\text { for } n \text { odd }}\end{array}\right.\]

more general \[\begin{aligned} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x^{n} e^{-a x^{2}+b x} d x &=i^{-n} a^{-(n+1) / 2} \sqrt{\pi} e^{b^{2} /(4 a)} U\left(-\frac{1}{2} n ; \frac{1}{2} ;-b^{2} / 4 a\right) \\ &=\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}} e^{b^{2} /(4 a)} \sum_{k=0}^{ | n / 2\rfloor} \frac{n !}{k !(n-2 k) !} \frac{(2 b)^{n-2 k}}{(4 a)^{n-k}} \\ &=\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}} e^{b^{2} /(4 a)} \sum_{k=0}^{ | n / 2\rfloor}\left(\begin{array}{c}{n} \\ {2 k}\end{array}\right)(2 k-1) ! !(2 a)^{k-n} b^{n-2 k} \end{aligned}\] where \(U(a ; b ; x)\) is a confluent hypergeometric function of the second kind

4 Take Home Information

  • \(\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-a x^{2}+b x+c} d x=\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}} e^{\frac{b^{2}}{4 a}+c}\)
  • \(\int \exp \left(-\frac{1}{2} x \cdot A \cdot x+J \cdot x\right) d^{n} x=\sqrt{\frac{(2 \pi)^{n}}{\operatorname{det} A}} \exp \left(\frac{1}{2} J \cdot A^{-1} \cdot J\right)\)
  • \(\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-a x^{2}} x^{n} d x=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}{\frac{(n-1) ! !}{2^{n / 2+1} a^{n / 2}} \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}}} & {\text { for } n \text { even }} \\ {\frac{\left[\frac{1}{2}(n-1)\right] !}{2 a^{(n+1) / 2}}} & {\text { for } n \text { odd }}\end{array}\right.\)

References

entry.title: 二次量子化
entry.content:
参考文献

《Nonequilibrium Many-Body Theory of Quantum Systems: A Modern Introduction》Gianluca Stefanucci

Noninteracting models

1 Bloch theorem and band structure

A crystal consists of a unit cell repeated periodically in three, two, or one dimensions. Each unit cell contains the same (finite) number of atoms arranged in the same geometry. An example is graphene, i.e., a planar structure of \(s p^{2}\) -bonded carbon atoms arranged in a honeycomb lattice as illustrated in Fig. 2.4. In this case the unit cell consists of two carbon atoms, \(a\) and \(b\) in the figure, repeated periodically along the directions \(v _{+}\) and \(v _{-}\). The unit cells can be labeled with a vector of integers \(n =\left(n_{1}, \ldots, n_{d} ight)\) where \(d\) is the dimension of the crystal, see again Fig. \(2.4 .\) The expansion of the vector \(n\) over the orthonormal basis \(\left\{ e _{i} ight\}\) with \(\left( e _{i} ight)_{j}=\delta_{i j}\) reads \[n =\sum_{i=1}^{d} n_{i} e _{i}\] Two unit cells with labels \(n\) and \(n ^{\prime}\) are nearest neighbor if \(\left| n - n ^{\prime} ight|=1 .\) As for the PPP model we assign to each unit cell a set of localized orbitals \(\left\{\varphi_{ n s \sigma} ight\}\) which we assume already orthonormal and denote by \(\hat{d}_{ n s \sigma}^{\dagger}\) and \(\hat{d}_{ n s \sigma}\), the creation and annihilation operators for electrons in the orbital \(\varphi_{ n s \sigma}\). The index \(s\) runs over all orbitals of a given unit cell. In the case of graphene we may assign a single \(p_{z}\) orbital to each carbon, so \(s=1,2\).

In the absence of magnetic fields or other couplings that break the spin symmetry, the matrix elements of \(\hat{h}\) are \[h_{ n s \sigma n ^{\prime} s^{\prime} \sigma^{\prime}}=\delta_{\sigma \sigma^{\prime}} h_{ n s n ^{\prime} s^{\prime}}\] If we choose orbitals localized around the atomic positions then the matrix elements \(h_{ n s n ^{\prime} s^{\prime}}\) are very small for \(\left| n - n ^{\prime} ight| \gg 1 .\) We then discard \(h_{ n s n ^{\prime} s^{\prime}}\) unless \(n\) and \(n ^{\prime}\) are nearest neighbors. The periodicity of a crystal is reflected in the fact that the unit cell Hamiltonian \(h_{ n s n s^{\prime}},\) as well as the Hamiltonian connecting two nearest neighbor cells \(h_{ n s} n \pm e _{i} s^{\prime},\) does not depend on \(n\). We therefore define the matrices \[h_{s s^{\prime}} \equiv h_{ ns ns ^{\prime}}\] and \[ egin{aligned}T_{i, s s^{\prime}} \equiv h_{ n + e _{i} s n s^{\prime}}, \quad \Rightarrow \quad T_{i, s s^{\prime}}^{\dagger} &=h_{ n + e _{i} s^{\prime} n s}^{*}=h_{ n s n + e _{i} s^{\prime}} \&=h_{ n - e _{i} s n s^{\prime}}\end{aligned}\] With these definitions our model for the noninteracting Hamiltonian of a crystal takes the form \[\hat{H}_{0}=\sum_{ n \sigma} \sum_{s s^{\prime}}\left(h_{s s^{\prime}} \hat{d}_{ n s \sigma}^{\dagger} \hat{d}_{ n s^{\prime} \sigma}+\sum_{i=1}^{d} T_{i, s s^{\prime}} \hat{d}_{ n + e _{i} s \sigma}^{\dagger} \hat{d}_{ n s^{\prime} \sigma}+T_{i, s s^{\prime}}^{\dagger} \hat{d}_{ n - e _{i} s \sigma}^{\dagger} \hat{d}_{ n s^{\prime} \sigma} ight)\] To better visualize the matrix structure of \(\hat{H}_{0}\) we introduce the vector of \(\hat{d}\) -operators \[\hat{ d }_{ n \sigma}^{\dagger} \equiv\left(\hat{d}_{ n 1 \sigma}^{\dagger}, \hat{d}_{ n 2 \sigma}^{\dagger}, \ldots ight), \quad \hat{ d }_{ n \sigma}=\left(\hat{d}_{ n 1 \sigma}^{\dagger}, \hat{d}_{ n 2 \sigma}^{\dagger}, \ldots ight)^{\dagger}\] and rewrite \(\hat{H}_{0}\) in terms of the product between these vectors and the matrices \(h, T_{i}\) and \(T_{i}^{\dagger}\) \[\hat{H}_{0}=\sum_{ n \sigma}\left(\hat{ d }_{ n \sigma}^{\dagger} h \hat{ d }_{ n \sigma}+\sum_{i=1}^{d} \hat{ d }_{ n + e _{i} \sigma}^{\dagger} T_{i} \hat{ d }_{ n \sigma}+\hat{ d }_{ n - e _{i} \sigma}^{\dagger} T_{i}^{\dagger} \hat{ d }_{ n \sigma} ight)\] The strategy to find the one-particle eigenvalues of \(\hat{H}_{0}\) consists of considering a finite block of the crystal and then letting the volume of the block go to infinity. This block is, for convenience, chosen as a parallelepiped with edges given by \(d\) linearly independent vectors of integers \(N _{1}, \ldots, N _{d}\) each radiating from a given unit cell. Without loss of generality we can choose the radiating unit cell at the origin. The set \(V _{b}\) of all unit cells contained in the block is then \[V _{b}=\left\{ n : rac{ n \cdot N _{i}}{ N _{i} \cdot N _{i}}<1 ext { for all } i ight\}\] In the case of a one-dimensional crystal we can choose only one vector \(N _{1}=N\) and the unit cells of the block \(n =n \in V _{b}\) are those with \(n=0,1, \ldots, N-1\). For the two-dimensional graphene, instead, we may choose, e.g., \(N _{1}=(N, 0)\) and \(N _{2}=(0, M)\) or \(N _{1}=(N, N)\) and \(N _{2}=(M,-M)\) or any other couple of linearly independent vectors. When the volume of the block tends to infinity the eigenvalues of the crystal are independent of the choice of the block. Interestingly, however, the procedure below allows us to know the eigenvalues of \(\hat{H}_{0}\) for any finite \(N _{1}, \ldots, N _{d},\) and hence to have access to the eigenvalues of blocks of different shapes. We come back to this aspect at the end of the section. To simplify the mathematical treatment we impose periodic boundary conditions along \(N _{1}, \ldots, N _{d}\), i.e., we "wrap" the block onto itself forming a ring in \(d=1\), a torus in \(d=2\), etc. This choice of boundary conditions is known as the Born-von Karman (BvK) boundary condition and turns out to be very convenient. Other kinds of boundary condition would lead to the same results in the limit of large \(V _{b}\). The Bvk condition implies that the cells \(n\) and \(n + N _{i}\) are actually the same cell and we therefore make the identifications \[\hat{ d }_{ n + N _{i} \sigma}^{\dagger} \equiv \hat{ d }_{ n \sigma}^{\dagger}, \quad \hat{ d }_{ n + N _{i} \sigma} \equiv \hat{ d }_{ n \sigma}\] for all \(N _{i}\). We are now in the position to show how the diagonalization procedure works. Consider the Hamiltonian (2.8) in which the sum over \(n\) is restricted to unit cells in \(V _{b}\) and the identification (2.10) holds for all boundary terms with one \(\hat{d}\) -operator outside \(V _{b}\). To bring \(\hat{H}_{0}\) into a diagonal form we must find a suitable linear combination of the \(\hat{d}\) -operators that preserves the anti-commutation relations, as discussed in Section \(1.6 .\) For this purpose we construct the matrix \(U\) with elements \[U_{ nk }= rac{1}{\sqrt{\left| V _{b} ight|}} e^{ ik \cdot n }\] where \(\left| V _{b} ight|\) is the number of unit cells in \(V _{b} .\) In (2.11) the row index runs over all \(n \in V _{b}\) whereas the column index runs over all vectors \(k =\left(k_{1}, \ldots, k_{d} ight)\) with components \(-\pi<\) \(k_{i} \leq \pi\) and, more importantly, fulfilling \[k \cdot N _{i}=2 \pi m_{i}, \quad ext { with } m_{i} ext { integers. }\] We leave it as an exercise for the reader to prove that the number of \(k\) vectors with these properties is exactly \(\left| V _{b} ight|\) and hence that \(U\) is a square matrix. Due to property (2.12) the quantity \(U_{ nk }\) is periodic in \(n\) with periods \(N _{1}, \ldots, N _{d}\). It is this periodicity that we now exploit to prove that \(U\) is unitary. Consider the following set of equalities and the likes with \(k_{2}^{\prime}, \ldots, k_{d}^{\prime} .\) In the second line of the above identities we use the fact that the sum over all \(n \in V _{b}\) of a periodic function \(f( n )\) is the same as the sum of \(f\left( n - e _{1} ight)\). For the left and the right hand side of these equations to be the same we must either have \(k = k ^{\prime}\) or \[\sum_{ n } U_{ n k }^{*} U_{ n k ^{\prime}}=0 \quad ext { for } k eq k ^{\prime}\] Since for \(k = k ^{\prime}\) the sum \(\sum_{ n } U_{ n k }^{*} U_{ n k }=1\), the matrix \(U\) is unitary and hence the operators \[\hat{ c }_{ k \sigma}= rac{1}{\sqrt{\left| V _{b} ight|}} \sum_{ n \in V _{b}} e^{- i k \cdot n } \hat{ d }_{ n \sigma}, \quad \hat{ c }_{ k \sigma}^{\dagger}= rac{1}{\sqrt{\left| v _{b} ight|}} \sum_{ n \in V _{b}} e^{ i k \cdot n } \hat{ d }_{ n \sigma}^{\dagger}\] preserve the anti-commutation relations. The inverse relations read \[\hat{ d }_{ n \sigma}= rac{1}{\sqrt{\left| V _{b} ight|}} \sum_{ k } e^{i k \cdot n } \hat{ c }_{ k \sigma}, \quad \hat{ d }_{ n \sigma}^{\dagger}= rac{1}{\sqrt{\left| V _{b} ight|}} \sum_{ k } e^{- i k \cdot n } \hat{ c }_{ k \sigma}^{\dagger}\] and the reader can easily check that due to property (2.12) the \(\hat{d}\) -operators satisfy the BvK boundary conditions (2.10). Inserting these inverse relations into (2.8) (in which the sum is restricted to \(n \in V _{b}\) ) we get the Hamiltonian \[\hat{H}_{0}=\sum_{ k \sigma} \hat{ c }_{ k \sigma}^{\dagger}\left(h+\sum_{i=1}^{d}\left(T_{i} e^{- i k_{i}}+T_{i}^{\dagger} e^{ i k_{i}} ight) ight) \hat{ c }_{ k \sigma}\] In this expression the matrix \(h_{ k }\) is Hermitian and can be diagonalized. Let \(\epsilon_{ k u}\) be the eigenvalues of \(h_{ k }\) and \(u_{ k }\) be the unitary matrix that brings \(h_{ k }\) into the diagonal form, i.e., \(h_{ k }=u_{ k } \operatorname{diag}\left(\epsilon_{ k 1}, \epsilon_{ k 2}, \ldots ight) u_{ k }^{\dagger} .\) The unitary matrix \(u_{ k }\) has the dimension of the number of orbitals in the unit cell and should not be confused with the matrix \(U\) whose dimension is \(\left| V _{b} ight| .\) We now perform a further change of basis and construct the following linear combinations of the \(\hat{c}\) -operators with fixed \(k\) vector \[\hat{ b }_{ k \sigma}=u_{ k }^{\dagger} \hat{ c }_{ k \sigma}, \quad \hat{ b }_{ k \sigma}^{\dagger}=\hat{ c }_{ k \sigma}^{\dagger} u_{ k }\] Denoting by \(u_{ k u}(s)=\left(u_{ k } ight)_{s u}\) the \((s, u)\) matrix element of \(u_{ k }\) the explicit form of the \(\hat{b}\) -operators is \[\hat{b}_{ k u \sigma}=\sum_{s} u_{ k u}^{*}(s) \hat{c}_{ k s \sigma}, \quad \hat{b}_{ k u \sigma}^{\dagger}=\sum_{s} u_{ k u}(s) \hat{c}_{ k s \sigma}^{\dagger}\] With these definitions the Hamiltonian \(\hat{H}_{0}\) takes the desired form since \[ egin{aligned}\hat{H}_{0} &=\sum_{ k \sigma} \hat{ c }_{ k \sigma}^{\dagger} u_{ k } \operatorname{diag}\left(\epsilon_{ k 1}, \epsilon_{ k 2}, \ldots ight) u_{ k }^{\dagger} \hat{ c }_{ k \sigma} \&=\sum_{ k u \sigma} \epsilon_{ k u} \hat{b}_{ k u \sigma}^{\dagger} \hat{b}_{ k u \sigma}\end{aligned}\] We have derived the Bloch theorem: the one-particle eigenvalues of \(\hat{H}_{0}\) are obtained by diagonalizing \(h_{ k }\) for all \(k\) and the corresponding one-particle eigenkets \(| k u \sigma angle=\hat{b}_{ k u \sigma}^{\dagger}|0 angle\) have overlap with the original basis functions \(\left| n s \sigma^{\prime} ight angle=d_{n s \sigma^{\prime}}^{\dagger}|0 angle\) given by \[\psi_{ k u \sigma}\left( n s \sigma^{\prime} ight)=\left\langle n s \sigma^{\prime} \mid k u \sigma ight angle= rac{\delta_{\sigma \sigma^{\prime}}}{\sqrt{\left| V _{b} ight|}} e^{i k \cdot n } u_{ k u}(s)\] which is a plane-wave with different amplitudes on different atoms of the same unit cell. When the volume of the block \(\left| V _{b} ight| ightarrow \infty\) the eigenvalues \(\epsilon_{ k u}\) become a continuum called a band. \(^{3}\) We then have a band for each \( u\) and the total number of bands coincides with the number of localized orbitals per unit cell. Each crystal is characterized by its band structure and, as we see in Section 6.3 .4 , the band structure can be experimentally measured. If we choose the localized basis functions to be of the form (2.1) and subsequently we want to increase the accuracy of the calculations by reducing the spacing \(\Delta\), then in the limit \(\Delta ightarrow 0\) the quantities \(u_{ k u}(s) ightarrow u_{ k u}( r )\) become continuous functions of the position \(r\) in the cell. These functions can be periodically extended to all space by imposing a requirement that they assume the same value in the same point of all unit cells. In the literature the periodic functions \(u_{ k u}( r )\) are called Bloch functions. Below we illustrate some elementary applications of this general framework.

One-band model

Figure 2.5 (a) A ring with \(N\) unit cells. (b) Eigenvalues of the ring Hamiltonian with \(t=-1\) and \(\epsilon=2\) for different numbers \(N\) of unit cells. The eigenvalues with \(N=61\) and 121 are shifted upward by 1 and 2 respectively.

The simplest example is a one-dimensional crystal with one orbital per unit cell, see Fig. \(2.5( a ) .\) Then the matrices \(h \equiv \epsilon\) and \(T \equiv t\) are \(1 imes 1\) matrices and the one-particle eigenvalues are \[\epsilon_{k}=\epsilon+t e^{- i k}+t e^{ i k}=\epsilon+2 t \cos k\] If the number \(N\) of unit cells is, e.g., odd, then the one-dimensional \(k\) vector takes the values \(k=2 \pi m / N\) with \(m=- rac{(N-1)}{2}, \ldots, rac{(N-1)}{2},\) as follows from (2.12). The eigenvalues (2.14) are displayed in Fig. \(2.5( b )\) for different \(N\). It is clear that when \(N ightarrow \infty\) they become a continuum and form one band.

Two-band model

Figure 2.6 (a) A ring with \(N\) unit cells and two atoms per cell. (b) Eigenvalues of the ring Hamiltonian with \(t=-1, \epsilon=2\) and \(\Delta=1 / 2\) for different numbers \(N\) of unit cells.

Another example of a one-dimensional crystal is shown in Fig. \(2.6( a ) .\) Each unit cell consists of two different atoms, \(a\) and \(b\) in the figure. We assign a single orbital per atom and neglect all off-diagonal matrix elements except those connecting atoms of type \(a\) to atoms of type \(b\). For simplicity we also consider the case that the distance between two nearest neighbor atoms is everywhere the same along the crystal. Then the matrices \(h\) and \(T\) are \(2 imes 2\) matrices with the following structure \[h=\left( egin{array}{cc}\epsilon+\Delta & t \t & \epsilon-\Delta\end{array} ight), \quad T=\left( egin{array}{ll}0 & t \0 & 0\end{array} ight)\] where \(\Delta\) is an energy parameter that takes into account the different nature of the atoms. The structure of \(T_{s s^{\prime}}=h_{n+1 s n s^{\prime}},\) see \((2.7),\) can be derived by checking the overlap between atom \(s\) in cell \(n+1\) and atom \(s^{\prime}\) in cell \(n\). For instance, if we take cell 2 we see from Fig. 2.6 (a) that atom \(a\) has overlap with atom \(b\) in cell 1 , hence \(T_{a b}=t\), but it does not have overlap with atom \(a\) in cell 1 , hence \(T_{a a}=0 .\) On the other hand atom \(b\) in cell 2 does not have overlap with any atom in cell \(1,\) and hence \(T_{b a}=T_{b b}=0 .\) The eigenvalues of \[h_{k}=h+T e^{- i k}+T^{\dagger} e^{ i k}=\left( egin{array}{cc}\epsilon+\Delta & t\left(1+e^{- i k} ight) \t\left(1+e^{ i k} ight) & \epsilon-\Delta\end{array} ight)\] are \[\epsilon_{k \pm}=\epsilon \pm \sqrt{\Delta^{2}+2 t^{2}(1+\cos k)}\] and are displayed in Fig. \(2.6( b )\) for different numbers \(N\) of unit cells. As in the previous example, the values of \(k\) have the form \(2 \pi m / N\) with \(m=- rac{(N-1)}{2}, \ldots, rac{(N-1)}{2}\) for odd \(N\). When \(N ightarrow \infty\) the \(\epsilon_{k \pm}\) become a continuum and form two bands separated by an energy gap of width \(2 \Delta\). If the crystal contains two electrons per unit cell then the lower band is fully occupied whereas the upper band is empty. In this situation we must provide a minimum energy \(2 \Delta\) to excite one electron in an empty state; the crystal behaves like an insulator if the gap is large and like a semiconductor if the gap is small. It is also worth noting that for \(\Delta=0\) we recover the previous example but with \(2 N\) atoms rather than \(N\).

Graphene

Another important example that we wish to discuss is the two-dimensional crystal with which we opened this section. Graphene is a single layer of graphite and, as such, not easy to isolate. It was not until 2004 that graphene was experimentally realized by transferring a single layer of graphite onto a silicon dioxide substrate [9] , an achievement which was rewarded with the Nobel prize in physics in \(2010 .\) The coupling between the graphene and the substrate is very weak and does not alter the electrical properties of the graphene. Before 2004 experimentalists were already able to produce tubes of graphene with a diameter of few nanometers. These carbon nanotubes can be considered as an infinitely long graphene strip wrapped onto a cylinder. Due to their mechanical (strong and stiff) and electrical properties, carbon nanotubes are among the most studied systems at the time of writing this book. There exist several kinds of nanotube depending on how the strip is wrapped. The wrapping is specified by a pair of integers \((P, Q)\) so that atoms separated by \(P_{ V _{+}}+Q_{ v -}\) are identified. Below we consider the armchair nanotubes for which \((P, Q)=(N, N)\) and hence the axis of the tube is parallel to \(v _{+}- v _{-}\)

Let us define the vector \(N _{1}=(N, N)\) and the vector parallel to the tube axis \(N _{2}=\) \((M,-M)\). The armchair nanotube is recovered when \(M ightarrow \infty\). For simplicity we assign a single \(p_{z}\) orbital to each carbon atom and consider only those off-diagonal matrix elements that connect atoms \(a\) to atoms \(b\). From Fig. 2.4 we then see that the matrices \(h, T_{1}\) and \(T_{2}\) must have the form \(^{4}\) \[h=\left( egin{array}{cc}0 & t \t & 0\end{array} ight), \quad T_{1}=\left( egin{array}{cc}0 & t \0 & 0\end{array} ight), \quad T_{2}=\left( egin{array}{cc}0 & t \0 & 0\end{array} ight)\] The eigenvalues of \[h_{ k }=h+\sum_{i=1}^{2}\left(T_{i} e^{-i k_{i}}+T_{i}^{\dagger} e^{i k_{i}} ight)=\left( egin{array}{cc}0 & t\left(1+e^{-i k_{1}}+e^{-i k_{2}} ight) \t\left(1+e^{i k_{1}}+e^{i k_{2}} ight) & 0\end{array} ight)\] can easily be calculated and read \[\epsilon_{ k \pm}=\pm t \sqrt{1+4 \cos rac{k_{1}-k_{2}}{2}\left(\cos rac{k_{1}-k_{2}}{2}+\cos rac{k_{1}+k_{2}}{2} ight)}\] The possible values of \(k\) belong to a square with vertices in \((\pm \pi, \pm \pi)\) and fulfill (2.12), i.e., \[ egin{array}{l} k \cdot N _{1}=N\left(k_{1}+k_{2} ight)=2 \pi m_{1} \k \cdot N _{2}=M\left(k_{1}-k_{2} ight)=2 \pi m_{2}\end{array}\]

Figure 2.7 (a) Equivalent domain of \(k\) vectors. The grey areas with the same roman numbers are separated either by the vector \((2 \pi, 0)\) or by the vector \((0,2 \pi)\). (b) Eigenvalues of a (5,5) armchair nanotube. The thick lines correspond to the valence band (below zero) and the conduction band (above zero). All bands in between the top and the conduction band and in between the bottom and the valence band are doubly degenerate.

From these relations it is evident that an equivalent domain of \(k\) vectors, like the one illustrated in Fig. \(2.7( a ),\) is more convenient for our analysis. This equivalent domain is a rectangle tilted by \(\pi / 4,\) with the short edge equal to \(\sqrt{2} \pi\) and the long edge equal to \(2 \sqrt{2} \pi\). If we define \(k_{x}=k_{1}+k_{2}\) and \(k_{y}=k_{1}-k_{2}\) then \(-2 \pi<k_{x} \leq 2 \pi\) and \(-\pi<k_{y} \leq \pi\) and hence \[ egin{array}{l}k_{x}=2 \pi rac{m_{1}}{N}, \quad ext { with } m_{1}=-N+1, \ldots, N \k_{y}=2 \pi rac{m_{2}}{M}, \quad ext { with } m_{2}=- rac{(M-1)}{2}, \ldots, rac{M-1}{2}\end{array}\] for odd \(M\). The reader can easily check that the number of \(k\) is the same as the number of atoms in the graphene block. In the limit \(M ightarrow \infty\) the quantum number \(k_{y}\) becomes a continuous index and we obtain \(2 imes 2 N\) one-dimensional bands corresponding to the number of carbon atoms in the transverse direction, \(^{5}\) \[\epsilon_{k_{y} k_{x} \pm}=\pm t \sqrt{1+4 \cos rac{k_{y}}{2}\left(\cos rac{k_{y}}{2}+\cos rac{k_{x}}{2} ight)}\] The set of all carbon atoms in the transverse direction can be considered as the unit cell of the one-dimensional crystal, which is the nanotube.

In Fig. \(2.7( b )\) we plot the eigenvalues \(\epsilon_{k_{y} k_{x} \pm}\) for the \((N, N)=(5,5)\) armchair nanotube. Since the neutral nanotube has one electron per atom, all bands with negative energy are fully occupied. It is noteworthy that the highest occupied band (valence band) and the lowest unoccupied band (conduction band) touch only in two points. Around these points the energy dispersion is linear and the electrons behave as if they were relativistic [10] . Increasing the diameter of the nanotube also, \(k_{x}\) becomes a continuous index and the \(\epsilon_{k \pm}\) become the eigenvalues of the two-dimensional graphene. In this limit the \(\epsilon_{ k \pm}\) form two two-dimensional bands which still touch in only two points. Due to its so peculiar band structure graphene is classified as a semi-metal, that is a crystal with properties between a metal and a semiconductor.

Fano model

The Fano model is ubiquitous in condensed matter physics as it represents the simplest schematization of a discrete state "interacting" with a continuum of states. It was originally introduced by Fano to explain a universal asymmetric line-shape observed in the absorption spectrum of several physical systems [14]. We introduce it here to model an atom or a molecule adsorbed on the surface of a metal, see the schematic illustration below.

Let \(|\epsilon Q angle\) be the single-particle energy eigenket of the metal, where \(Q\) is a quantum number (continuous or discrete) that accounts for the degeneracy of the eigenvalue \(\epsilon\). In this section the spin index carried by states and operators is understood since everything is diagonal in spin space. Equivalently, we can think of fermions with spin zero. For the atom we consider only a single localized orbital and denote by \(\left|\epsilon_{0} ight angle\) the corresponding ket. For large distances between the atom and the surface the Hamiltonian of the system is the sum of the Hamiltonian \(\hat{H}_{ ext {met }}\) of the metal and the Hamiltonian \(\hat{H}_{ ext {at }}\) of the atom \[\hat{H}_{ met }+\hat{H}_{ at }=\int d \epsilon d Q \epsilon \hat{d}_{\epsilon Q}^{\dagger} \hat{d}_{\epsilon Q}+\epsilon_{0} \hat{d}_{0}^{\dagger} \hat{d}_{0}\] where the \(\hat{d}\) -operators create or annihilate electrons and hence satisfy the anti-commutation relations \[\left[\hat{d}_{\epsilon Q}, \hat{d}_{\epsilon^{\prime} Q^{\prime}}^{\dagger} ight]_{+}=\delta\left(\epsilon-\epsilon^{\prime} ight) \delta\left(Q-Q^{\prime} ight), \quad\left[\hat{d}_{0}, \hat{d}_{0}^{\dagger} ight]_{+}=1\] When the atom approaches the surface the overlap \(T_{\epsilon Q} \equiv\left\langle\epsilon Q|\hat{h}| \epsilon_{0} ight angle\) increases and cannot be neglected any longer. In this regime the Hamiltonian of the system becomes \[\hat{H}_{0}=\hat{H}_{ met }+\hat{H}_{ at }+\int d \epsilon d Q\left(T_{\epsilon Q} \hat{d}_{\epsilon Q}^{\dagger} \hat{d}_{0}+T_{\epsilon Q}^{*} \hat{d}_{0}^{\dagger} \hat{d}_{\epsilon Q} ight)\] This is the general structure of the Fano model. It is common (and for later purposes also instructive) to discretize the continuum of states by retaining only one state \(\left|\epsilon_{k} Q_{k} ight angle\) in the volume element \(\Delta \epsilon \Delta Q\). Then, for small volume elements the Fano Hamiltonian can be approximated as \[\hat{H}_{0}=\sum_{k} \epsilon_{k} \hat{d}_{k}^{\dagger} \hat{d}_{k}+\epsilon_{0} \hat{d}_{0}^{\dagger} \hat{d}_{0}+\sum_{k}\left(T_{k} \hat{d}_{k}^{\dagger} \hat{d}_{0}+T_{k}^{*} \hat{d}_{0}^{\dagger} \hat{d}_{k} ight)\] where the discrete \(\hat{d}\) -operators satisfy the anti-commutation relations \(\left[\hat{d}_{k}, \hat{d}_{k^{\prime}} ight]_{+}=\delta_{k k^{\prime}} .\) To recover the continuum limit we establish the correspondence \[T_{k}=\sqrt{\Delta \epsilon \Delta Q} T_{\epsilon_{k} Q_{k}}\] for the off-diagonal matrix elements of \(\hat{h}\), and \[\hat{d}_{k}=\sqrt{\Delta \epsilon \Delta Q} \hat{d}_{\epsilon_{k} Q_{k}}, \quad \hat{d}_{k}^{\dagger}=\sqrt{\Delta \epsilon \Delta Q} \hat{d}_{\epsilon_{k} Q_{k}}^{\dagger}\] for the fermionic operators. Letting \(\Delta \epsilon \Delta Q ightarrow 0\) the discrete Hamiltonian (2.18) reduces to the continuum Hamiltonian (2.17) and \[\left[\hat{d}_{\epsilon_{k} Q_{k}}, \hat{d}_{\epsilon_{k^{\prime}} Q_{k^{\prime}}}^{\dagger} ight]_{+}= rac{\delta_{k k^{\prime}}}{\Delta \epsilon \Delta Q} ightarrow \delta\left(\epsilon-\epsilon^{\prime} ight) \delta\left(Q-Q^{\prime} ight)\] We now calculate the atomic occupation \(n_{0}\) for a given Fermi energy \(\epsilon_{ F }\), which is the energy of the highest occupied level of the metal. Let \(|\lambda angle\) be the single-particle eigenkets of \(\hat{H}_{0}\) with eigenenergies \(\epsilon_{\lambda}\). The corresponding annihilation and creation operators \(\hat{c}_{\lambda}\) and \(\hat{c}_{\lambda}^{\dagger}\) are a linear combination of the original \(\hat{d}\) -operators as discussed in Section 1.5 , \[\hat{c}_{\lambda}^{\dagger}=\left\langle\epsilon_{0} \mid \lambda ight angle \hat{d}_{0}^{\dagger}+\sum_{k}\langle k \mid \lambda angle \hat{d}_{k}^{\dagger}\] and with a similar equation for the adjoint. The ground state \(\left|\Phi_{0} ight angle\) of the system is obtained by occupying all the \(|\lambda angle\) s with energies \(\epsilon_{\lambda} \leq \epsilon_{ F }\) and reads \[\left|\Phi_{0} ight angle=\prod_{\lambda: \epsilon_{\lambda} \leq \epsilon_{F}} \hat{c}_{\lambda}^{\dagger}|0 angle\] To calculate the atomic occupation \(n_{0}=\left\langle\Phi_{0}\left|\hat{d}_{0}^{\dagger} \hat{d}_{0} ight| \Phi_{0} ight angle\) we evaluate the ket \(\hat{d}_{0}\left|\Phi_{0} ight angle\) by moving the operator \(\hat{d}_{0}\) through the string of \(\hat{c}^{\dagger}\) -operators, as we did in (1.57). The difference here is that the anti-commutator is \(\left[\hat{d}_{0}, \hat{c}_{\lambda}^{\dagger} ight]_{+}=\left\langle\epsilon_{0} \mid \lambda ight angle\) rather than a Kronecker delta. Hubbard model

The Hubbard model was originally introduced to describe transition metals and rare-earth metals, i.e., solids composed of atoms with very localized outer electrons \((d\) or \(f\) shells). In these materials the degree of localization of the outer-electron orbitals is so high that the Coulomb integrals \(v_{s_{1} s_{2} s_{3} s_{4}}\) can be approximated as in (2.3) with the diagonal elements \(U_{s} \equiv v_{s s}\) about an order of magnitude larger than the off-diagonal ones. For this reason Hubbard, in a milestone paper from 1963 [15], included only the diagonal interaction \(U_{s}\) in his treatment and wrote the model Hamiltonian \[\hat{H}=\hat{H}_{0}+\hat{H}_{ int }=\sum_{\sigma} \sum_{s s^{\prime}} h_{s s^{\prime}} \hat{d}_{s \sigma}^{\dagger} \hat{d}_{s^{\prime} \sigma}+\sum_{s} U_{s} \hat{n}_{s \uparrow} \hat{n}_{s \downarrow}\] that today carries his name. In this Hamiltonian the sums run over the lattice position \(s\) of the nuclei, the \(\hat{d}\) -operators are fermionic annihilation and creation operators for electrons with the usual anti-commutation relations \[\left[\hat{d}_{s \sigma}, \hat{d}_{s^{\prime} \sigma^{\prime}}^{\dagger} ight]_{+}=\delta_{\sigma \sigma^{\prime}} \delta_{s s^{\prime}}, \quad\left[\hat{d}_{s \sigma}, \hat{d}_{s^{\prime} \sigma^{\prime}} ight]_{+}=0\] and \(\hat{n}_{s \sigma}=\hat{d}_{s \sigma}^{\dagger} \hat{d}_{s \sigma}\) is the occupation operator for electrons in \(s\) with spin \(\sigma\). The matrix elements \(h_{s s^{\prime}}\) are typically set to zero if the distance between \(s\) and \(s^{\prime}\) exceeds a few lattice spacings. In the context of model Hamiltonians the off-diagonal matrix elements \(h_{s s^{\prime}}\) are also called hopping integrals or simply hoppings since they multiply the operator \(\hat{d}_{s \sigma}^{\dagger} \hat{d}_{s^{\prime} \sigma}\), which destroys an electron in \(s^{\prime}\) and creates an electron in \(s,\) an operation that can be pictured as the hopping of an electron from \(s^{\prime}\) to \(s\). It is interesting to note that in the Hubbard model two electrons interact only if they occupy the same atomic site (and of course have opposite spins).

To gain some insight into the physics of the Hubbard model we compare two limiting situations, i.e., \(\hat{H}_{ ext {int }}=0\) and \(\hat{H}_{0}=0 .\) We see that electrons behave as "waves" if \(\hat{H}_{ ext {int }}=0\) and as "particles" if \(\hat{H}_{0}=0\); how they behave when both \(\hat{H}_{0}\) and \(\hat{H}_{ ext {int }}\) are nonzero is a fascinating problem intimately related to wave-particle dualism. To readers interested in the physics of the Hubbard model we suggest the review article in Ref. [16] and the books in Refs. [17,18].

For \(\hat{H}_{ ext {int }}=0\) the Hubbard Hamiltonian describes noninteracting electrons on a lattice. Let \(|k \sigma angle=c_{k \sigma}^{\dagger}|0 angle\) be the one-particle eigenkets with energies \(\epsilon_{k} .\) If we order the energies \(\epsilon_{k} \leq \epsilon_{k+1}\), the state of lowest energy with \(N_{\uparrow / \downarrow}\) electrons of spin up/down is \[|\Phi angle=\prod_{k=1}^{N_{\uparrow}} \prod_{k^{\prime}=1}^{N_{\downarrow}} \hat{c}_{k \uparrow}^{\dagger} \hat{c}_{k^{\prime} \downarrow}^{\dagger}|0 angle \quad ext { with } \quad \hat{H}_{0}|\Phi angle=\left(\sum_{k=1}^{N_{\uparrow}} \epsilon_{k}+\sum_{k^{\prime}=1}^{N_{\downarrow}} \epsilon_{k^{\prime}} ight)|\Phi angle\] We can say that in \(|\Phi angle\) the electrons behave as "waves" since they have probability 0 or 1 of being in a delocalized state \(|k \sigma angle .\) The \(N\) -particle ground state of \(\hat{H}_{0}\) is obtained by minimizing the eigenvalue in (2.30) with respect to \(N_{\uparrow}\) and \(N_{\downarrow}\) under the constraint \(N_{\uparrow}+N_{\downarrow}=N\). For nondegenerate energies \(\epsilon_{k}<\epsilon_{k+1}\), the ground state of \(\hat{H}_{0}\) with an even number \(N\) of electrons is unique and reads \[\left|\Phi_{0} ight angle=\prod_{k=1}^{N / 2} \hat{c}_{k \uparrow}^{\dagger} \hat{c}_{k \downarrow}^{\dagger}|0 angle\] We leave it as an exercise for the reader to show that \(\left|\Phi_{0} ight angle\) is also an eigenstate of the total spin operators [see (1.92)], \[\hat{ S }=\left(\hat{S}^{x}, \hat{S}^{y}, \hat{S}^{z} ight) \equiv \sum_{s} \hat{ S }_{s}=\sum_{s}\left(\hat{S}_{s}^{x}, \hat{S}_{s}^{y}, \hat{S}_{s}^{z} ight)\] with vanishing eigenvalue, i.e., it is a singlet. If we perturb the system with a weak external magnetic field \(B\) along, say, the \(z\) axis and discard the coupling to the orbital motion, the noninteracting part of the Hamiltonian changes to \[\hat{H}_{0} ightarrow \hat{H}_{0}-g \mu_{ B } \hat{ S } \cdot B =\hat{H}_{0}- rac{1}{2} g \mu_{ B } B\left(\hat{N}_{\uparrow}-\hat{N}_{\downarrow} ight)\] with \(g\) the electron gyromagnetic ratio, \(\mu_{ B }\) the Bohr magneton, and \(\hat{N}_{\sigma}=\sum_{s} \hat{n}_{s \sigma}\) the operator for the total number of particles of spin \(\sigma\). The eigenkets (2.30) are also eigenkets of this new Hamiltonian but with a different eigenvalue \[\left(\hat{H}_{0}-g \mu_{ B } \hat{ S } \cdot B ight)|\Phi angle=\left(\sum_{k=1}^{N_{\uparrow}}\left(\epsilon_{k}- rac{1}{2} g \mu_{ B } B ight)+\sum_{k^{\prime}=1}^{N_{\downarrow}}\left(\epsilon_{k^{\prime}}+ rac{1}{2} g \mu_{ B } B ight) ight)|\Phi angle\] Thus, in the presence of an external magnetic field the state (2.31) is no longer the lowest in energy since for, e.g., \(B>0,\) it becomes energetically convenient to have more electrons of spin up than of spin down. This is the typical behavior of a Pauli paramagnet, that is a system whose total spin is zero for \(B=0\) and grows parallel to \(B\) for \(B eq 0 .\)

Next we discuss the case \(\hat{H}_{0}=0\). The Hamiltonian \(\hat{H}_{ ext {int }}\) is already in a diagonal form and the generic eigenket can be written as \[\left|\Phi_{X Y} ight angle=\prod_{s \in X} \prod_{s^{\prime} \in Y} \hat{d}_{s \uparrow}^{\dagger} \hat{d}_{s^{\prime} \downarrow}^{\dagger}|0 angle\] where \(X\) and \(Y\) are two arbitrary collections of atomic sites. We can say that in \(\left|\Phi_{X Y} ight angle\) the electrons behave like "particles" since they have probability 0 or 1 of being on a given atomic site. The energy eigenvalue of \(\left|\Phi_{X Y} ight angle\) is \[E_{X Y}=\sum_{s \in X \cap Y} U_{s}\] The ground state(s) for a given number \(N=N_{\uparrow}+N_{\downarrow}\) of electrons can be constructed by choosing \(X\) and \(Y\) that minimize the energy \(E_{X Y}\). Denoting by \(N_{ V }\) the total number of atomic sites, we have that for \(N \leq N_{ V }\) all states with \(X \cap Y=\emptyset\) are ground states (with zero energy) and, again, the system behaves like a Pauli paramagnet.

In conclusion, neither \(\hat{H}_{0}\) nor \(\hat{H}_{ ext {int }}\) favors any kind of magnetic order. However, their sum \(\hat{H}_{0}+\hat{H}_{ ext {int }}\) sometimes does. In Section 2.5 we illustrate an example of this phenomenon.

Particle-hole symmetry

In this section we solve explicitly the Hubbard model with only two sites, the so called Hubbard dimer, with Hamiltonian \[\hat{H}=T \sum_{\sigma}\left(\hat{d}_{1 \sigma}^{\dagger} \hat{d}_{2 \sigma}+\hat{d}_{2 \sigma}^{\dagger} \hat{d}_{1 \sigma} ight)+U\left(\hat{n}_{1 \uparrow} \hat{n}_{1 \downarrow}+\hat{n}_{2 \uparrow} \hat{n}_{2 \downarrow} ight)\] This Hamiltonian belongs to a general class of Hubbard Hamiltonians defined on bipartite lattices, i.e., lattices that can be divided into two sets of sites \(A\) and \(B\) with hoppings only from sites of \(A\) to sites of \(B\) and vice versa, i.e. \[\hat{H}_{ bip }=\sum_{\sigma} \sum_{s \in A \atop s^{\prime} \in B}\left(h_{s s^{\prime}} \hat{d}_{s \sigma}^{\dagger} \hat{d}_{s^{\prime} \sigma}+h_{s^{\prime} s} \hat{d}_{s^{\prime} \sigma}^{\dagger} \hat{d}_{s \sigma} ight)+\sum_{s} U_{s} \hat{n}_{s \uparrow} \hat{n}_{s \downarrow}\] In the Hubbard dimer \(A\) is site 1 and \(B\) is site 2 and \(h_{12}=T .\) If the lattice is bipartite and if \(h_{s s^{\prime}}=h_{s^{\prime} s}\) and \(U_{s}=U\) is independent of \(s\), the Hubbard Hamiltonian enjoys an interesting particle-hole symmetry which can be used to simplify the calculation of eigenvalues and eigenkets. To conclude our analysis we must calculate the eigenkets and eigenvalues with three and four particles. This can be done using the particle-hole symmetry and the results are reported in Table \(2.1 .\) It is interesting to observe that when \(T ightarrow 0\) the eigenvalues in \(H _{2}\) become 0 (4 times degenerate) and \(U\) (two times degenerate). This is the dissociation limit which corresponds to pulling the two atomic sites infinitely far apart. The results agree with our physical intuition; if two isolated (Hubbard) atoms have one electron each (either with spin up or down) then the energy is zero whereas if both electrons are on the same atom then the energy is \(U\).

Heisenberg model

“这么多同学在科研上前赴后继，不禁让我想起姚先生说的一句话，现在是计算机科学的黄金时代，也是全人类的黄金时代，能够站在这样的黄金时代里，我感到无比的荣幸，我梦想能够成为黄金时代大潮中的一朵浪花，为人类智慧添砖加瓦。”

动机

学者与机构

高等理论计算

姚期智教授给清华大学新入学研究生开的一门课，课程内容：

  • 经典计算复杂性
    1. NP 完全性，
    2. 多项式空间复杂性，
    3. 对数空间复杂性，
    4. 交互式证明系统，
    5. 随机复杂性，
    6. 去随机化，
    7. 概率检验证明系统，
    8. 电路复杂性，
    9. 通信复杂性，
    10. 判定树复杂性等。
  • 在量子计算复杂性方面将包括：
    1. 量子计算模型，
    2. 量子电路，
    3. 量子 Fourier 变换算法，
    4. Shor 算法，
    5. Grover 量子搜索算法，
    6. 量子纠错码，

  • 参考教材

高等理论计算机科学

旨为介绍理论计算机科学的一些前沿的主题：

  1. 近似算法、
  2. 随机算法、
  3. 计算复杂性、
  4. 优化理论、
  5. 机器学习理论

并就大家感兴趣的问题进行深入的探讨；通过专题探讨，帮助学生确立今后研究的方向，明确研究的目标。

课程将快速回顾关于凸优化和机器学习的基础知识：

线性/逻辑回归，正则化，牛顿法，随机梯度下降（不同步，方差减少法），生成与歧视，方差与偏差。现有的机器学习和预测算法方面：k-nn，SVM，内核技巧，聚类，Adaboost，梯度提升，随机森林。在线学习和顺序预测方面：多臂老虎机问题，通用投资组合，乘法加权法，在线凸优化，基本时间序列。基于线性代数的学习算法方面：SVD，主成分分析（PCA），独立分量分析（ICA），非负矩阵分解（NMF），主题建模，矩阵完成，字典学习，张量法，谱聚类。

entry.content:
[TOC]

简介

目标

  • 画出能带
  • 实空间分布
  • 纠缠熵，纠缠谱
  • 拓扑数：陈数，缠绕数，charge

拓扑物态数值计算的一些库

  1. Python Tight Binding

一个二维系统的能带

\[h(\vec{k})=\sin k_{x} \sigma_{x}+\sin k_{y} \sigma_{y}+\left(m+\cos k_{x}+\cos k_{y}\right) \sigma_{z}\]

\[\begin{aligned}H &=\sum_{k_{x}, k_{y}}\left(c_{k_{x}, k_{y}, \uparrow}^{+} \quad c_{k_{x}, k_{y}, \downarrow}^{+}\right) h(\vec{k})\left(\begin{array}{c}c_{k_{x}, k_{y}, \uparrow} \\c_{k_{x}, k_{y}, \downarrow}\end{array}\right) \\&=\sum_{k_{x}, k_{y}}\left(c_{k_{x}, k_{y}, \uparrow}^{+} \quad c_{k_{x}, k_{y}, \downarrow}^{+}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}m+\cos k_{x}+\cos k_{y} & \sin k_{x}+i \sin k_{y} \\\sin k_{x}-i \sin k_{y} & -\left(m+\cos k_{x}+\cos k_{y}\right)\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}c_{k_{x}, k_{y}, \uparrow} \\c_{k_{x}, k_{y}, \downarrow}\end{array}\right)\\&=\sum_{x, k_{y}}\left(\begin{array}{cc}c_{x, k_{y}, \uparrow}^{+} & c_{x, k_{y}, \downarrow}^{+}\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}m+\cos k_{y} & i \sin k_{y} \\-i \sin k_{y} & -\left(m+\cos k_{y}\right)\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}c_{x, k_{y}, \uparrow} \\c_{x, k_{y}, \downarrow}\end{array}\right)\\&\quad +\left[\sum_{x, k_{y}}\left(c_{x, k_{y}, \uparrow}^{+} c_{x, k_{y}, \downarrow}^{+}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}\frac{1}{2} & \frac{1}{2 i} \\\frac{1}{2 i} & -\frac{1}{2}\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}c_{x+1, k_{y}, \uparrow} \\c_{x+1, k_{y}, \downarrow}\end{array}\right)+ H.C. \right]\\&=\left(\begin{array}{cccccc}M_{A} & M_{B} & 0 & 0 & 0 & \cdots \\M_{B}^{T} & M_{A} & M_{B} & 0 & 0 & \cdots \\0 & M_{B}^{T} & M_{A} & M_{B} & 0 & \cdots \\0 & 0 & M_{B}^{T} & M_{A} & M_{B} & \cdots \\0 & 0 & 0 & M_{B}^{T} & M_{A} & \cdots \\\vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \ddots\end{array}\right)\\& =\left(\begin{array}{ccc}M_{A}\left(x_{1}, k_{y 1}\right) & M_{B}\left(x_{1}, k_{y 1}\right) & 0 & \cdots \\M_{A}\left(x_{2}, k_{y 1}\right) & M_{B}\left(x_{2}, k_{y 1}\right) & \cdots \\M_{A}\left(x_{3}, k_{y 1}\right) & \cdots \\& & \ddots\end{array}\right) \bigoplus\left(\begin{array}{cccc}M_{A}\left(x_{1}, k_{y 2}\right) & M_{B}\left(x_{1}, k_{y 2}\right) & 0 & \cdots \\& M_{A}\left(x_{2}, k_{y 2}\right) & M_{B}\left(x_{2}, k_{y 2}\right) & \cdots \\& & M_{A}\left(x_{3}, k_{y 2}\right) & \cdots \\& & & & \ddots\end{array}\right)\\& \quad \bigoplus\left(\begin{array}{ccc}M_{A}\left(x_{1}, k_{y 3}\right) & M_{B}\left(x_{1}, k_{y 3}\right) & 0 & \cdots \\M_{A}\left(x_{2}, k_{y 3}\right) & M_{B}\left(x_{2}, k_{y 3}\right) & \cdots \\& M_{A}\left(x_{3}, k_{y 3}\right) & \cdots \\& & \ddots\end{array}\right) \bigoplus\left(\begin{array}{cccc}M_{A}\left(x_{1}, k_{y 4}\right) & M_{B}\left(x_{1}, k_{y 4}\right) & 0 & \cdots \\& M_{A}\left(x_{2}, k_{y 4}\right) & M_{B}\left(x_{2}, k_{y 4}\right) & \cdots \\& & M_{A}\left(x_{3}, k_{y 4}\right) & \cdots \\& & & & \ddots\end{array}\right)\\&\quad \oplus \cdots\end{aligned}\]

代码

clcm=-1.5;Nx=50;Ny=200;kxarray=2*pi/Nx*((-Nx/2-1/2):1:(Nx/2-1/2));kyarray=2*pi/Ny*((-Ny/2-1/2):1:(Ny/2-1/2));MB = zeros(2*Nx);for iky=1:length(kyarray)    ky=kyarray(iky);    A1 = m+cos(ky);    A2 = 1i*sin(ky);    A3 = -1i*sin(ky);    A4 = -(m+cos(ky));    A = [A1,A2;A3,A4];    for j = 1:Nx        MA((2*j-1):(2*j),(2*j-1):(2*j)) = A;    end        B1 = 1/2;    B2 = 1/(2*1i);    B3 = 1/(2*1i);    B4 = -1/2;    B = [B1,B2;B3,B4];        for j = 1:Nx-1        MB((2*j+1):(2*j+2),(2*j-1):(2*j)) = B;    end        H = MA+MB+MB';       [V,D] = eig(H);    F(:,iky) = diag(D);endfigureplot(kyarray,F,'k')

参考

  1. 二维格点系统

  2. 博士论文《一维的拓扑绝缘体SSH模型拓扑相和畴壁分数电荷的研究》杨昆仑，南京师范大学。

一维橫场XY模型的缠绕数

参考

  1. 一维橫场XY模型的缠绕数

结果

%一维橫场XY模型的缠绕数clearN=10000;karray=2*pi/(N)*(-(N/2-1/2):1:(N/2-1/2));ks=karray;dk=karray(2)-karray(1);harray=[0.0:0.1:1.0];gammaarray=[0:0.1:1.0];J=1;% 方法一（数值求和）ticfor ig=1:length(gammaarray)    gamma=gammaarray(ig);    for ih=1:length(harray)        h=harray(ih);         wn(ih,ig)=0;        for ik=1:length(karray)            k=karray(ik);            Bz=J*cos(k)+h;dBz=-J*sin(k);            By=J*gamma*sin(k);dBy=J*gamma*cos(k);            wn(ih,ig)=wn(ih,ig)+(dk*(Bz*dBy-By*dBz)/(By^2+Bz^2))/(2*pi);        end    endenddisp(['方法一（数值求和）用时：' num2str(round(toc*10)/10) 's.'])% 方法一（数值求和）clear wn By Bz dBy dBzticfor ig=1:length(gammaarray)    gamma=gammaarray(ig);    for ih=1:length(harray)        h=harray(ih);        Bz=J*cos(ks)+h;dBz=-J*sin(ks);        By=J*gamma*sin(ks);dBy=J*gamma*cos(ks);        wn(ih,ig)=sum(dk*(Bz.*dBy-By.*dBz)./(By.^2+Bz.^2))/(2*pi);    endenddisp(['方法二（矩阵求和）用时：' num2str(round(toc*10)/10) 's.'])% 方法三 clear wnticfor ig=1:length(gammaarray)    delta1=gammaarray(ig);    for ih=1:length(harray)        h=harray(ih);                ising=@(x)(((J*cos(x)+h).*(J*gamma*cos(x))-(J*gamma*sin(x)).*(-J*sin(x)))./((J*gamma*sin(x)).^2+(J*cos(x)+h).^2))/(2*pi);        wn(ih,ig)=integral(ising,-pi,pi);    endenddisp(['方法三（积分求和）用时：' num2str(round(toc*10)/10) 's.'])

态密度

参考：态密度

二维立方晶格模型的色散关系 \[\varepsilon_{k}=-2 t\left[\cos \left(k_{x}+\cos \left(k_{y}\right)\right]\right.\] 态密度定义为单位频率间隔内的状态数 \[g(\varepsilon)=\lim _{\Delta \varepsilon \rightarrow 0} \frac{\Delta n}{\Delta \varepsilon}=\frac{d n}{d \varepsilon}\]

Matlab

% DOS 态密度% tight binding parameterseps = 0;t = 1;% number of k values per dimensionlv = 5000;% number of bins for the DOSnbins = 101;% vector of k valuesk=linspace(-pi,pi,lv);[kx,ky] = meshgrid(k,k);% calculate the energyE = eps - 2 * t * (cos(kx)+cos(ky));% bin the energy to get the DOS,what it is in python???[DOS, Eval] = hist(E(:),nbins);% 归一化鸭！！！DOS = DOS/(Eval(2)-Eval(1))/lv.^2;% 这里把自旋也考虑进来，其实没多大影响。%DOS = DOS * 2;plot(Eval,DOS)

python

import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as np#parametersmu=0t=1kx=0ky=0delta=(2*np.pi)/1000res=[]for kx in np.linspace(-np.pi,np.pi,1001):    for ky in np.linspace(-np.pi,np.pi,1001):        E=mu-2*t*(np.cos(kx)+np.cos(ky))        res.append(E)        ky=ky+delta        kx=kx+deltaplt.title('DOS of 2d TB Model')plt.xlabel('E')plt.ylabel('DOS')#density=Ture for normalizationplt.hist(res,bins=1000,density=1)plt.show()

entry.title: 外尔半金属（Weyl semimetal）的拓扑数计算
entry.content:
[TOC]

本文计算了两个模型拓扑数相关的的陈数和贝里相位，并在附录给出数值计算陈数的代码。

计算陈数的步骤小结

  1. 写出动量空间的哈密顿量
  2. 泰勒展开到第一阶
  3. 将直角坐标转到球坐标(或者极坐标)
  4. 求本征态
  5. 对本征态微分，再内积得到贝里联络
  6. 对贝里联络积分得到，贝里相位
  7. 对贝里联络取旋量，得贝里曲率
  8. 对贝里曲率积分得到，陈数

一个简单模型的陈数计算

现在我们计算 \(H( k )= k \cdot \sigma\) 对应的陈数，

1哈密顿量

\[ egin{aligned}H( k )&=\pm k \cdot \sigma \&=\pm\left(k_{x} \sigma_{x}+k_{y} \sigma_{y}+k_{z} \sigma_{s} ight)\&=k_{x}\left( egin{array}{ll}0 & 1 \1 & 0\end{array} ight)+k_{y}\left( egin{array}{cc}0 & -i \i & 0\end{array} ight)+k_{z}\left( egin{array}{cc}1 & 0 \0 & -1\end{array} ight)\&=\left( egin{array}{cc}k_{s} & k_{x}-i k_{y} \k_{x}+i k_{y} & -k_{z}\end{array} ight)\end{aligned}\]

2将直角坐 标转到球面坐标

\(k_{x}=k \sin heta \cos \phi,\) \(k_{y}=k \sin heta \sin \phi,\) \(k_{z}=k \cos heta,\) 其中$ k=| k |$, 则 \[ egin{aligned}H( k )&=\left( egin{array}{cc}k \cos heta & k \sin heta \cos \phi-i k \sin heta \sin \phi \k \sin heta \cos \phi+i k \sin heta \sin \phi & -k \cos heta\end{array} ight)\&=\left( egin{array}{cc}k \cos heta & k \sin heta e^{-i \phi} \k \sin heta e^{i \phi} & -k \cos heta\end{array} ight)\end{aligned}\]

3 求本征态

哈密顿量对应的久期方程为 \[\left| egin{array}{cc}k \cos heta-E & k \sin heta e^{-i \phi} \k \sin heta e^{i \phi} & -k \cos heta-E\end{array} ight|=0\] 解久期方程得到系统的本征值为 \[E=\pm k\] 我们解本征值为 \(-k\) 对应的本征矢 \(\psi=\left( egin{array}{l}a \ b\end{array} ight),\) 哈密顿量为 \[\left( egin{array}{cc}k \cos heta & k \sin heta e^{-i \phi} \k \sin heta e^{i \phi} & -k \cos heta\end{array} ight)\left( egin{array}{l}a \b\end{array} ight)=-k\left( egin{array}{l}a \b\end{array} ight)\] 可以解得本征矢为 \[\psi=\left( egin{array}{c}-\sin rac{ heta}{2} e^{-i \phi} \\cos rac{ heta}{2}\end{array} ight)\]

4 贝里联络

梯度算符在球坐标中定义为 \[ abla_{ k }= rac{\partial}{\partial k} e _{k}+ rac{1}{k} rac{\partial}{\partial heta} e _{ heta}+ rac{1}{k \sin heta} rac{\partial}{\partial \phi} e _{\phi}\] 可以计算系统的贝里联络为 \[ egin{aligned}A( k )&=\left\langle\psi\left|i abla_{ k } ight| \psi ight angle\&=\left\langle\psi\left|i\left( rac{\partial}{\partial k}, rac{1}{k} rac{\partial}{\partial heta}, rac{1}{k \sin heta} rac{\partial}{\partial \phi} ight) ight| \psi ight angle\&=\left(A_{k}, A_{ heta}, A_{\phi} ight)\&=\left(0,0, rac{ an rac{ heta}{2}}{2 k} ight)\end{aligned}\]

5 贝里曲率

系统的贝里曲率为 \[ egin{aligned}&F( k )= abla_{ k } imes A( k )\&= rac{1}{k^{2} \sin heta}\left( egin{array}{ccc} e _{k} & q e _{ heta} & k \sin heta e _{\phi} \ rac{\partial}{\partial k} & rac{\partial}{\partial heta} & rac{\partial}{\partial \phi} \A_{k} & k A_{ heta} & k \sin heta A_{\phi}\end{array} ight)\&= rac{1}{k \sin heta}\left[ rac{\partial}{\partial heta}\left(\sin heta A_{\phi} ight)- rac{\partial}{\partial \phi} A_{ heta} ight] e _{k}+ rac{1}{k}\left[ rac{1}{\sin heta} rac{\partial}{\partial \phi} A_{k}- rac{\partial}{\partial k}\left(k A_{\phi} ight) ight] e _{ heta}+ rac{1}{k}\left[ rac{\partial}{\partial k}\left(k A_{ heta} ight)- rac{\partial}{\partial heta} A_{k} ight] e _{\phi}\&=\left( rac{ rac{ an rac{ heta}{2}}{2 k}}{k} \cot heta+ rac{1}{k} rac{\partial\left( rac{ an rac{ heta}{2}}{2 k} ight)}{\partial heta} ight) e _{k}-\left( rac{ an rac{ heta}{2}}{ rac{2 k}{k}}+ rac{\partial\left( rac{ an rac{ heta}{2}}{2 k} ight)}{\partial k} ight) e _{ heta}\&=\left( rac{ an rac{ heta}{2}}{2 k^{2}} \cot heta+ rac{1}{4 k^{2}}\left(\sec ^{2} rac{ heta}{2} ight) ight) e _{k}-\left( rac{ an rac{ heta}{2}}{2 k^{2}}- rac{ an rac{ heta}{2}}{2 k^{2}} ight) e _{ heta}\&= rac{1}{2 k^{2}} e _{k}\end{aligned}\] 小结 \[ egin{aligned}F( k )&= abla_{ k } imes A( k )\&=\left(F_{k}, F_{ heta}, F_{\phi} ight)\&=\left( rac{1}{2 k^{2}}, 0,0 ight)\end{aligned}\]

6 陈数

外尔点对应的陈数为 \[ egin{aligned}C&= rac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{S} F d S\&= rac{1}{2 \pi} k^{2} \int_{0}^{\pi} \sin heta d heta \int_{0}^{2 \pi} d \phi F_{k}\&= rac{1}{2 \pi} k^{2} \int_{0}^{\pi} \sin heta d heta \int_{0}^{2 \pi} d \phi\left( rac{1}{2 k^{2}} ight)\&=1\end{aligned}\] 同理，可以计算外尔点 \(H( k )=- k \cdot \sigma\) 对应的陈数为 \[C= rac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{S} F d S=-1\]

另一个模型的 陈数

1哈密顿量

\[H( k )=2 eta \sin k_{y} \sigma_{x}+2 \alpha \sin k_{\lambda} \sigma_{y}-2 t_{0}\left(\cos k_{x}+\cos k_{y} ight) \sigma_{z}\]

做一阶的泰勒展开 \[ egin{aligned}H\left(k_{x}, k_{y} ight)&=H\left(k_{x}^{0}+q_{x}, k_{y}^{0}+q_{y} ight)\&=2 q_{x}\left(\alpha \cos k_{x} \sigma_{y}+t_{0} \sin k_{x} \sigma_{z} ight)+2 q_{y}\left( eta \cos k_{y} \sigma_{x}+t_{0} \sin k_{y} \sigma_{z} ight)\end{aligned}\] 对于接触点 \(\left(k_{x}^{0}, k_{y}^{0} ight)=(0, \pi),\) 上式哈密顿量变为 \[H\left(q_{x}, q_{y} ight)=2 \alpha q_{x} \sigma_{y}-2 eta q_{y} \sigma_{x}\]

2极坐标

将其展开，并转化到平面极坐标下， \[ egin{aligned}H\left(q_{x}, q_{y} ight)&=2\left( egin{array}{cc}0 & eta q_{y}+i \alpha q_{x} \ eta q_{y}-i \alpha q_{x} & 0\end{array} ight) \&=2 q\left( egin{array}{cc}0 & eta \cos heta+i \alpha \sin heta \ eta \cos heta-i \alpha \sin heta & 0\end{array} ight)\end{aligned}\] 可以计算得到本征值为 \[E_{\pm}=\pm 2 q \sqrt{ eta^{2} \cos ^{2} heta+\alpha^{2} \sin ^{2} heta}\]

3本征态

对于本征值为负的，本征态设为 \(\psi=\left( egin{array}{l}a \ b\end{array} ight),\) 则 \[2 q\left( egin{array}{cc}0 & eta \cos heta+i \alpha \sin heta \ eta \cos heta-i \alpha \sin heta & 0\end{array} ight)\left( egin{array}{l}a \b\end{array} ight)=-2 q \sqrt{ eta^{2} \cos ^{2} heta+\alpha^{2} \sin ^{2} heta}\left( egin{array}{l}a \b\end{array} ight)\] 解得本征态 \[\left( egin{array}{l}a \b\end{array} ight)= rac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left( egin{array}{l}1 \ rac{- eta \cos heta+i \alpha \sin heta}{\sqrt{ eta^{2} \cos ^{2} heta+\alpha^{2} \sin ^{2} heta}}\end{array} ight)\]

4贝里联络

\[ egin{array}{c}\partial_{ heta}|\psi angle= rac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\partial_{ heta} rac{- eta \cos heta+i \alpha \sin heta}{\sqrt{ eta^{2} \cos ^{2} heta+\alpha^{2} \sin ^{2} heta}} ight) \\partial_{ heta} rac{- eta \cos heta+i \alpha \sin heta}{\sqrt{ eta^{2} \cos ^{2} heta+\alpha^{2} \sin ^{2} heta}}= rac{\alpha eta(i eta \cos heta+\alpha \sin heta)}{\left( eta^{2} \cos ^{2} heta+\alpha^{2} \sin ^{2} heta ight)^{3 / 2}} \i \partial_{ heta} rac{- eta \cos heta+i \alpha \sin heta}{\sqrt{ eta^{2} \cos ^{2} heta+\alpha^{2} \sin ^{2} heta}}= rac{\alpha eta(- eta \cos heta+i \alpha \sin heta)}{\left( eta^{2} \cos ^{2} heta+\alpha^{2} \sin ^{2} heta ight)^{3 / 2}}\end{array}\]

贝里联络 \[ egin{aligned}\left\langle\psi\left|i \partial_{ heta} ight| \psi ight angle &= rac{1}{2}\left(1 rac{- eta \cos heta-i \alpha \sin heta}{\sqrt{ eta^{2} \cos ^{2} heta+\alpha^{2} \sin ^{2} heta}} ight)\left( rac{\alpha eta(- eta \cos heta+i \alpha \sin heta)}{\left( eta^{2} \cos ^{2} heta+\alpha^{2} \sin ^{2} heta ight)^{3 / 2}} ight) \&= rac{1}{2} rac{\alpha eta}{ eta^{2} \cos ^{2} heta+\alpha^{2} \sin ^{2} heta}\end{aligned}\]

5贝里相位

贝里相位为 \[ egin{aligned}\gamma &=\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}\left\langle\psi\left|i \partial_{ heta} ight| \psi ight angle d heta \&= rac{1}{2} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} rac{\alpha eta}{ eta^{2} \cos ^{2} heta+\alpha^{2} \sin ^{2} heta} d heta \&= rac{1}{2} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} rac{-\alpha \sin heta d( eta \cos heta)+ eta \cos heta d(\alpha \sin heta)}{ eta^{2} \cos ^{2} heta+\alpha^{2} \sin ^{2} heta}\end{aligned}\] 换元 \(h_{x}= eta \cos heta, \quad h_{y}=\alpha \sin heta,\) 则上式可以写作 \[ rac{1}{2} \oint rac{h_{x} d h_{y}-h_{y} d h_{x}}{h_{x}^{2}+h_{y}^{2}}\] 这式就是 Winding Number 的定义, 由于不显含参量 \( heta\), 所以把积分上下限去掉，改写为环路积分，设 \[ rac{h_{ x }}{\sqrt{h_{ x }^{2}+h_{y}^{2}}} \equiv \cos \varphi \quad rac{h_{y}}{\sqrt{h_{ x }^{2}+h_{y}^{2}}} \equiv \sin \varphi\] 积分变为 \[ egin{aligned}\gamma &= rac{1}{2} \oint rac{h_{x} d h_{y}-h_{y} d h_{x}}{h_{x}^{2}+h_{y}^{2}}\&= rac{1}{2} \oint \cos \varphi d \sin \varphi-\sin \varphi d \cos \varphi\&= rac{1}{2} \oint d \varphi\end{aligned}\]

  • 当顺时针积分时，即可得到贝里相位 \(\gamma=\pi ;\)
  • 当逆时针积分时，即可得到贝里相位 \(\gamma=-\pi\) 。

同理，按上述计算方法可以计算得到接触点 \(\left(k_{x}^{0}, k_{y}^{0} ight)=(\pi, 0)\) 的贝里相位。

定义法

定义法在数值计算上可能会比较耗时，但在理解上比较直接和方便：

  • 先是计算贝里联络 (Berry connection) \(A_{\mu}(k)=\left\langle n(k)\left|\partial_{\mu} ight| n(k) ight angle\)
  • 然后再计算贝里曲率 (Berry curvature) \(F_{12}(k)=\partial_{1} A_{2}(k)-\partial_{2} A_{1}(k)\)
  • 积分得到陈数 (Chern number) \(c_{n}= rac{1}{2 \pi i } \int_{T^{2}} d ^{2} k F_{12}(k)\)

这里以文献 中的“量子反常霍尔模型”的哈密顿量为例子，用定义法在数值上计算陈数。代码如下：

import numpy as npimport matplotlib.pyplot as pltfrom math import *   # 引入pi, cos等import timedef hamiltonian(kx, ky):  # 量子反常霍尔QAH模型（该参数对应的陈数为2）    t1 = 1.0    t2 = 1.0    t3 = 0.5    m = -1.0    matrix = np.zeros((2, 2))*(1+0j)    matrix[0, 1] = 2*t1*cos(kx)-1j*2*t1*cos(ky)    matrix[1, 0] = 2*t1*cos(kx)+1j*2*t1*cos(ky)    matrix[0, 0] = m+2*t3*sin(kx)+2*t3*sin(ky)+2*t2*cos(kx+ky)    matrix[1, 1] = -(m+2*t3*sin(kx)+2*t3*sin(ky)+2*t2*cos(kx+ky))    return matrixdef main():    start_time = time.process_time()    n = 1000  # 积分密度    delta = 1e-9  # 求导的偏离量    chern_number = 0  # 陈数初始化    for kx in np.linspace(-pi, pi, n):        for ky in np.linspace(-pi, pi, n):            H = hamiltonian(kx, ky)            eigenvalue, eigenvector = np.linalg.eig(H)            vector = eigenvector[:, np.argsort(np.real(eigenvalue))[0]]  # 价带波函数            # print(np.argsort(np.real(eigenvalue))[0])  # 排序索引（从小到大）            # print(eigenvalue)  # 排序前的本征值            # print(np.sort(np.real(eigenvalue)))  # 排序后的本征值（从小到大）                       H_delta_kx = hamiltonian(kx+delta, ky)             eigenvalue, eigenvector = np.linalg.eig(H_delta_kx)            vector_delta_kx = eigenvector[:, np.argsort(np.real(eigenvalue))[0]]   # 略偏离kx的波函数            H_delta_ky = hamiltonian(kx, ky+delta)              eigenvalue, eigenvector = np.linalg.eig(H_delta_ky)            vector_delta_ky = eigenvector[:, np.argsort(np.real(eigenvalue))[0]]  # 略偏离ky的波函数            H_delta_kx_ky = hamiltonian(kx+delta, ky+delta)              eigenvalue, eigenvector = np.linalg.eig(H_delta_kx_ky)            vector_delta_kx_ky = eigenvector[:, np.argsort(np.real(eigenvalue))[0]]  # 略偏离kx和ky的波函数            # 价带的波函数的贝里联络(berry connection) # 求导后内积            A_x = np.dot(vector.transpose().conj(), (vector_delta_kx-vector)/delta)   # 贝里联络Ax（x分量）            A_y = np.dot(vector.transpose().conj(), (vector_delta_ky-vector)/delta)   # 贝里联络Ay（y分量）                        A_x_delta_ky = np.dot(vector_delta_ky.transpose().conj(), (vector_delta_kx_ky-vector_delta_ky)/delta)  # 略偏离ky的贝里联络Ax            A_y_delta_kx = np.dot(vector_delta_kx.transpose().conj(), (vector_delta_kx_ky-vector_delta_kx)/delta)  # 略偏离kx的贝里联络Ay            # 贝里曲率(berry curvature)            F = (A_y_delta_kx-A_y)/delta-(A_x_delta_ky-A_x)/delta            # 陈数(chern number)            chern_number = chern_number + F*(2*pi/n)**2    chern_number = chern_number/(2*pi*1j)    print('Chern number = ', chern_number)    end_time = time.process_time()    print('CPU执行时间(min)=', (end_time-start_time)/60)if __name__ == '__main__':    main()

Matlab代码为

波函数符号会出现波动，因此要增加以下三段代码（原因是波函数整体符号变号，仍然是哈密顿量的波函数，但在做波函数相减时会完全不同）：

if  sum((abs(Vkx-VV)))>0.01      Vkx=-Vkx;end        if  sum((abs(Vky-VV)))>0.01    Vky=-Vky; end        if  sum(abs(Vkxky-VV))>0.01    Vkxky=-Vkxky;end

有时加了以上这三段还不够，波函数会时有以下这种形式（例如），仍然是不连续：

这时候取负号是不能解决波函数的不连续问题，这里用取模来处理（原理上是要通过选取规范进行变换，得到波函数（1, 0），之后会提到）：

if abs(VV(1))<0.0001 ||abs(VV(2))<0.0001      VV=abs(VV);      Vkx=abs(Vkx);      Vky=abs(Vky);      Vkxky=abs(Vkxky); end

所以规范 (gauge) 的选取在定义法中就显得很重要了，需要选定一个规范，使得局域的波函数连续。

在数值上可以写代码去搜索找个近似的规范 （包括了前面提到的两种特殊情况） ，使得波函数连续，但在计算效率上又降低很多了

所以这里还是推荐使用高效法来计算

高效法

采用的是参考文献 中的方法

We first define a U(1) link variable from the wave functions of the \(n\) th band as \[U_{\mu}\left(k_{\ell} ight) \equiv\left\langle n\left(k_{\ell} ight) \mid n\left(k_{\ell}+\hat{\mu} ight) ight angle / N _{\mu}\left(k_{\ell} ight)\] where \(N _{\mu}\left(k_{\ell} ight) \equiv\left|\left\langle n\left(k_{\ell} ight) \mid n\left(k_{\ell}+\hat{\mu} ight) ight angle ight| .\) The link variables are well defined as long as \(N _{\mu}\left(k_{\ell} ight) eq 0,\) which can always be assumed to be the case (one can avoid a singularity \(N _{\mu}\left(k_{\ell} ight)=0\) by an infinitesimal shift of the lattice).
