\[\begin{aligned}\Delta_{i j} &=\frac{V}{2}\left(\left\langle c_{i \uparrow} c_{j \downarrow}\right\rangle-\left\langle c_{i \downarrow} c_{j \uparrow}\right\rangle\right) \\\Delta_{i j}^{*} &=\frac{V}{2}\left(\left\langle c_{j \downarrow}^{\dagger} c_{i \uparrow}^{\dagger}\right\rangle-\left\langle c_{j \uparrow}^{\dagger} c_{i \downarrow}^{\dagger}\right\rangle\right)\end{aligned}\]

  • the constant energy term

\[E_{\text {const}}=-U\left\langle n_{i \uparrow}\right\rangle\left\langle n_{i \downarrow}\right\rangle+\sum_{i j} \frac{\left|\Delta_{i j}\right|^{2}}{V}\]

commutation relations

We can obtain the commutation relations: \[\begin{aligned}\left[c_{i \uparrow}, H _{e f f}\right]_{-}&=\sum_{j \sigma^{\prime}} \tilde{h}_{i \uparrow j \sigma^{\prime}} c_{j \sigma^{\prime}}+\sum_{j} \Delta_{i j} c_{j \downarrow}^{\dagger} \\\left[c_{i \uparrow}^{\dagger}, H _{e f f}\right]_{-}&=-\sum_{j \sigma^{\prime}} \tilde{h}_{j \sigma^{\prime}, i \uparrow} c_{j \sigma^{\prime}}^{\dagger}-\sum_{j} \Delta_{i j}^{*} c_{j \downarrow} \\\left[c_{i \downarrow}, H _{e f f}\right]_{-}&=\sum_{j \sigma^{\prime}} \tilde{h}_{i \downarrow j \sigma^{\prime}} c_{j \sigma^{\prime}}-\sum_{j} \Delta_{j i} c_{j \uparrow}^{\dagger} \\\left[c_{i \downarrow}^{\dagger}, H _{e f f}\right]_{-}&=-\sum_{j \sigma^{\prime}} \tilde{h}_{j \sigma^{\prime}, i \downarrow} c_{j \sigma^{\prime}}^{\dagger}+\sum_{j} \Delta_{j i}^{*} c_{j \uparrow}\end{aligned}\]

quasiparticle operators

the electron field operator can be expressed as a linear combination of electron- and hole-like quasiparticle excitations, \[\begin{aligned}c_{i \sigma}=\sum_{n}^{\prime}\left(u_{i \sigma}^{n} \gamma_{n}-\sigma v_{i \sigma}^{n *} \gamma_{n}^{\dagger}\right)\\ c_{i \sigma}^{\dagger}=\sum_{n}^{\prime}\left(u_{i \sigma}^{n *} \gamma_{n}^{\dagger}-\sigma v_{i \sigma}^{n} \gamma_{n}\right)\end{aligned}\] where

  • \(\sigma=\pm 1\) denotes the up and down spin orientations.
  • The operators \(\gamma_{n}^{\dagger}\left(\gamma_{n}\right)\) create (annihilate) a Bogoliubov quasiparticle at state \(n .\)
  • The prime sign above the summation in the transformation means only those states with positive energy are counted.

The quasiparticle operators satisfy the anti-commutation relations: \[\begin{array}{l}\left\{\gamma_{n}, \gamma_{m}^{\dagger}\right\}=\delta_{n m} \\\left\{\gamma_{n}, \gamma_{m}\right\}=\left\{\gamma_{n}^{\dagger}, \gamma_{m}^{\dagger}\right\}=0\end{array}\] These relations also guarantee the anti-commutation relations among the original electronic field operators.

diagonalize

With the above canonical transformation, the Hamiltonian is diagonalized in the following form: \[H_{e f f}=\sum_{n} E_{n} \gamma_{n}^{\dagger} \gamma_{n}+E_{ const }^{\prime}\] where the index \(n\) also includes the pseudo-spin state index.

BdG equations

The quasiparticle operators satisfy the following commutation relations, \[\begin{array}{l}{\left[\gamma_{n}^{\dagger}, H_{e f f}\right]_{-}=-E_{n} \gamma_{n}^{\dagger}} \\{\left[\gamma_{n}, H_{e f f}\right]_{-}=E_{n} \gamma_{n}}\end{array}\] we compare the coefficients of the terms with \(\gamma_{n}\) and \(\gamma_{n}^{\dagger}\) and arrive at \[\begin{aligned}E_{n} u_{i \uparrow}^{n}&=\sum_{j \sigma^{\prime}} \tilde{h}_{i \uparrow, j \sigma^{\prime}} u_{j \sigma^{\prime}}+\sum_{j} \Delta_{i j} v_{j \downarrow}^{n}\\E_{n} u_{i \downarrow}^{n} &=\sum_{j \sigma^{\prime}} \tilde{h}_{i \downarrow j \sigma^{\prime}} u_{j \sigma^{\prime}}^{n}+\sum_{j} \Delta_{j i} v_{j \uparrow}^{n} \\E_{n} v_{i \uparrow}^{n} &=-\sum_{j \sigma^{\prime}} \sigma^{\prime} \tilde{h}_{i \uparrow, j \sigma^{\prime}}^{*} v_{j \sigma^{\prime}}^{n}+\sum_{j} \Delta_{i j}^{*} u_{j \downarrow}^{n} \\E_{n} v_{i \downarrow}^{n} &=\sum_{j \sigma^{\prime}} \sigma^{\prime} \tilde{h}_{i \downarrow, j \sigma^{\prime}}^{*}, v_{j \sigma^{\prime}}^{n}+\sum_{j} \Delta_{j i}^{*} u_{j \uparrow}^{n}\end{aligned}\]

matrix form

This set of BdG equations can be cast into a matrix form: \[\sum_{j} \hat{M}_{i j} \hat{\phi}_{j}=E_{n} \hat{\phi}_{i}\] where \[\hat{M}_{i j}=\left[\begin{array}{cccc}\tilde{h}_{i \uparrow j \uparrow} & \tilde{h}_{i \uparrow, j \downarrow} & 0 & \Delta_{i j} \\\tilde{h}_{i \downarrow, j \uparrow} & \tilde{h}_{i \downarrow, j \downarrow} & \Delta_{j i} & 0 \\0 & \Delta_{i j}^{*} & -\tilde{h}_{i \uparrow, j \uparrow}^{*} & \tilde{h}_{i \uparrow, j \downarrow}^{*} \\\Delta_{j i}^{*} & 0 & \tilde{h}_{i \downarrow j \uparrow}^{*} & -\tilde{h}_{i \downarrow, j \downarrow}^{*}\end{array}\right]\] and \[\hat{\phi}_{i}=\left(\begin{array}{c}u_{i \uparrow} \\u_{i \downarrow} \\v_{i \uparrow} \\v_{i \downarrow}\end{array}\right)\]

self-consistency conditions

This set of BdG equations is subjected to the self-consistency conditions: \[\begin{aligned}n_{i \uparrow} &=\sum_{n}^{\prime}\left[\left|u_{i \uparrow}^{n}\right|^{2} f\left(E_{n}\right)+\left|v_{i \uparrow}^{n}\right|^{2} f\left(-E_{n}\right)\right] \\n_{i \downarrow} &=\sum_{n}\left[\left|u_{i \downarrow}^{n}\right|^{2} f\left(E_{n}\right)+\left|v_{i \downarrow}^{n}\right|^{2} f\left(-E_{n}\right)\right]\end{aligned}\] and \[\Delta_{i j}=\frac{V}{4} \sum_{n}^{\prime}\left[\left(u_{i \uparrow}^{n} v_{j \downarrow}^{n *}+u_{j \downarrow}^{n} v_{i \uparrow}^{n *}\right)+\left(u_{i \downarrow}^{n} v_{j \uparrow}^{n *}+u_{j \uparrow}^{n} v_{i \downarrow}^{*}\right)\right] \tanh \left(\frac{E_{n}}{2 k_{B} T}\right)\] where

  • \(f(E)\) is the Fermi-Dirac distribution function

Symmetry

Theorem: If \(\left(u_{i \uparrow}^{n}, v_{i \downarrow}^{n}, u_{i \downarrow}^{n}, v_{i \uparrow}^{n}\right)\) is the solution to the BdG equations with eigenvalue \(E_{n},\) then \(\left(-v_{i \uparrow}^{n *}, u_{i \downarrow}^{n *}, v_{i \downarrow}^{n *},-u_{i \uparrow}^{n *}\right)\) is the solution to the same equations with eigenvalue \(-E_{n}\)

Using this symmetry property, rewrite the self-consistency conditions \[\begin{array}{l}n_{i \uparrow}=\sum_{n}\left|u_{i \uparrow}^{n}\right|^{2} f\left(E_{n}\right) \\n_{i \downarrow}=\sum_{n}\left|v_{i \downarrow}^{n}\right|^{2} f\left(-E_{n}\right)\end{array}\] and \[\Delta_{i j}=\frac{V}{4} \sum_{n}\left[u_{i \uparrow}^{n} v_{j \downarrow}^{n *}+u_{j \uparrow}^{n} v_{i \downarrow}^{*}\right] \tanh \left(\frac{E_{n}}{2 k_{B} T}\right)\]

Absence of SOC & spin-flip terms

In the absence of spin-orbit coupling and other spin-flip scattering terms, that is \(\tilde{h}_{i \uparrow, j \downarrow}=\tilde{h}_{i \downarrow, j \uparrow}=0,\) the BdG equations become block-diagonalized into two sets of equations: \[\left\{\begin{array}{l}E_{\tilde{n} 1} u_{i \uparrow}^{\tilde{n} 1}=\sum_{j} \tilde{h}_{i \uparrow, j \uparrow} u_{j \uparrow}^{\tilde{n} 1}+\sum_{j} \Delta_{i j} v_{j \downarrow}^{\tilde{n} 1} \\E_{\tilde{n} 1} v_{i \downarrow}^{\tilde{n} 1}=-\sum_{j} \tilde{h}_{i \downarrow, j \downarrow}^{*} v_{j \downarrow}^{\tilde{n} 1}+\sum_{j} \Delta_{j i}^{*} u_{j \uparrow}^{\tilde{n} 1}\end{array}\right.\] and \[\left\{\begin{array}{l}E_{\tilde{n} 2} u_{i \downarrow}^{\tilde{n} 2}=\sum_{j} \tilde{h}_{i \downarrow, j \downarrow} u_{j \downarrow}^{\tilde{n} 2}+\sum_{j} \Delta_{j i} v_{j \uparrow}^{\tilde{n} 2} \\E_{\tilde{n} 2} v_{i \uparrow}^{\tilde{n} 2}=-\sum_{j} \tilde{h}_{i \uparrow, j \uparrow}^{*} v_{j \uparrow}^{n}+\sum_{j} \Delta_{i j}^{*} u_{j \downarrow}^{n}\end{array}\right.\]

Canonical Transformation

This block-diagonalization structure leads to a distinct nature of the canonical transformation: \[\begin{aligned}c_{i \uparrow} &=\sum_{\tilde{n}}^{\prime}\left(u_{i \uparrow}^{\tilde{n} 1} \gamma_{\tilde{n} 1}-v_{i \uparrow}^{\tilde{n} 2 *} \gamma_{\tilde{n} 2}^{\dagger}\right) \\ c_{i \uparrow}^{\dagger}&=\sum_{\tilde{n}}^{\prime}\left(u_{i \uparrow}^{\tilde{n} 1 *} \gamma_{\tilde{n} 1}^{\dagger}-v_{i \uparrow}^{\tilde{n} 2} \gamma_{\tilde{n} 2}\right) \\c_{i \downarrow} &=\sum_{\tilde{n}}\left(u_{i \downarrow}^{\tilde{n} 2} \gamma_{\tilde{n} 2}+v_{i \downarrow}^{\tilde{n} 1 *} \gamma_{\tilde{n} 1}^{\dagger}\right) \\ c_{i \downarrow}^{\dagger}&=\sum_{\tilde{n}}\left(u_{i \downarrow}^{\tilde{n} 2 *} \gamma_{\tilde{n} 2}^{\dagger}+v_{i \downarrow}^{\tilde{n} 1} \gamma_{\tilde{n} 1}\right)\end{aligned}\]

reducing matrix

The block diagonalization and the symmetry property suggest that we merely need to solve one sets subject to the self-consistency condition: \[\begin{aligned}n_{i \uparrow} &=\sum_{\tilde{n}}\left|u_{i \uparrow}^{\tilde{n} 1}\right|^{2} f\left(E_{\tilde{n} 1}\right) \\n_{i \downarrow} &=\sum_{\tilde{n}}\left|v_{i \downarrow}^{\tilde{n} 1}\right|^{2} f\left(-E_{\tilde{n} 1}\right)\end{aligned}\] and \[\Delta_{i j}=\frac{V}{4} \sum_{\tilde{n}}\left[u_{i \uparrow}^{\tilde{n} 1} v_{j \downarrow}^{\tilde{n} 1 *}+u_{j \uparrow}^{\tilde{n} 1} v_{i \downarrow}^{\tilde{n} 1 *}\right] \tanh \left(\frac{E_{\tilde{n} 1}}{2 k_{B} T}\right)\] Therefore

by reducing the diagonalization of a \(4 N\) by \(4 N\) matrix down to that of a \(2 N\) by \(2 N\) matrix, the computational efficiency is improved significantly.

Here \(N\) would be \(N_{x} N_{y}\) for a two-dimensional lattice while \(N_{x} N_{y} N_{z}\) for a three-dimensional lattice with \(N_{x}, N_{y},\) and \(N_{z}\) being the linear dimension of the system. When it is obvious that no spin-flip effect occurs, the reduced set of BdG equations, Eq. ( 2.30 ), will be used with the hat symbol on the energy eigenvalue index and the set index dropped. It will be encountered frequently in the later discussions.

BdG equations for \(s\) -wave SC

It is straightforward for us to obtain the BdG equations for an \(s\) -wave superconductor in the lattice model. There we first replace \(U\) by \(-U(U>0)\) so that the Hamiltonian becomes \[H =\sum_{i j, \sigma \sigma^{\prime}} c_{i \sigma}^{\dagger}\left[h_{i \sigma, j \sigma^{\prime}}-\mu \delta_{i j} \delta_{\sigma \sigma^{\prime}}\right] c_{j \sigma^{\prime}}-U \sum_{i} n_{i \uparrow} n_{i \downarrow}\] which leads to the BdG equations: \[\begin{aligned}E_{n} u_{i \uparrow}^{n} &=\sum_{j \sigma^{\prime}} \tilde{h}_{i \uparrow j \sigma^{\prime}} u_{j \sigma^{\prime}}+\Delta_{i i} v_{i \downarrow}^{n} \\E_{n} u_{i \downarrow}^{n} &=\sum_{j \sigma^{\prime}} \tilde{h}_{i \downarrow j \sigma^{\prime}} u_{j \sigma^{\prime}}^{n}+\Delta_{i i} v_{i \uparrow}^{n} \\E_{n} v_{i \uparrow}^{n} &=-\sum_{j \sigma^{\prime}} \sigma^{\prime} \tilde{h}_{i \uparrow, j \sigma^{\prime}}^{*} v_{j \sigma^{\prime}}^{n}+\Delta_{i i}^{*} u_{j \downarrow}^{n} \\E_{n} v_{i \downarrow}^{n} &=\sum_{j \sigma^{\prime}} \sigma^{\prime} \tilde{h}_{i \downarrow, j \sigma^{\prime}}^{*} v_{j \sigma^{\prime}}^{n}+\Delta_{i i}^{*} u_{i \uparrow}^{n}\end{aligned}\] Here \[\tilde{h}_{i \sigma, j \sigma^{\prime}}=h_{i \sigma, j \sigma^{\prime}}-\mu \delta_{i j} \delta_{\sigma \sigma^{\prime}}\] and the self-consistency condition \[\Delta_{i i}=\frac{U}{2} \sum_{n}^{\prime}\left[u_{i \uparrow}^{n} v_{i \downarrow}^{n *}+u_{i \downarrow}^{n} v_{i \uparrow}^{n *}\right] \tanh \left(\frac{E_{n}}{2 k_{B} T}\right)\]

Absence terms

In the absence of spin-orbit coupling and spin-flip scattering, the BdG equations become \[\left\{\begin{array}{l}E_{\tilde{n} 1} u_{i \uparrow}^{\tilde{n} 1}=\sum_{j} \tilde{h}_{i \uparrow, j \uparrow} u_{j \uparrow}^{\tilde{n} 1}+\Delta_{i i} v_{i \downarrow}^{\tilde{n} 1} \\E_{\tilde{n} 1} v_{i \downarrow}^{\tilde{n} 1}=-\sum_{j} \tilde{h}_{i \downarrow, j \downarrow}^{*} v_{j \downarrow}^{\tilde{n} 1}+\Delta_{i i}^{*} u_{i \uparrow}^{\tilde{n} 1}\end{array}\right.\] and \[\left\{\begin{array}{l}E_{\tilde{n} 2} u_{i \downarrow}^{\tilde{n} 2}=\sum_{j} \tilde{h}_{i \downarrow, j \downarrow} u_{j \downarrow}^{\tilde{n} 2}+\Delta_{i i} v_{i \uparrow}^{\tilde{n} 2} \\E_{\tilde{n} 2} v_{i \uparrow}^{\tilde{n} 2}=-\sum_{j} \tilde{h}_{i \uparrow, j \uparrow}^{*} v_{j \uparrow}^{n}+\Delta_{i i}^{*} u_{i \downarrow}^{\tilde{n} 2}\end{array}\right.\] with \[\Delta_{i i}=\frac{U}{2} \sum_{\tilde{n}} u_{i \uparrow}^{\tilde{n} 1} v_{j \downarrow}^{\tilde{n} 1 *} \tanh \left(\frac{E_{\tilde{n} 1}}{2 k_{B} T}\right)\]

Physical quantities

The BdG solutions can describe

  1. single particle properties

  2. two-particle correlations

For example

  • local density of states is a direct measure of single particle properties
  • eigenfunctions can be used to study the two-particle correlations

In particular

  • the optical superconductivity reveals the information about the coherent peak
  • the superfluid stiffness and its temperature dependence set a criterion for superconductivity.

Both quantities are directly measurable in experiments. Theoretically, the formulae for these quantities, as derived from the BdG method, are also valid for inhomogeneous superconductors.

Local Density of States

From Eqs above \[\begin{array}{l}n_{i \uparrow}=\sum_{n}^{\prime}\left[\left|u_{i}^{n}\right|^{2} f\left(E_{n}\right)+\left|v_{i \uparrow}^{n}\right|^{2} f\left(-E_{n}\right)\right] \\n_{i \downarrow}=\sum_{n}^{\prime}\left[\left|u_{i \downarrow}^{n}\right|^{2} f\left(E_{n}\right)+\left|v_{i \downarrow}^{n}\right|^{2} f\left(-E_{n}\right)\right]\end{array}\] we extract the expression for the local density of states: \[\rho_{i \sigma}(E)=\sum_{n}^{\prime}\left[\left|u_{i \sigma}^{n}\right|^{2} \delta\left(E_{n}-E\right)+\left|v_{i \sigma}\right|^{2} \delta\left(E_{n}+E\right)\right]\] and the corresponding thermalized density of states \[\rho_{i \sigma}(E)=-\sum_{n}\left[\left|u_{i \sigma}^{n}\right|^{2} f^{\prime}\left(E_{n}-E\right)+\left|v_{i \sigma}\right|^{2} f^{\prime}\left(E_{n}+E\right)\right]\]

Bond Current

The bond current can be derived in the following way. The Heisenberg equation of motion for \(\left\langle n_{i}\right\rangle=\left\langle n_{i \uparrow}\right\rangle+\left\langle n_{i \downarrow}\right\rangle\) is: \[\begin{aligned}i \hbar \frac{\partial\left\langle n_{i}\right\rangle}{\partial t} &=\left\langle\left[n_{i}, H\right]_{-}\right\rangle \\&=\left\langle\left\{-\sum_{j \neq i, \sigma, \sigma^{\prime}}\left[-t\left(j \sigma^{\prime}, i \sigma\right) c_{j \sigma^{\prime}}^{\dagger} c_{i \sigma}+t\left(i \sigma, j \sigma^{\prime}\right) c_{i \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{j \sigma^{\prime}}\right]\right\}\right\rangle\end{aligned}\] The electrical current operator from site \(j\) to site \(i\) is then found to be: \[\hat{J}_{i j}=\frac{e}{i \hbar} \sum_{\sigma, \sigma^{\prime}}\left[t\left(i \sigma, j \sigma^{\prime}\right) c_{i \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{j \sigma^{\prime}}-t\left(j \sigma^{\prime}, i \sigma\right) c_{j \sigma^{\prime}}^{\dagger} c_{i \sigma}\right]\] and the average bond current is given by: \[J_{i j}=\frac{e}{i \hbar} \sum_{\sigma, \sigma^{\prime}} \sum_{n}^{\prime}\left\{t\left(i \sigma, j \sigma^{\prime}\right)\left[u_{i \sigma}^{n *} u_{j \sigma^{\prime}}^{n} f\left(E_{n}\right)+\sigma \sigma^{\prime} v_{i \sigma}^{n} v_{j \sigma^{\prime}}^{n *}\left(1-f\left(E_{n}\right)\right)\right]- c.c. \right\}\]

symmetry

Using the symmetry property of the BdG equations, we can also write the physical quantities in the following form: \[\begin{array}{c}n_{i \sigma}=\sum_{n}\left|u_{i \sigma}^{n}\right|^{2} f\left(E_{n}\right)=\sum_{n}\left|v_{i \sigma}^{n}\right|^{2}\left[1-f\left(E_{n}\right)\right] \\J_{i j}=\frac{e}{i \hbar} \sum_{\sigma, \sigma^{\prime}} \sum_{n}\left\{t\left(i \sigma, j \sigma^{\prime}\right) u_{i \sigma}^{n *} u_{j \sigma^{\prime}}^{n} f\left(E_{n}\right)- c.c. \right\} \\=\frac{e}{i \hbar} \sum_{\sigma, \sigma^{\prime}} \sum_{n}\left\{t\left(i \sigma, j \sigma^{\prime}\right) \sigma \sigma^{\prime} v_{i \sigma}^{n} v_{j \sigma^{\prime}}^{n *}\left(1-f\left(E_{n}\right)\right)- c.c. \right\}\end{array}\] and \[\rho_{i \sigma}(E)=-\sum_{n}\left|u_{i \sigma}^{n}\right|^{2} f^{\prime}\left(E_{n}-E\right)=-\sum_{n}\left|v_{i \sigma}^{n}\right|^{2} f^{\prime}\left(E_{n}+E\right)\] These new formulations are especially useful when we study the ferromagnetic impurity or Zeeman effect because the wavefunction of quasiparticles can be solved in a \(2 \times 2\) spin space.

two-particle correlations

we give the derivation of the superfluid density for the model with the Hamiltonian \[H =\sum_{i j, \sigma} c_{i \sigma}^{\dagger}\left[-t_{i j}-\left(\mu+\frac{U}{2}-U_{i}^{ imp }\right) \delta_{i j}\right] c_{j \sigma}+U \sum_{i} n_{i \uparrow} n_{i \downarrow}-\frac{V}{2} \sum_{i \neq j} n_{i} n_{j}\] Here the impurity potential is represented by \(U_{i}^{ imp }\) In the presence of an electric field pointing to the \(x\) -direction, \[E_{x}\left( r _{i}, t\right)=\Xi_{x} e^{i\left( q \cdot r _{i}-\omega t\right)}\] The current density along the \(x\) -direction is defined as \[J_{x}\left( r _{i}, t\right)=\sigma_{x x}\left( r _{i}, \omega\right) E_{x}\left( r _{i}, t\right)\] where \(\sigma_{x x}\left( r _{i}, \omega\right)\) is the local conductivity.

Gauge

In the Coulomb gauge, which dictates \(\nabla \cdot A =0\) and the scalar potential \(\phi=0,\) the electric field can be expressed in terms of a vector potential \[A_{x}\left( r _{i}, t\right)=-\frac{i}{\omega} E_{x}\left( r _{i}, t\right)\] Therefore, the total Hamiltonian becomes \[H_{ t }=-\sum_{i j, \sigma} \tilde{t}_{i j} c_{i \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{j \sigma}+\sum_{i \sigma}\left(U_{i}^{ imp }-\frac{U}{2}-\mu\right) c_{i \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{i \sigma}+U \sum_{i} n_{i \uparrow} n_{i \downarrow}-\frac{V}{2} \sum_{i j} n_{i} n_{j}\] where \[\tilde{t}_{i j}=t_{i j} e^{i \phi_{i j}(t)}\] with the gauge phase \(\phi_{i j}(t)=e A_{i j}=e A_{x}\left( r _{i}, t\right)\left(x_{i}-x_{j}\right) .\) Hereafter the charge \(e\) for electrons includes the sign. In the linear response limit, we expand this hopping term up to the second order of \(A_{x}\left( r _{i}, t\right)\) \[\tilde{t}_{i j} \approx t\left[1+i \phi_{i j}+\frac{1}{2 !}\left(i \phi_{i j}\right)^{2}\right]\] The total Hamiltonian can then be rewritten as: \[H_{ t }=H-i \sum_{i j, \sigma} \phi_{i j}(t) t_{i j} c_{i \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{j \sigma}+\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i j, \sigma} \phi_{i j}^{2}(t) t_{i j} c_{i \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{j \sigma}\]

hopping integral

If we limit the hopping integral only between the nearest neighbors, we have \[\begin{aligned}H_{ t }=& H-i e a \sum_{i, \sigma}\left[-A_{x}\left( r _{i}, t\right) t_{i, i+\hat{x}} c_{i \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{i+\hat{x}, \sigma}+A_{x}\left( r _{i+\hat{x}}, t\right) t_{i+\hat{x}, i} c_{i+\hat{x}, \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{i \sigma}\right] \\&+\frac{e^{2} a^{2}}{2} \sum_{i, \sigma}\left[A_{x}^{2}\left( r _{i}, t\right) t_{i, i+\hat{x}} c_{i \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{i+\hat{x}, \sigma}+A_{x}^{2}\left( r _{i+\hat{x}}, t\right) t_{i+\hat{x}, i} c_{i+\hat{x}, \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{i \sigma}\right]\\\approx & H-i e a \sum_{i, \sigma} A_{x}\left( r _{i}, t\right)\left[-t_{i, i+\hat{x}} c_{i \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{i+\hat{x}, \sigma}+t_{i+\hat{x}, i} c_{i+\hat{x}, \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{i \sigma}\right] \\&+\frac{e^{2} a^{2}}{2} \sum_{i, \sigma} A_{x}^{2}\left( r _{i}, t\right)\left[t_{i, i+\hat{x}} c_{i \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{i+\hat{x}, \sigma}+t_{i+\hat{x}, i} c_{i+\hat{x}, \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{i \sigma}\right] \\\approx & H-e a \sum_{i} A_{x}\left( r _{i}, t\right) J_{x}^{P}\left( r _{i}\right)-\frac{e^{2} a^{2}}{2} \sum_{i} A_{x}^{2}\left( r _{i}, t\right) K_{x}\left( r _{i}\right) \\=& H+H^{\prime}(t)\end{aligned}\] where the particle current and the local kinetic energy associated with the \(x\) -oriented links are defined as \[\begin{aligned}J_{x}^{P}\left( r _{i}\right) &=i \sum_{\sigma}\left[t_{i+\hat{x}, i} c_{i+\hat{x}, \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{i \sigma}-t_{i, i+\hat{x}} c_{i \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{i+\hat{x}, \sigma}\right] \\&=i t \sum_{\sigma}\left[c_{i+\hat{x}, \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{i \sigma}-c_{i \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{i+\hat{x}, \sigma}\right]\end{aligned}\] and \[\begin{aligned}K_{x}\left( r _{i}\right) &=-\sum_{\sigma}\left[t_{i, i+\hat{x}} c_{i \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{i+\hat{x}, \sigma}+t_{i+\hat{x}, i} c_{i+\hat{x}, \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{i \sigma}\right] \\&=-t \sum_{\sigma}\left[c_{i \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{i+\hat{x}, \sigma}+c_{i+\hat{x}, \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{i \sigma}\right]\end{aligned}\] The \(x\) -oriented current density operator is then found to be \[J_{x}^{Q}\left( r _{i}\right)=-\frac{\delta H^{\prime}(t)}{\delta A_{x}\left( r _{i}, t\right)}=e J_{x}^{P}\left( r _{i}\right)+e^{2} K_{x}\left( r _{i}\right) A_{x}\left( r _{i}, t\right)\] Here we have set the lattice constant \(a=1\).

Alternative derivation

An alternative derivation of the current density operator is to start with the electric polarization operator: \[P =e \sum_{i} r _{i} n_{i}\] with its \(x\) -component \[P_{x}=e \sum_{i} x_{i} n_{i}\] The time-derivative is \[\begin{aligned}J_{x}^{Q}\left( r _{i}\right) &=i\left[H_{t}, P_{x}\right] \\&=i e \sum_{i j, \sigma} x_{i}\left[\tilde{t}_{i j} c_{i \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{j \sigma}-\tilde{t}_{j i} c_{j \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{i \sigma}\right] \\&=i e \sum_{i j, \sigma}\left(x_{i}-x_{j}\right) \tilde{t}_{i j} c_{i \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{j \sigma} \\&=i e \sum_{i j, \sigma}\left(x_{i}-x_{j}\right) t_{i j}\left(1+i \phi_{i j}\right) c_{i \sigma}^{\dagger} c_{j \sigma} \\&=e J_{x}^{P}\left( r _{i}\right)+e^{2} K_{x}\left( r _{i}\right) A_{x}\left( r _{i}, t\right)\end{aligned}\]

expectation value

Now let us calculate the expectation value of the current density operator. In the linear response theory, the statistical operator in the interaction picture is given by: \[\hat{\rho}_{I}(t)=\hat{\rho}_{I}(-\infty)-\frac{i}{\hbar} \int_{-\infty}^{t}\left[H_{I}^{\prime}\left(t^{\prime}\right), \hat{\rho}_{I}(-\infty)\right]_{-} d t^{\prime}\] The expectation of a physical variable is found to be: \[\begin{aligned}\langle\hat{O}\rangle &=\operatorname{Tr}\left[\hat{\rho}_{I}(-\infty) \hat{O}_{I}\right]-\frac{i}{\hbar} \int_{-\infty}^{t} \operatorname{Tr}\left\{\hat{\rho}_{I}(-\infty)\left[\hat{O}_{I}(t), H_{I}^{\prime}\left(t^{\prime}\right)\right]_{-}\right\} d t^{\prime} \\&=\left\langle\hat{O}_{I}\right\rangle_{0}-\frac{i}{\hbar} \int_{-\infty}^{t}\left\langle\left[\hat{O}_{I}(t), H_{I}^{\prime}\left(t^{\prime}\right)\right]_{-}\right\rangle_{0} d t^{\prime}\end{aligned}\] where \[\hat{O}_{I}=e^{i H t} \hat{O} e^{-i H t}\] and \[H_{I}^{\prime}(t)=e^{i H t} H^{\prime}(t) e^{-i H t}\] with the term proportional to \(A^{2}(t)\) in \(H^{\prime}(t)\) neglected. The particle current density is then given by \[\left\langle J_{x}^{P}\left( r _{i}\right)\right\rangle=-i \int_{-\infty}^{t}\left\langle\left[J_{x}^{P}\left( r _{i}, t\right), H_{I}^{\prime}(t)\right]\right\rangle\] where the particle operator and the perturbation term in the Heisenberg picture with respect to the unperturbed Hamiltonian \(H\) are given by, respectively, \[J_{x}^{P}\left( r _{i}, t\right)=e^{i H t} J_{x}^{P}\left( r _{i}\right) e^{-i H t}\] We notice that the first term in \(H^{\prime}(t)\) can be rewritten as \[-e \sum_{i, \sigma} A_{x}\left( r _{i}, t\right) J_{x}^{P}\left( r _{i}\right)=\frac{i e}{\omega} J_{x}^{P}(- q ) \Xi_{x} e^{-i \omega t}\] where the Fourier transform of the particle density operator is given by \[J_{x}^{P}( q )=\sum_{i} e^{-i q \cdot r _{i}} J_{x}^{P}\left( r _{i}\right)\] We then obtain \[\left\langle J_{x}^{P}\left( r _{i}\right)\right\rangle=\frac{e}{\omega} E_{x}\left( r _{i}, t\right) e^{-i q \cdot r _{i}} \int_{-\infty}^{t} d t^{\prime} e^{i \omega\left(t-t^{\prime}\right)}\left\langle\left[J_{x}^{P}\left( r _{i}, t\right), J_{x}^{P}\left(- q , t^{\prime}\right)\right]\right\rangle\] Finally, the current density is found to be \[\begin{aligned}\left\langle J_{x}^{Q}\left( r _{i}\right)\right\rangle=& \frac{e^{2}}{\omega} E_{x}\left( r _{i}, t\right) e^{-i q \cdot r _{i}} \int_{-\infty}^{t} d t^{\prime} e^{i \omega\left(t-t^{\prime}\right)}\left\langle\left[J_{x}^{P}\left( r _{i}, t\right), J_{x}^{P}\left(- q , t^{\prime}\right)\right]\right\rangle \\&-\frac{i e^{2}}{\omega}\left\langle K_{X}\left( r _{i}\right)\right\rangle E_{x}\left( r _{i}, t\right)\end{aligned}\]

local conductivity

The local conductivity is then given by \[\begin{aligned}\sigma_{x x}\left( r _{i}, \omega\right)=& \frac{\left\langle J_{x}^{Q}\left( r _{i}\right)\right\rangle}{E_{x}\left( r _{i}, t\right)} \\=& \frac{e^{2}}{\omega} e^{-i q \cdot r _{i}} \int_{-\infty}^{t} d t^{\prime} e^{i \omega\left(t-t^{\prime}\right)}\left\langle\left[J_{x}^{P}\left( r _{i}, t\right), J_{x}^{P}\left(- q , t^{\prime}\right)\right]\right\rangle \\&-\frac{i e^{2}}{\omega}\left\langle K_{x}\left( r _{i}\right)\right\rangle\end{aligned}\] To eliminate the atomic fluctuations, we take an average over the spatial variable \(r _{i}\) and obtain the conductivity \[\sigma_{x x}( q , \omega)=\frac{e^{2}}{N \omega} \int_{-\infty}^{t} d t^{\prime} e^{i \omega\left(t-t^{\prime}\right)}\left\langle\left[J_{x}^{P}( q , t), J_{x}^{P}\left(- q , t^{\prime}\right)\right]\right\rangle-\frac{i e^{2}}{\omega}\left\langle K_{x}\right\rangle\] where \[\left\langle K_{x}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i}\left\langle K_{x}\left( r _{i}\right)\right\rangle\]

frequency-dependent

since the correlation function is only a function of the time difference \(t-t^{\prime},\) we can express the conductivity as \[\begin{aligned}\sigma_{x x}( q , \omega) &=\frac{e^{2}}{N \omega} \int_{0}^{\infty} d t e^{i \omega t}\left\langle\left[J_{x}^{P}( q , t), J_{x}^{P}(- q , 0)\right]\right\rangle-\frac{i e^{2}}{\omega}\left\langle K_{x}\right\rangle \\&=\frac{e^{2}}{i \omega}\left[\frac{i}{N} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} d t \theta(t) e^{i \omega t}\left\langle\left[J_{x}^{P}( q , t), J_{x}^{P}(- q , 0)\right]\right\rangle+\left\langle K_{x}\right\rangle\right] \\&=\frac{e^{2}}{i \omega}\left[-\Pi_{x x}( q , \omega)+\left\langle K_{x}\right\rangle\right]\end{aligned}\] where we define the retarded correlation function of the particle current operator as \[\Pi_{x x}( q , t)=-\frac{i}{N} \theta(t)\left\langle\left[J_{x}^{P}( q , t), J_{x}^{P}(- q , 0)\right]\right\rangle\] with its Fourier transform \[\Pi_{x x}( q , \omega)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} d t e^{i \omega t} \Pi_{x x}( q , t)\] The frequency-dependent, uniform electrical conductivity is given by taking the limit \(q \rightarrow 0\) \[\sigma_{x x}(\omega)=\frac{e^{2}}{i \omega}\left[-\Pi_{x x}( q =0, \omega)+\left\langle K_{x}\right\rangle\right]\] Be reminded that the order of these limits cannot be reversed.

transverse conductivity

Similarly the transverse conductivity can also be derived as: \[\sigma_{x y}( q , \omega)=\frac{e^{2}}{i \omega}\left[-\Pi_{x y}( q , \omega)\right]\]

Reference

《Bogoliubov-de Gennes Method and Its Applications》Jian-Xin Zhu

entry.title: BCS theory for Superconductor
entry.content:
[TOC]

1 Attractive interaction and Cooper pairs

Attractive interaction from Screening

Electrons repel each other with Coulomb potential: \[V\left(\left| r - r ^{\prime}\right|\right)=\frac{e^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon\left| r - r ^{\prime}\right|}\] In a metal we are dealing with quasiparticles (electron with surrounding exchange-correlated hole) \[V\left(\left| r - r ^{\prime}\right|\right)=\frac{e^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon\left| r - r ^{\prime}\right|} e^{-\left| r - r ^{\prime}\right| / r_{t f}}\] where \(r_{t f}\) Thomas-Fermi screening reduces substantially the repulsive force Electrons move in a solid in the field of positively charged ions. Due to vibrations the ion positions at \(R_{i}\) will be displaced by \(\delta R_{i} .\) Such a displacement means a creation of phonons (a set of quantum harmonic oscillators) Modulation of the charge density and the effective potential \(V_{1}(r)\) for the electrons \[\delta V_{1}(r)=\sum_{i} \frac{\partial V_{1}(r)}{\partial R_{i}} \delta R_{i}\] Effective interaction of electrons due to exchange of phonons \[V_{e f f}(q, \omega)=\left|g_{q \lambda}\right| \frac{1}{\omega^{2}-\omega_{q \lambda}^{2}}\] where \(g_{q \lambda}\) is a constant of electron-phonon interaction \(\left(g_{q \lambda} \approx \frac{m}{M}\right.\) is a small number \()\).and \(\omega_{q \lambda}\) is a phonon frequency

After averaging, \(\omega_{q \lambda}\) phonon frequency is replace by a typical Debye phonon frequency \(\omega_{D}\) \[V_{e f f}(\omega)=\left|g_{e f f}\right| \frac{1}{\omega^{2}-\omega_{D}^{2}}\] For \(\omega<\omega_{D}\) D and low temperatures \[V_{e f f}(\omega) \propto-\left|g_{e f f}\right|\] is Attraction interaction. This is called over screening, and is crucial to the formation of Cooper pairs

Cooper pair from Attractive interaction

For two electrons live deep inside a Fermi sphere, the over screening cannot take effect, since the two electrons have nowhere to go (state change) due to Pauli exclusion principle. Only electrons near the Fermi surface can attract each other.

Cooper showed that such an attraction leads to a bound state, no matter how weak the attraction is. Let paired state satisfies the Schrodinger equation \[\left[\frac{p_{1}^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{p_{2}^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{V_{0}} \sum_{k} V( k ) e^{i k \cdot\left( r _{1}- r _{2}\right)}\right] \Psi\left( r _{1}, r _{2}\right)=E \mid \Psi\left( r _{1}, r _{2}\right)\] Expand the paired state \(\Psi\left( r _{1}, r _{2}\right)=\sum_{k} g_{k} e^{i k \cdot\left( r _{1}- r _{2}\right)}\) substitute it to the Schrodinger equation \[2 \frac{\hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m} g_{k}+\frac{1}{V_{0}} \sum V\left( k - k ^{\prime}\right) g_{k^{\prime}}=E g_{k}\]

2 BCS Hamiltonian and Mean Field

BCS Hamiltonian

The most general form of Hamiltonian for interacting electrons is \[H=\sum_{m n} H_{m n} c_{n}^{\dagger} c_{m}+\frac{1}{2} \sum_{k l m n} V_{k l m n} c_{k}^{\dagger} c_{m}^{\dagger} c_{n} c_{l}\] Let's included the phonon effect in the effective interaction, the income electrons \(\left( k , k^{\prime}\right)\) exchange phonon q, outcome as \(\left( k - q , k^{\prime}+q\right)\). The Hamiltonian become \[H=\sum_{k} \xi_{k} c_{k}^{\dagger} c_{k}+\frac{1}{2 N} \sum_{k, k^{\prime}, q} V_{k, k^{\prime}}^{e f f} c_{k+q}^{\dagger} c_{k^{\prime}-q}^{\dagger} c_{k^{\prime}} c_{k}\] where \(\xi_{k}=\varepsilon_{k}-\mu\) and \(V_{k, k^{\prime}}=V_{0}\) if the magnitude of \(\xi_{k}=\varepsilon_{k}-\mu\) is smaller than a cutoff energy \(\hbar \omega_{D}\)

only the states near the fermi surface can be scattered.

For simplify, we consider \(q=0\) and only keep the singlet-pair terms,ignore triplet-pair terms and the rest of the terms \[H=\sum_{k} \xi_{k} c_{k}^{\dagger} c_{k}+\frac{1}{N} \sum_{k, k^{\prime}, q} V_{k, k^{\prime}} c_{k^{\prime}}^{\dagger} c_{-k^{\prime}}^{\dagger} c_{-k} c_{k}\] The second term describes the destruction of a Cooper pair two electrons with opposite momenta and spin, and the subsequent creation of another Cooper pair

Mean-Field of BCS Hamiltonian

We are going to mean-field decoupling of the quartic term \(c_{k^{\prime}}^{\dagger} c_{-k^{\prime}}^{\dagger} c_{-k} c_{k}\)

Mean-Field

First we define \[\begin{aligned}\delta^{\prime} &=\left\langle c_{k^{\prime}}^{\dagger} c_{-k^{\prime}}^{\dagger}\right\rangle \\\delta &=\left\langle c_{-k} c_{k}\right\rangle\end{aligned}\] Thus we have \[\begin{aligned}c_{k^{\prime}}^{\dagger} c_{-k^{\prime}}^{\dagger} &=\delta^{\prime}-\delta^{\prime}+c_{k^{\prime}}^{\dagger} c_{-k^{\prime}}^{\dagger}=\delta^{\prime}+\left(c_{k^{\prime}}^{\dagger} c_{-k^{\prime}}^{\dagger}-\delta^{\prime}\right) \\c_{-k} c_{k} &=\delta-\delta+c_{-k} c_{k}=\delta+\left(c_{-k} c_{k}-\delta\right)\end{aligned}\] Then, the quartic term express by \[\begin{aligned}c_{k^{\prime}}^{\dagger} c_{-k^{\prime}}^{\dagger} c_{-k} c_{k} &=\left[\delta^{\prime}+\left(c_{k^{\prime}}^{\dagger} c_{-k^{\prime}}^{\dagger}-\delta^{\prime}\right)\right]\left[\delta+\left(c_{-k} c_{k}-\delta\right)\right] \\&=\delta^{\prime} \delta+\delta\left(c_{k^{\prime}}^{\dagger} c_{-k^{\prime}}^{\dagger}-\delta^{\prime}\right)+\delta^{\prime}\left(c_{-k} c_{k}-\delta\right)+(\ldots) \\&=\delta^{\prime} \delta+\delta c_{k^{\prime}}^{\dagger} c_{-k^{\prime}}^{\dagger}+\delta^{\prime} c_{-k} c_{k}+(\ldots)\end{aligned}\] the small part \((\ldots)\) can be neglected

Mean-Field of BCS Hamiltonian

the mean value \(\left\langle c_{-k} c_{k}\right\rangle\) corresponds to one Cooper pair in the superconducting state. letIs introduce the superconductor gap function \[\begin{aligned}\Delta_{ k } &=-\frac{1}{N} \sum_{k^{\prime}} V_{k, k^{\prime}}\left\langle c_{-k} c_{k}\right\rangle \\\Delta_{ k }^{*} &=-\frac{1}{N} \sum_{k^{\prime}} V_{k, k^{\prime}}\left\langle c_{k^{\prime}}^{\dagger} c_{-k^{\prime}}^{\dagger}\right\rangle\end{aligned}\] first term of Mean-Field BCS Hamiltonian \[\begin{aligned}H_{M F} &=\sum_{k} \xi_{k} c_{k}^{\dagger} c_{k}-\sum_{-k} \xi_{k} c_{-k} c_{-k}^{\dagger}+\sum_{k}\left(\Delta_{ k }^{*} c_{-k} c_{k}+c_{k}^{\dagger} c_{-k}^{\dagger} \Delta_{ k }\right)+N \Delta_{ k } \Delta_{ k }^{\prime} \\&=\sum_{ k }\left(c_{ k }^{\dagger} \quad c_{- k }\right)\left[\begin{array}{cc}\xi_{k} & \Delta_{k} \\\Delta_{ k }^{*} & -\xi_{k}\end{array}\right]\left(\begin{array}{c}c_{k} \\c_{-k}^{\dagger}\end{array}\right)+\text {const}\end{aligned}\]

3 BCS Thoery

Hamiltonian diagonalize: Bogoliubov transformation

The purpose of solving the Bogoliubov-de Gennes equations is to find the unitary transformation which diagonalizes the Hamiltonian. introduce the unitary matrix, \[U=\left(\begin{array}{cc}u_{ k } & v_{ k }^{*} \\-v_{ k } & u_{ k }^{*}\end{array}\right)\] Assume it can diagonalize The Matrix \[U^{\dagger} H U=\left(\begin{array}{cc}u_{ k }^{*} & -v_{ k }^{*} \\v_{ k } & u_{ k }\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}\left(\varepsilon_{ k }-\mu\right) & \Delta \\\Delta^{*} & -\left(\varepsilon_{ k }-\mu\right)\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}u_{ k } & v_{ k }^{*} \\-v_{ k } & u_{ k }^{*}\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{cc}E_{ k } & 0 \\0 & -E_{ k }\end{array}\right)\] where eigenEnergy \[E_{ k }=\pm \sqrt{\left(\varepsilon_{ k }-\mu\right)^{2}+|\Delta|^{2}}\] Thus Hamiltonian can be diagonalised by a rotation of operators \[\left(\begin{array}{c}c_{ k \uparrow} \\c_{- k \downarrow}^{\dagger}\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{cc}u_{ k } & -v_{ k } \\v_{ k }^{*} & u_{ k }^{*}\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}\gamma_{ k \uparrow} \\\gamma_{- k \downarrow}^{\dagger}\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}u_{ k } \gamma_{ k \uparrow}-v_{ k } \gamma_{- k \downarrow}^{\dagger} \\-v_{ k }^{*} \gamma_{ k \uparrow}+u_{ k }^{*} \gamma_{- k \downarrow}^{\dagger}\end{array}\right)\] in this basis \[\begin{aligned}H_{k} &=\left(c_{ k \uparrow}^{\dagger}, c_{- k \downarrow}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}\xi_{ k } & -\Delta \\-\Delta^{*} & -\xi_{- k }\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}c_{ kT } \\c_{- k \downarrow}^{\dagger}\end{array}\right) \\&=\left(\begin{array}{cc}\gamma_{ k \uparrow}^{\dagger} & \gamma_{- k \downarrow}\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}E_{ k } & 0 \\0 & -E_{ k }\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}\gamma_{ k \uparrow} \\\gamma_{- k \downarrow}^{\dagger}\end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\] The result suggests that in the superconducting state the relevant excitation particles are superpositions of electrons and holes.The quasi-particles acted on by the \(\gamma\) -operators are bogolon. \[\begin{aligned}\gamma_{ k \uparrow}^{\dagger} &=c_{ k , \uparrow}^{\dagger} u_{ k }-c_{- k , \downarrow} v_{ k } \\\gamma_{- k \downarrow} &=c_{ k , \uparrow}^{\dagger} v_{ k }^{*}+c_{- k , \downarrow} u_{ k }^{*}\end{aligned}\] since Bogolon is linear combinations of the electronic operators, thus it obey the fermionic anticommutation rules. \[\left\{\gamma_{k \sigma}, \gamma_{k^{\prime} \sigma^{\prime}}^{\dagger}\right\}=\delta_{k k^{\prime}} \delta_{\sigma \sigma^{\prime}}\]

Calculation of \(u_{k}\) and \(v_{k}\)

rewritten in matrix form \[\begin{aligned}U^{\dagger} H U&=\left(\begin{array}{cc}u_{ k }^{*} & -v_{ k }^{*} \\v_{ k } & u_{ k }\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}\left(\varepsilon_{ k }-\mu\right) & \Delta \\\Delta^{*} & -\left(\varepsilon_{ k }-\mu\right)\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}u_{ k } & v_{ k }^{*} \\-v_{ k } & u_{ k }^{*}\end{array}\right)\\&=\left(\begin{array}{cc}E_{ k } & 0 \\0 & -E_{ k }\end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\] These eigenvalues are found in \[\operatorname{det}( H -\lambda I )=\left(\xi_{ k }-\lambda\right)\left(-\xi_{- k }-\lambda\right)-|\Delta|^{2}=0\] For a crystal symmetric under inversion \(\xi_{k}=\xi_{-k}\) and the equation reduces \[\lambda=\sqrt{\xi_{ k }^{2}+|\Delta|^{2}}\] explicitly \[\begin{aligned}&=\left(\begin{array}{cc}u_{ k }^{*} & -v_{ k }^{*} \\v_{ k } & u_{ k }\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}\left(\xi_{k}\right) & \Delta \\\Delta^{*} & -\left(\xi_{k}\right)\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}u_{ k } & v_{ k }^{*} \\-v_{ k } & u_{ k }^{*}\end{array}\right)\\&=\left(\begin{array}{cc}u_{ k }\left(u_{ k }^{*} \xi_{ k }+v_{ k }^{*} \Delta^{*}\right)+v_{ k }^{*}\left(u_{ k }^{*} \Delta-v_{ k } \xi_{- k }\right) & u_{ k }^{*}\left(u_{ k }^{*} \Delta-v_{ k } \xi_{- k }\right)-v_{ k }\left(u_{ k }^{*} \xi_{ k }+v_{ k } \Delta^{*}\right) \\u_{ k }\left(u_{ k } \Delta^{*}-v_{ k }^{*} \xi_{ k }\right)+v_{ k }^{*}\left(-v_{ k }^{*} \Delta-u_{ k } \xi_{- k }\right) & u_{ k }^{*}\left(-v_{ k }^{*} \Delta-u_{ k } \xi_{- k }\right)-v_{ k }\left(u_{ k } \Delta^{*}-v_{ k }^{*} \xi_{ k }\right)^{*}\end{array}\right\}\\&=\left(\begin{array}{cc}\xi_{ k }\left(u_{ k }^{2}-v_{ k }^{2}\right)+2 u_{ k } v_{ k } \Delta & \Delta\left(u_{ k }^{2}-v_{ k }^{2}\right)-2 u_{ k } v_{ k } \xi_{ k } \\\Delta\left(u_{ k }^{2}-v_{ k }^{2}\right)-2 u_{ k } v_{ k } \xi_{ k } & \xi_{ k }\left(v_{ k }^{2}-u_{ k }^{2}\right)-2 u_{ k } \Delta\end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\] For the last step,we let \(u_{k}, v_{k}, \Delta\) be real numbers for simplicity, and crystal symmetric \(\xi_{ k }=\xi_{- k }\) \[\left(\begin{array}{cc}E_{ k } & 0 \\0 & -E_{ k }\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{cc}\xi_{ k }\left(u_{ k }^{2}-v_{ k }^{2}\right)+2 u_{ k } v_{ k } \Delta & \Delta\left(u_{ k }^{2}-v_{ k }^{2}\right)-2 u_{ k } v_{ k } \xi_{ k } \\\Delta\left(u_{ k }^{2}-v_{ k }^{2}\right)-2 u_{ k } v_{ k } \xi_{ k } & \xi_{ k }\left(v_{ k }^{2}-u_{ k }^{2}\right)-2 u_{ k } v_{ k }\end{array}\right)\] Parameter comparison \[\begin{array}{r}E_{ k }=\xi_{ k }\left(u_{ k }^{2}-v_{ k }^{2}\right)+2 u_{ k } v_{ k } \Delta \\\qquad \begin{array}{r}E_{ k }=\lambda=\sqrt{\xi_{ k }^{2}+|\Delta|^{2}} \\u_{ k }^{2}+v_{ k }^{2}=1\end{array}\end{array}\] simultaneous equation, cancel \(\Delta\) \[E_{ k }=\xi_{ k }\left(2 u_{ k }^{2}-1\right)+2 u_{ k } \sqrt{1-u_{ k }^{2}} \sqrt{E_{ k }^{2}-\xi_{ k }^{2}}\]

\[E_{ k }=\xi_{ k }\left(1-2 v_{ k }^{2}\right)+2 v_{ k } \sqrt{1-v_{ k }^{2}} \sqrt{E_{ k }^{2}-\xi_{ k }^{2}}\]

deduce that, and we Reach the target \[\left|u_{ k }\right|^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(1+\frac{\xi_{ k }}{E_{ k }}\right), \quad\left|v_{ k }\right|^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(1-\frac{\xi_{ k }}{E_{ k }}\right)\]

Density of particles

The average density on a site i is given by the expectation value of the number operator \[\left\langle\hat{n}_{i}\right\rangle=\left\langle c_{i \uparrow}^{\dagger} c_{i \uparrow}\right\rangle+\left\langle c_{i \downarrow}^{\dagger} c_{i \downarrow}\right\rangle\] The electronic operators are linear combinations of the quasiparticles operators \[c_{i \sigma}=\sum_{n}\left[u_{n, i \sigma} \gamma_{n \sigma}+v_{n, i \sigma}^{*} \gamma_{n \bar{\sigma}}^{\dagger}\right]\] After plugging in the transformation \[\begin{aligned}\left\langle\hat{n}_{i}\right\rangle &=\sum_{n}\left\langle\left(u_{n, i \uparrow}^{*} \gamma_{n \uparrow}^{\dagger}-v_{n, i \uparrow} \gamma_{n \downarrow}\right)\left(u_{n, i \uparrow} \gamma_{n \uparrow}+v_{n, i \uparrow}^{*} \gamma_{n \downarrow}^{\dagger}\right)\right\rangle \\&+\sum_{n}\left\langle\left(u_{n, i \downarrow}^{*} \gamma_{n \downarrow}^{\dagger}+v_{n, i \downarrow \mid} \gamma_{n \uparrow}\right)\left(u_{n, i \downarrow} \gamma_{n \downarrow}+v_{n, i \downarrow}^{*} \gamma_{n \uparrow}^{\dagger}\right)\right\rangle \\&=\sum_{n}\left\langle\left|u_{n, i \uparrow}\right|^{2} \gamma_{n \uparrow}^{\dagger} \gamma_{n \uparrow}+\left|v_{n, i \uparrow}\right|^{2} \gamma_{n \downarrow} \gamma_{n \downarrow}^{\dagger}+u_{n, i \downarrow}^{*} v_{n, i \downarrow}^{*} \gamma_{n \uparrow}^{\dagger} \gamma_{n \downarrow}^{\dagger}+u_{n, i \uparrow v_{n, i \uparrow}} \gamma_{n \downarrow} \gamma_{n \uparrow}\right\rangle \\&+\sum_{n}\left\langle\left|u_{n, i \downarrow}\right|^{2} \gamma_{n \downarrow}^{\dagger} \gamma_{n \downarrow}+\left|v_{n, i \downarrow}\right|^{2} \gamma_{n \uparrow \gamma} \gamma_{n \uparrow}^{\dagger}+u_{n, i \downarrow}^{*} v_{n, i \downarrow}^{*} \gamma_{n \downarrow}^{\dagger} \gamma_{n \uparrow}^{\dagger}+u_{n, i \downarrow} v_{n, i \downarrow} \gamma_{n} \uparrow \gamma_{n \downarrow}\right\rangle\end{aligned}\] The quasiparticles are themselves linear combinations of the electronic operators, thus obey the fermionic anticommutation rules. \[\left\langle\gamma_{n \sigma}^{\dagger} \gamma_{n^{\prime} \sigma^{\prime}}\right\rangle=f\left(E_{n \sigma}\right) \delta_{n n^{\prime}} \delta_{\sigma \sigma^{\prime}} \text { and }\left\langle\gamma_{n \sigma} \gamma_{n^{\prime} \sigma^{\prime}}\right\rangle=0\] The average density \[\left\langle\hat{n}_{i}\right\rangle=\sum_{n}\left[\left|u_{n, i \uparrow}\right|^{2} f\left(E_{n \uparrow}\right)+\left|v_{n, i \uparrow}\right|^{2}\left(1-f\left(E_{n \downarrow}\right)\right)+\left|u_{n, i \downarrow}\right|^{2} f\left(E_{n \downarrow}\right)\left|v_{n, i \downarrow}\right|\left(1-f\left(E_{n \uparrow}\right)\right)\right]\] the correspondence between positive and negative eigenvalues \(1-f(E)=f(-E)\) \[\left\langle\hat{n}_{i}\right\rangle=\sum_{l}\left|u_{l, i \uparrow}\right|^{2} f\left(E_{l \uparrow}\right)+\left|v_{l, i \downarrow}\right|^{2}\left(1-f\left(E_{l \uparrow}\right)\right)\] in the case of no spin dependence reduces \[\left\langle\hat{n}_{i}\right\rangle=\sum_{l}\left[\left|u_{l, i}\right|^{2} f\left(E_{l}\right)+\left|v_{l, i}\right|^{2}\left(1-f\left(E_{l}\right)\right)\right]\]

4 Self-Consistent Equation

the gap function \[\Delta_{k}=-\sum_{k^{\prime}} V_{k k^{\prime}}\left\langle c_{-k^{\prime} \downarrow} c_{k^{\prime} \uparrow}\right\rangle\] the electron operators in terms of bogolon operators \[\begin{aligned}c_{k \uparrow} &=u_{k} \gamma_{k \uparrow}+v_{k} \gamma_{-k \downarrow}^{\dagger} \\c_{-k \downarrow} &=-v_{k} \gamma_{k \uparrow}^{\dagger}+u_{k} \gamma_{-k \downarrow}\end{aligned}\] The gap equation can be rewritten \[\begin{aligned}\Delta &=\sum_{ k } V\left\langle\left(u_{ k }^{*} \gamma_{- k \downarrow}-v_{ k } \gamma_{ k \uparrow}^{\dagger}\right)\left(u_{ k }^{*} \gamma_{ k \uparrow}+v_{ k } \gamma_{- k \downarrow}^{\dagger}\right)\right\rangle \\&=\sum_{ k } V\left(u_{ k }^{*} v_{ k }\left\langle\gamma_{- k \downarrow} \gamma_{- k \downarrow}^{\dagger}\right\rangle-v_{ k } u_{ k }^{*}\left\langle\gamma_{ k \uparrow}^{\dagger} \gamma_{ k \uparrow}\right\rangle\right)\end{aligned}\] Bogolons behave as free fermions, and they are distributed according to Fermi-Dirac statistics. \[\left\langle\gamma_{k \uparrow}^{\dagger} \gamma_{k \uparrow}\right\rangle=f\left(E_{k}\right)=\frac{1}{e^{E_{k} / k_{B} T}+1}\] and for term \[\left\langle\gamma_{k \uparrow}^{\dagger} \gamma_{-k \downarrow}^{\dagger}\right\rangle=\left\langle\Psi_{G}\left|\gamma_{k \uparrow}^{\dagger} \gamma_{-k \downarrow}^{\dagger}\right| \Psi_{G}\right\rangle=0\] Back to gap equation \[\begin{aligned}\Delta &=\sum_{ k } V\left[u_{ k }^{*} v_{ k }\left(1-f\left(E_{ k }\right)\right)-v_{ k } u_{ k }^{*} f\left(E_{ k }\right)\right] \\&=\sum_{ k } V u_{ k }^{*} v_{ k }\left[1-2 f\left(E_{ k }\right)\right]\end{aligned}\] The latter part of Equation \[1-2 f\left(E_{ k }\right)=1-\frac{2}{e^{E_{k} / k_{B} T}+1}=\frac{e^{E_{k} / k_{B} T}-1}{e^{E_{k} / k_{B} T}+1}=\tanh \frac{E_{k}}{2 k_{B} T}\] We Calculated \(u_{k}\) and \(v_{k},\) so \[\left(u_{ k }^{*} v_{ k }\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(1+\frac{\xi_{ k }}{E_{ k }}\right) \frac{1}{2}\left(1-\frac{\xi_{ k }}{E_{ k }}\right)=\frac{1}{4}\left(1-\frac{\xi_{ k }^{2}}{E_{ k }^{2}}\right)=\frac{1}{4} \frac{\Delta_{ k }^{2}}{E_{ k }^{2}}\] Reach the common form of gap equation \[\Delta_{ k }=-\frac{1}{N} \sum_{ k ^{\prime}} \frac{V_{ kk ^{\prime}} \Delta_{ k ^{\prime}}}{2 E_{ k ^{\prime}}} \tanh \left(\frac{E_{ k ^{\prime}}}{2 k_{B} T}\right)\]

entry.title: 机器学习在物理学中的应用
entry.content:
[TOC]

1 利用自编码器学习并表示量子态

1.1 自编码器

自编码器 (Autoencoder) 是一种用于数据降维的神经网络结构

一个自编码 器包含了

  • 编码器 (encoder)
  • 译码器 (decoder)

自编码的结构

  • 输入层和输出层
  • 前3层构成 编码器
  • 后3层构成 译码器
  • 中间的code layer的神经元称为潜变量 (latent variables)

应该保持 输出层和 输入层相等。我们可以定义潜变量的个数和输入维度的比值是压缩比 \[压缩比=\frac{潜变量个数}{输入维度}\] 当压缩比小于一时，自编码器将输人数据的维度做了降维。

1.2 变分自编码器

和传统的编码器相比，变分自编码器 (Variational autoencoder) 的最大不同之处是潜变量服从宽度是一的高斯分布。这个约束使得编码器能够产生高质量的编码。

作为生成器的译码器

假设有一个译码器

  • 它的任务是生成一张人能够识别的图片
  • 输入这个译码器的潜变量输入是独热码 (One hot)，比如输入 [1,0,0],[0,1,0],[0,0,1] 时这个译码器分别输出手马数字 0,1,2 。

这样我们就押有了一个手写数字图片的生成器。

然而由于独热编码，这个生成器只能最多生成三种图片类型，我们需要生成更多的图片类型，因此可以不使用独热码，而使用一个矢量作为潜变量，这个矢量里的每个数字都是随机实数。由于潜变量中的元素存在很多的组合，因此生成器可以生成很多类型的图片。

自编码器

当潜变量是随机数时，想要人为判别不同类型的输入是很困难的。因此我们使用一个编码器，这个编码器接受的输入是一张人可以识别的图片，输出的是元素是随机实数的潜变量。当我们把编码器和译码器一起使用时，就构成了一个标准的编码器。我们可以通过监督性学习，让编码器的输入和译码器的输出十分接近以至于人眼无法分辨出区别。这时我们就有了一个可以正常工作的自编码器。然而这个自编码器的功能是有限的，它不能生成新的图片，而只能输出和输入几乎一样的图片。

变分自编码器

对标准自编码器的潜变量做一些约束就可以使一个标准自编码器变成一个变分自编码器。这个约束就是潜变量里的随机实数服从宽度是一的高斯分布。为 了实现这个约束，我们在训练变分编码器时使用的损失函数包含两个部分： \[\text { Loss }=\text { generation loss }+\text { latent loss }\] 其中

  • generation loss 是 译 码 器生成 的图 像和 输入的图像之前 的差异
  • generation loss = MSE(generated image, real image), MSE 是均方误差
  • latent loss 是潜变量和宽度是一的高斯分布之间的 KL 散度，又称为相对熵，它反映了潜变量服从的分布和高斯随机分布之间的距离。

2 利用深度卷积神经网络求解薛定讲方程

3 机器学习区分物质的相

4 利用受限玻尔兹曼机求解量子多体系统的基态

参考文献

  1. 《机器学习在量子物理学中的应用》

entry.title: 路径积分与其他方法的联系
entry.content:
[TOC]

  • 路径积分&薛定谔方程
  • 路径积分&格林 (Green) 函数的关系
  • 路径积分&统计学配分函数

与薛定谔方程

费恩曼传播函数 \(K\left(x_{b}, t_{b} ; x_{a}, t_{a}\right)\) 为波函数 \(\psi(x, t)\) 满足的积分方程的核, 即 \[\psi(x, t)=\int d x_{a} K\left(x, t ; x_{a}, t_{a}\right) \psi\left(x_{a}, t_{a}\right)\] 而此积分核可用无穷维泛函积分表示为 \[K\left(x_{b}, t_{b} ; x_{a}, t_{a}\right)= N \int_{x_{a}}^{x_{b}} D x(t) \exp \left\{\frac{ i }{\hbar} S[x(t)]_{t_{a}}^{t_{b}}\right\}\] 为了证明这个式子与通常量子力学表达式等价

方法1

  1. 为此将 \(\psi(x, t+\epsilon)\) 按无穷小量 \(\epsilon\) 展开
  2. 将 \(K(x, t+\epsilon ; y, t)=\left(\frac{m}{2 \pi i \hbar \epsilon}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \exp \left\{\frac{ i \epsilon}{\hbar}\left[\frac{m}{2}\left(\frac{x-y}{\epsilon}\right)^{2}-V(y)\right]\right\}\left(1+O\left(\epsilon^{2}\right)\right)\) 代入上式，并改变积分变量 \(y \rightarrow x+\eta,\) 得

\[\begin{aligned}\psi(x, t+\epsilon)&=\int d y K(x, t+\epsilon ; y, t) \psi(y, t)\\=&\left(\frac{m}{2 \pi i \hbar \epsilon}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} d \eta \exp \left\{\frac{ i m}{2 \hbar \epsilon} \eta^{2}\right\}\left[1-\frac{ i }{\hbar} \epsilon V(x+\eta)\right] \\& \times \psi(x+\eta, t)\left(1+O\left(\epsilon^{2}\right)\right)\end{aligned}\]

  • 由于 \(\epsilon\) 很小, 所以如果 \(\eta\) 很大, 第一项中的指数因子快速振荡, 这些贡献相互抵消
  • 所以积分的主要贡献来自积分区: \(0 \leqslant|\eta| \leqslant\left(\frac{2 \pi \hbar \epsilon}{m}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} .\)
  • 于是将被积函数 \(\psi(x+\eta, t), V(x+\eta)\) 等按泰勒级数展开, 且保持到 \(\epsilon\) 阶.

利用积分公式 \[\begin{aligned}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} d \eta \exp \left\{\frac{ i m}{2 \hbar \epsilon} \eta^{2}\right\}&=\left(\frac{2 \pi i \hbar \epsilon}{m}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \\\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} d \eta \cdot \eta \exp \left\{\frac{ i m}{2 \hbar \epsilon} \eta^{2}\right\}&=0\\\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} d \eta \cdot \eta^{2} \exp \left\{\frac{ i m}{2 \hbar \epsilon} \eta^{2}\right\}&=\frac{ i \hbar \epsilon}{m}\left(\frac{2 \pi i \hbar \epsilon}{m}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}\end{aligned}\] 对展开式积分 \[\begin{aligned}\psi(x, t+\epsilon)=&\left(\frac{m}{2 \pi i \hbar \epsilon}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} d \eta \exp \left\{\frac{ i m}{2 \hbar \epsilon} \eta^{2}\right\}\left(1-\frac{ i \epsilon}{\hbar} V(x)+O\left(\epsilon^{2}\right)\right) \\& \times\left(\psi(x, t)+\eta \psi^{\prime}(x, t)+\frac{\eta^{2}}{2} \psi^{\prime \prime}(x, t)+O\left(\eta^{3}\right)\right) \\=& \psi(x, t)-\frac{ i \epsilon}{\hbar} V(x) \psi(x, t)+\frac{ i \hbar \epsilon}{2 m} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{2}} \psi(x, t)+O\left(\epsilon^{2}\right)\end{aligned}\] 整理 \[\begin{aligned}\lim _{\epsilon \rightarrow 0} \frac{\psi(x, t+\epsilon)-\psi(x, t)}{\epsilon}&=-\frac{ i }{\hbar}\left(V(x)-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{2}}\right) \psi(x, t)\\\frac{\partial}{\partial t} \psi(x, t)&=-\frac{ i }{\hbar}\left(V(x)-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{2}}\right) \psi(x, t)\end{aligned}\] 正是薛定谔方程 \[i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \psi(x, t)=\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{2}}+V(x)\right) \psi(x, t)\]

方法2

将费恩曼传播函数 \(K\left(x, t ; x_{0}, t_{0}\right)=\left\langle x\left| e ^{-\frac{i}{\hbar} \hat{H}\left(t-t_{0}\right)}\right| x_{0}\right\rangle\) 直接对时间求导数, 得 \[\begin{aligned}i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} K\left(x, t ; x_{0}, t_{0}\right) &=\left\langle x\left|\hat{H} e ^{-\frac{i}{\hbar} \hat{H}\left(t-t_{0}\right)}\right| x_{0}\right\rangle \\&=\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{2}}+V(x)\right) K\left(x, t ; x_{0}, t_{0}\right)\end{aligned}\] 即费恩曼传播函数满足薛定号方程 \[\left( i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t}-\hat{H}(x, p)\right) K\left(x, t ; x_{a}, t_{a}\right)=0\] 及边界条件 \[K\left(x_{b}, t ; x_{a}, t\right)={ }_{H}\left\langle x_{b}, t \mid x_{a}, t\right\rangle_{H}=\delta\left(x_{b}-x_{a}\right)\]

与格林函数

费恩曼传播函数与熟知的格林函数有着密切的联系. 因此,借助格林函数可以将路径积分理论应用到许多物理领域.

注意到费恩曼传播函数中时间参变量的单向性, \(t_{b}>t_{a},\) 可以引入格林函数 \[G\left(x_{b}, t_{b} ; x_{a}, t_{a}\right) \equiv K\left(x_{b}, t_{b} ; x_{a}, t_{a}\right) \Theta\left(t_{b}-t_{a}\right)\] 其中, 阶梯函数 \[\theta(t)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}0, & \text { 当 } t<0 \\1, & \text { 当 } t \geqslant 0\end{array}\right.\] 满足 \[\frac{ d }{ d t} \Theta(t)=\delta(t)\] 这样引入的格林函数满足非齐次薛定谔方程 \[\left( i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t}-\hat{H}\right) G\left(x_{b}, t ; x_{a}, 0\right)= i \hbar \delta\left(x_{b}-x_{a}\right) \delta(t)\] 因此格林函数是时间演化算子 \[\hat{U}(t)= e ^{-\frac{1}{\hbar} \hat{H} t} \Theta(t)\] 在薛定谔表象下的矩阵元 \[\begin{aligned}G\left(x_{b}, t_{b} ; x_{a}, t_{a}\right) &=\left\langle x_{b}\left|\hat{U}\left(t_{b}-t_{a}\right)\right| x_{a}\right\rangle \\&=K\left(x_{b}, t_{b} ; x_{a}, t_{a}\right) \Theta\left(t_{b}-t_{a}\right)\end{aligned}\] 对于保守力体系, 格林函数在能量表象中具有如下简单的形式: \[\begin{aligned}G\left(x_{b}, x_{a} ; t\right) &=\left\langle x_{b}|\hat{U}(t)| x_{a}\right\rangle=\sum_{n}\left\langle x_{b} \mid n\right\rangle\left\langle n\left| e ^{-\frac{1}{\hbar} \hat{H} t}\right| x_{a}\right\rangle \\&=\sum_{n} e ^{-\frac{i}{\hbar} E_{n} t} \psi_{n}\left(x_{b}\right) \psi_{n}^{*}\left(x_{a}\right)\end{aligned}\] 格林函数及费恩曼传播函数都包含了体系的全部动力学信息, 在量子场论、统 计物理等领域中具有广泛的应用.

迹核函数

费恩曼传播函数实际上也是波函数满足的积分方程的积分核, 因此也常被称为费恩曼核. 分析研究费恩曼核的迹 (称为迹核函数) 有着重要的意义.

对保守力体系, 哈密顿量不显含时间, 可对费恩曼核取迹, 得体系的迹核函数为 \[\begin{aligned}Z(T) &=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} d x K(x, T ; x, 0)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} d x \langle x |\exp \left\{-\frac{ i }{\hbar} \hat{H} T\right\} | x \rangle \\&=\operatorname{tr}\left( e ^{-\frac{i}{\hbar} \hat{H} T}\right)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \exp \left\{-\frac{ i }{\hbar} E_{n} T\right\}\end{aligned}\] 将\(K\left(x_{b}, t_{b} ; x_{a}, t_{a}\right)= N \int_{x_{a}}^{x_{b}} D x(t) \exp \left\{\frac{ i }{\hbar} S[x(t)]_{t_{a}}^{t_{b}}\right\}\)式代入 \[\begin{aligned}Z(T) &=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} d x N \int_{x_{a}}^{x_{b}} D ^{\prime} x(t)(t) \exp \left\{\frac{ i }{\hbar} S[x(t)]_{t_{a}}^{t_{b}}\right\} \\& \equiv \int_{x(T)=x(0)} D x(t) e ^{\frac{1}{\hbar}} \int_{0}^{T} d t\left(\frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}(t)^{2}-V(x(t))\right)\end{aligned}\] 其中

  • 迹核函数 \(Z(T)\) 为不含量纲的物理量
  • \(N\) 已经吸收到积分测度 \(D x(t)\) 中, 全部 \(N\) 维 \((N \rightarrow \infty)\) 空问积分都是取全空间积分

也可将上式式简记为 \[Z(T)=\int D x(t) \exp \left\{\frac{ i }{\hbar} S[x(t)]_{0}^{T}\right\}\] 这里迹核函数 \(Z(T)\) 体现了量子态的全部信息，是重点分析的对象. 由于迹核函数 \(Z(T)\) 在形式上很像统计物理配分函数 \(Z=\sum_{n} e ^{-\beta E_{n}},\) 故又称为量子配分函数.

虚时延拓

在路径积分的计算中, 常利用虚时延拓 (称为“欧几里得技术”) 得到有意义的 结果. 这是因为通常体系的能量本征值下有界上无界, 天此可将时间参量 \(t\) 解析延 拓到下半复平面. 做 Wick 转动, \[t \rightarrow- i \tau\] 即在复 \(t\) 平面转动积分回路使其变为欧几里得路径积分: \[Z(T)=\int_{x(T)=x(0)} D x(\tau) e ^{-\frac{1}{\hbar} \int_{0}^{T} d t \frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}(\tau)^{2}-V(x(\tau))}\] 通常还将保守力体系格林函数定义成费恩曼传播函数的傅里叶变换 (称为 \(z\) 空问格林函数 \()\) \[\begin{aligned}G \left(x_{b}, x_{a} ; z\right) &=\frac{1}{ i \hbar} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} d t e ^{\frac{ i }{\hbar} z t} K\left(x_{b}, x_{a} ; t\right) \Theta(t) \\&=\frac{1}{ i \hbar} \int_{0}^{\infty} d t \exp \left\{\frac{ i }{\hbar}(z+ i \epsilon) t\right\} K\left(x_{b}, x_{a} ; t\right) \quad\left(\epsilon \rightarrow 0^{+}\right) \\&=\sum_{n} \frac{\Psi_{n}\left(x_{b}\right) \Psi_{n}^{*}\left(x_{a}\right)}{z-E_{n}+ i \epsilon} \quad\left(\epsilon \rightarrow 0^{+}\right)\end{aligned}\] 其中

  • 附加 \(\epsilon \rightarrow 0^{+}\) 是引入的收敛因子, 在计算结束后再取 \(\epsilon \rightarrow 0^{+} .\)
  • 由于 \(\hat{H}\) 的本征 值为实数, \(z\) 空间格林函数在复 \(z\) 平面上除实轴外都解析. 就上式而言, 其极 点为束缚态本征值, 而奇点留数决定束缚态波函数
  • 如果 \(\hat{H}\) 的本征值存在连续谱, 上式中求和号应代以沿 \(E\) 轴积分, 则 \(z\) 空间格林函数有一条割线.

统计配分函数的路径积分表述

统计物理主要研究处于热平衡态的物理体系. 按照正则系综玻尔兹曼分布, 在一定温度 \(T\) 下, 体系处于能级为 \(E\) 的状态的概率正比于 \(\exp \left\{-\frac{E}{k T}\right\},\) 这里 \(k\) 是玻 尔兹曼常量 \(\left(k=1.38047 \times 10^{-16} erg /{ }^{\circ} C \right) .\)

配分函数

决定物理体系热平衡性质的重要函数是配分函数 (partition function) \[\begin{aligned}Z &=\sum_{n} e ^{-\frac{E_{n}}{k T}}\\&=\sum_{n} e ^{-\beta E_{n}} \\&= e ^{-\beta F} \end{aligned}\] 其中, \(F\) 称为体系的自由能, 满足 \[F=-k T \ln Z\] 体系处于能级 \(E_{n}\) 的相对概率为 \[p_{n}=\frac{ e ^{-\beta E_{n}}}{Z}= e ^{-\beta\left(E_{n}-F\right)}\] 用 \(\hat{A}\) 代表体系某物理性质的力学量算符, 它在态 \(\psi_{n}\) 的平均值 (期待值) 为 \[A_{n}=\int \psi_{n}^{*} \hat{A} \psi_{n} d V\] 因此, 整个体系的统计平均值为 \[\begin{aligned}\bar{A} &=\sum_{n} p_{n} A_{n}\\&=\frac{1}{Z} \sum_{n} A_{n} e ^{-\beta E_{n}} \\&=\frac{1}{Z} \sum_{n} \int \psi_{n}^{*}(x) \hat{A} \psi_{n}(x) e ^{-\beta E_{n}} d x\end{aligned}\] 体系热平衡态的确定有时要求要有比配分函数更多信息. 例如, 对于位形空间 的体系, 找到体系在 \(x\) 处的概率为 \[p(x)=\frac{1}{Z} \psi_{n}^{*}(x) \psi_{n}(x) e ^{-\beta E_{n}}\] 其中, \(\psi_{n}^{*}(x) \psi_{n}(x)=\left|\psi_{n}(x)\right|^{2}\) 为粒子处于 \(\psi_{n}(x)\) 纯态时找到 \(x\) 的概率, 而 \(p(x)\) 为 对所有可能态的平均概率. 引入密度矩阵 (density matrix) \[\begin{aligned}\rho\left(x^{\prime}, x\right)&=\sum_{n} \psi_{n}\left(x^{\prime}\right) \psi_{n}^{*}(x) e ^{-\beta E_{n}}\\&= \langle x^{\prime} | e ^{-\beta \hat{H}} | x \rangle\end{aligned}\]

Wick 转动

费恩曼传播函数在能量表象的一般表达式为 \[\begin{aligned}K\left(x_{b}, t ; x_{a}, 0\right)&= \langle x_{b} | e ^{-\frac{i}{\hbar} \hat{H} t} | x_{a} \rangle\\&=\sum_{n} e ^{-\frac{i}{\hbar} E_{n} t} \psi_{n}\left(x_{b}\right) \psi_{n}^{*}\left(x_{a}\right)\end{aligned}\] 将 \(\left\langle x^{\prime}\left|e^{-\beta \hat{H}}\right| x\right\rangle\) 与\(\left\langle x_{b}\left|e^{-\frac{i}{\hbar} \hat{H} t}\right| x_{a}\right\rangle\) 式比较, 相当于对时间作 Wick 转动 (Wick rotation) \[t \rightarrow- i \beta\] 因此, 对于统计物理中的密度矩阵, 可以类似于费恩曼传播函数作路径积分演算, 下 面我们给出统计配分函数的路径积分形式. 当体系处在热平衡态, 温度 \(T\) 固定, \(\beta=\frac{1}{k T}\) 为固定参量, 引入小参量 \(\delta=\frac{\beta}{N},\) 则密度矩阵 \[\begin{aligned}\rho\left(x^{\prime}, x\right)=&\left\langle x^{\prime}\left| e ^{-\beta \hat{H}}\right| x\right\rangle \quad(\beta=N \delta) \\=& \lim _{N \rightarrow \infty, \delta \rightarrow 0} \int \prod_{j=1}^{N-1} d x_{j}\left\langle x^{\prime}\left| e ^{-\delta \hat{H}}\right| x_{N-1}\right\rangle \\& \times\left\langle x_{N-1}\left| e ^{-\delta \hat{H}}\right| x_{N-2}\right\rangle \cdots\left\langle x_{1}\left| e ^{-\delta \hat{H}}\right| x\right\rangle \\=& \lim _{N \rightarrow \infty, \delta \rightarrow 0} \int \prod_{j=1}^{N-1} d x_{j} \prod_{j=0}^{N-1} \frac{ d p_{j}}{2 \pi \hbar} \\& \times \exp \left\{\delta \sum_{j=0}^{N-1}\left[\frac{ i }{\delta \hbar} p_{j}\left(x_{j+1}-x_{j}\right)-H\left(p_{j}, x_{j}\right)\right]\right\}\\=&\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty, \delta \rightarrow 0} \int \prod_{j=1}^{N-1} d x_{j} \prod_{j=0}^{N-1} \frac{ d p_{j}}{2 \pi \hbar} \exp \left\{-\frac{\Delta \tau}{\hbar} \sum_{j=0}^{N-1}\left[H\left(p\left(\tau_{j}\right), x\left(\tau_{j}\right)\right)-\frac{ i }{\hbar} p\left(\tau_{j}\right) \dot{x}\left(\tau_{j}\right)\right]\right\}\\=&\int_{x(0)=x}^{x(\beta)=x^{\prime}} D ^{\prime} x \int \frac{ D p}{2 \pi \hbar} \exp \left\{-\int_{0}^{\beta} d \tau[H(p, x)- i p \dot{x}]\right\}\\=& \lim _{N \rightarrow \infty, \Delta \tau \rightarrow 0}\left(\frac{m}{2 \pi \hbar \Delta \tau}\right)^{\frac{N}{2}} \int \prod_{j=1}^{N-1} d x_{j} \\& \times \exp \left\{-\Delta \tau \sum_{j=0}^{N-1}\left[\frac{m}{2}\left(\frac{x_{j+1}-x_{j}}{\Delta \tau}\right)^{2}+V\left(x_{j}\right)\right]\right\} \\=& N \int_{x}^{x^{\prime}} D ^{\prime} x(\tau) \exp \left\{-\int d \tau\left(\frac{m \dot{x}^{2}}{2}+V(x)\right)\right\}\end{aligned}\] 其中我们用到了

  1. “短时”传播函数

\[\begin{aligned}&\left\langle x_{j+1}\left| e ^{-\delta \hat{H}}\right| x_{j}\right\rangle \\=&\left\langle x_{j+1}\left| e ^{-\delta\left(\frac{\hat{P}^{2}}{2 m}+\hat{V}(x)\right)}\right| x_{j}\right\rangle \\=& \int d p\left\langle x_{j+1}\left| e ^{-\delta \frac{\hat{P}^{2}}{2 m}}\right| p\right\rangle\left\langle p\left| e ^{-\delta \hat{V}(x)}\right| x_{j}\right\rangle\left(1+O\left(\delta^{2}\right)\right)\\=&\frac{1}{2 \pi \hbar} \int d p \exp \left\{-\delta \frac{p^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{ i }{\hbar} p\left(x_{j+1}-x_{j}\right)\right\} e ^{-\delta V\left(x_{j}\right)}\left(1+O\left(\delta^{2}\right)\right) \\=&\frac{1}{2 \pi \hbar}\left(\frac{2 m \pi}{\delta}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \exp \left\{-\delta\left[\frac{m}{2 \hbar^{2} \delta^{2}}\left(x_{j+1}-x_{j}\right)^{2}+V\left(x_{j}\right)\right]\right\}\left(1+O\left(\delta^{2}\right)\right)\end{aligned}\]

  1. 时间延拓成虚时间, 从而使物理的闵氏空间延拓为实欧空间.

于是, 统计配分函数可写为路径积分形式 \[\begin{aligned}Z(\beta) &=\operatorname{tr}(\exp \{-\beta \hat{H}\})=\int d x\langle x|\exp \{-\beta \hat{H}\}| x\rangle \\&=\int d x \int_{x(0)=x}^{x(\beta)=x} D ^{\prime} x \int \frac{ D p}{2 \pi \hbar} \exp \left\{-\int_{0}^{\beta} d \tau[H(p, x)- i p \dot{x}]\right\} \\&=\int_{x(0)=x(\beta)} D x(\tau) \exp \left\{-\int_{0}^{\beta} d \tau\left[\frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}^{2}(\tau)+V(x(\tau))\right]\right\}\end{aligned}\]

entry.title: 基于对称性的物理(1/2)Lie群
entry.content:
二维旋转

同一个群（对应一种变换）可以作用于不同类对象：圆（几何图形），或者向量。

矩阵表示变换

本节考虑向量，可以用旋转矩阵表示向量的旋转或反射

  • 旋转

将起点位于原点的向量绕原点逆时针旋转 \(\theta\) 角度的旋转矩阵为 \[R_{\theta}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}\cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\\sin \theta & \cos \theta\end{array}\right)\]

  • 反射

关于 x 轴与 y 轴的反射变换用矩阵表示为: \[P_{x}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}-1 & 0 \\0 & 1\end{array}\right) \quad P_{y}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}1 & 0 \\0 & -1\end{array}\right)\] 将矩阵乘法作为群乘法 o, 可以验证对于所有的 \(\theta\)，\(R(\theta)\)，\(P_{x}\)，\(P_{y}\) 与 矩阵乘法符合群公理，因而构成一个群，亦即旋转与反射变换构成一个群。

长度不变的变换

可以用更抽象的方式表达“所有让二维向量长度不变的变换，向量长度就是向量与自身点乘的平方根 \((|a|=\sqrt{a \cdot a}) .\) 向量长度在变换 \(a \rightarrow a^{\prime}\) 下不变意味着 : \[a^{\prime} \cdot a^{\prime} \stackrel{!}{=} a \cdot a\] 将线性变换对应的矩阵记作 \(O\)，变换即为 \(a \rightarrow a^{\prime}= O a\) \[a \cdot a=a^{T} a \\\downarrow\\ a^{\prime T} a^{\prime}=( O a)^{T} O a=a^{T} O ^{T} O a \stackrel{!}{=} a^{T} a=a \cdot a\] 由此可见，使向量长度不变的变换必须满足 \[O ^{T} O =I\] 其中 \(I\) 表示单位矩阵。前文的旋转和反射矩阵都满足此条 件

例子

对于旋转矩阵 \(O= R_{\theta}\) \[\begin{aligned}R_{\theta}^{T} R_{\theta}=& \left(\begin{array}{cc}\cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\\sin \theta & \cos \theta\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}\cos \theta & \sin \theta \\-\sin \theta & \cos \theta\end{array}\right)\\=&\left(\begin{array}{cc}\cos ^{2} \theta+\sin ^{2} \theta & 0 \\0 & \sin ^{2} \theta+\cos ^{2} \theta\end{array}\right)\\=& \left(\begin{array}{ll}1 & 0 \\0 & 1\end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\]

\(O (2)\) 群(正交群)

\(2 \times 2\) 矩阵中所有满足 \(O^{T} O=I\) 式的矩阵构成了 \(O (2)\) 群，即所有 \(2 \times 2\) 正交矩阵构成的群。

特殊正交群 \(S O (2)\)

我们可以找出这个群中描述旋转变换的那一部分（构成一个子群）。根据 \[\begin{aligned}\operatorname{det}\left( O ^{T} O\right)=& \operatorname{det}\left(O^{T}\right) \operatorname{det}(O) \stackrel{!}{=} \operatorname{det}(I)=1 \\&(\operatorname{det}( O ))^{2} \stackrel{!}{=} 1 \rightarrow \operatorname{det}( O ) \stackrel{!}{=} \pm 1\end{aligned}\] \(\operatorname{det} O =1\) 的矩阵对应旋转变换。

条件 \[O ^{T} O =I\\\operatorname{det} O =1\] 定义了 \(S O (2)\) 群

  • 这里的 \(S\) 表示 “特殊' (special)
  • \(O\)表示 \(^{\prime}\) 正交 '(orthogonal \()\)

\(S O (2)\) 包含的旋转变换保持了坐标系的取向，即一个右手坐标系 经旋转变换后还是右手系，而反射变换会改变它的取向。用线性代数的概念来说，我们规定 \(S O (2)\) 中的矩阵行列式必须为+1

用单位复数表示旋转变换

还可以用单位复数来表示二维的旋转变换:

  • \(z=a+i b\)
  • \(|z|^{2}=z^{*} z=1\)
\(U (1)\) 群

所有单位复数构成一个群，称为\(U (1)\) 群。

群乘法即为复数乘法,不难验证它符合群公理。

为了看出它与之前引入的 O(2), SO(2)群的关系，我们将 U(1) 群的条件 一复数的模（长度）为 1 表示为 \(\forall U \in U (1)\) \[U ^{*} U =1\] 单位复数另一种写法是： \[R_{\theta}= e ^{i \theta}=\cos \theta+i \sin \theta\] \(R_{\theta}\) 的模平方为: \[\begin{aligned}R_{\theta}^{*} R_{\theta}&= e ^{-i \theta} e ^{i \theta}\\&=(\cos \theta-i \sin \theta)(\cos \theta+i \sin \theta)\\&=1\end{aligned}\]

例子

将向量 (3,5) 对应的复数 \(z=3+5 i\) 旋转 \(90^{\circ}:\) \[\begin{aligned}z \rightarrow z^{\prime}&= e ^{i 90^{\circ}} z\\&=( \cos 90^{\circ} +i \sin 90^{\circ} )(3+5 i)\\&=i(3+5 i)\\&=3 i-5\end{aligned}\]

  • 复数乘以 $ e^{i 90^{}}$ 旋转了\(90^{\circ}\)。
  • 需要注意 e \(^{i 90^{\circ}}\) 作用于（乘以）向量对应的复数而非向量本身。
  • 描述二维旋转只需要一个参数: 旋转角 \(\phi\). 而复数有两个自由度（实部和虚部），因此我们加上单位复数的限制:\(|z|=\) 实部 \(^{2}+\) 虚部 \(^{2}=1,\) 刚好只剩一个自由度。
两种表述的联系

描述二维旋转的两种方式

  • 单位复数
  • \(2 \times 2\) 矩阵（矩阵元 都是实数）

通过如下方式相联系。定义: \[1=\left(\begin{array}{ll}1 & 0 \\0 & 1\end{array}\right)\quad i =\left(\begin{array}{cc}0 & -1 \\1 & 0\end{array}\right)\] 不难验证这样定义的 1, i 仍然满足: \[1^{2}=1, \quad i ^{2}=-1, \quad 1 i = i 1= i\] 这样单位复数对应的 \(2 \times 2\) 实数矩阵为 \[\begin{aligned}R_{\theta}&=\cos \theta+i \sin \theta\\&=\cos \theta\left(\begin{array}{cc}1 & 0 \\0 & 1\end{array}\right)+\sin \theta\left(\begin{array}{cc}0 & -1 \\1 & 0\end{array}\right)\\&=\left(\begin{array}{cc}\cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\\sin \theta & \cos \theta\end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\] 可见，定义了复单位 \(i \rightarrow\) 实矩阵 的对应关系后，单位复数就回到了熟悉的旋转矩阵。还有一点要注意：旋转矩阵作用于向量（列矩阵），而我们将 \(i\) 与 \(2 \times 2\) 的实矩阵相联系，因此被旋转的向量（与个复数对应）也将变成一个 \(2 \times 2\) 矩阵。

例子

任意向量 \((a, b)\) 对应的复数对应的 \(2 \times 2\) 矩阵为: \[\begin{aligned}z&=a+i b\\&=a\left(\begin{array}{cc}1 & 0 \\0 & 1\end{array}\right)+b\left(\begin{array}{cc}0 & -1 \\1 & 0\end{array}\right)\\&=\left(\begin{array}{cc}a & -b \\b & a\end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\] 将旋转矩阵作用于 z: \[\begin{aligned}z^{\prime} &=R_{\theta} z \\\left(\begin{array}{cc}a^{\prime} & -b^{\prime} \\b^{\prime} & a^{\prime}\end{array}\right) &=\left(\begin{array}{cc}\cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\\sin \theta & \cos \theta\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}a & -b \\b & a\end{array}\right) \\\left(\begin{array}{ll}a^{\prime} & -b^{\prime} \\b^{\prime} & a^{\prime}\end{array}\right)&=\left(\begin{array}{cc}a \cos \theta-b \sin \theta & -b \cos \theta-a \sin \theta \\a \sin \theta+b \cos \theta & -b \sin \theta+a \cos \theta\end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\] 由上式可得 \[\begin{array}{l}a^{\prime}=a \cos \theta-b \sin \theta \\b^{\prime}=a \sin \theta+b \cos \theta\end{array}\] 这与旋转矩阵作用于向量（列矩阵形式）相同： \[\left(\begin{array}{cc}\cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\\sin \theta & \cos \theta\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}a \\b\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}a \cos \theta-b \sin \theta \\a \sin \theta+b \cos \theta\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{l}a^{\prime} \\b^{\prime}\end{array}\right)(3.22)\]

同构映射

我们看到这两种表示方法是一回事儿，用数学术语来说，\(SO (2)\) 与 \(U (1)\) 间有一个同构映射。这一点太重要了，之后的篇幅会不断出现这种思想。

三维旋转

作为基底的矩阵

三维向量旋转变换当然可以用 \(3 \times 3\) 旋转矩阵 \[R_{x}=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 0 & 0 \\0 & \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\0 & \sin \theta & \cos \theta\end{array}\right) \]

\[R_{y}=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}\cos \theta & 0 & \sin \theta \\0 & 1 & 0 \\-\sin \theta & 0 & \cos \theta\end{array}\right)\]

\[R_{z}=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}\cos \theta & -\sin \theta & 0 \\\sin \theta & \cos \theta & 0 \\0 & 0 & 1\end{array}\right)\]

类比 \(S O (2)\) 群，上面三个矩阵构成了 \(S O (3)\) 群的一组基。这意味着 \(S O (3)\) 中的任意群元（矩阵）都可以写为 \(R_{x}, R_{y}, R_{z}\) 的线性组合，且系数唯一。将向量 \[\vec{v}=\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\0 \\0\end{array}\right)\] 绕 z 轴旋转就是用旋转矩阵乘以向量： \[R_{z}(\theta) \vec{v}=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}\cos \theta & -\sin \theta & 0 \\\sin \theta & \cos \theta & 0 \\0 & 0 & 1\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\0 \\0\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}\cos \theta \\\sin \theta \\0\end{array}\right)\]

四元数（quaternions）

为找出描述三维旋转的第二法，我们尝试把复数的概念扩展到三维空间。首先试着把 2 维的复数扩展为 3 维复数，但前人探索发现没有 3 维的,但存在 4 维・复数，, 称为四元数（quaternions)。

类比复数来构造四元数，复数只有一个虚单位 \(i,\) 而四元数里定义三个虚单位，记作 \(i , j , k\)，它们仍然满足

任意一个四元数 \(q\) 表示为

\[q=a 1+b i +c j +d k\]

  • 乘法

要想定义四元数间的乘法，必须定义虚单位间的乘法规则 \[ijk=-1\] 导出 \[\begin{aligned}ijk&=-1 \\ i j kk &=- k \\ij &= k \end{aligned}\]

  • 逆元

\[\begin{aligned}q^{\dagger} q & \stackrel{!}{=} 1\\ (a 1-b i -c j -d k )(a 1 +b i +c j +d k )&=1\\a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+d^{2}&=1\end{aligned}\]

就像单位复数构成一个群（群乘法为复数乘法）那样，单位四元数也构成一个群（群乘法为四元数乘法）。

矩阵对应

类似于我们将二维复数与 \(2 \times 2\) 实数矩阵建立联系的做法，四元数也可如此 - 将四个基 \(1, i , j , k\) 与合适的矩阵一一对应。

其中一种方式（还有别的方式）是将它们与 \(2 \times 2\)复数矩阵对应 \[\begin{aligned}1=\left(\begin{array}{ll}1 & 0 \\0 & 1\end{array}\right) \quad, \quad i =\left(\begin{array}{cc}0 & -1 \\1 & 0\end{array}\right)\\ j =\left(\begin{array}{ll}0 & i \\i & 0\end{array}\right) \quad, \quad k =\left(\begin{array}{cc}i & 0 \\0 & -i\end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\] 不难验证上式满足四元数乘法，比如 \(i j=k\) 、\(i j k=-1\)式。

这样任意一个四元数都可用矩阵表示为: \[q=a 1+b i +c j +d k =\left(\begin{array}{cc}a+d i & b+c i \\-b+c i & a-d i\end{array}\right)\]

  • \(S U (2)\)

因为 \(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+d^{2}=1\)，比较可以发现单位四元数对应的矩阵的行列式为1。

  • \(U ^{\dagger} U =1\) 幺正 unitary
  • \(\operatorname{det}( U )=1\)

任意单位四元数都唯一对应 \(S U (2)\) 群中的一个群元。

\(S U (2)\) 群如何与三维旋转联系？

试将三维向量 \(\vec{v}=(x, y, z)\) 定义为如下四元数 ： \[v \equiv x i +y j +z k\] 例：定义 u 是 \(R i + R j + R k\) 的某一单位向量，则任意单位四元数 \(t\) 可表示为: \[t=\cos \theta+u \sin \theta\] 任意三维向量 \(\vec{v}\) 可表示为: \[\begin{aligned}\vec{v}&=\left(v_{x}, v_{y}, v_{z}\right)^{T}\\&=v_{x} i +v_{y} j +v_{z} k \\&{=} \left(\begin{array}{cc}i v_{z} & v_{x}+i v_{y} \\-v_{x}+i v_{y} & -i v_{z}\end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\] 简明起见我们举个特例，把向量 \(\vec{v}=(1,0,0)^{T}\) 绕 \(z\) 轴旋转。 \[\begin{aligned}\vec{v}&=(1,0,0)^{T} \\\rightarrow v&=1 i +0 j +0 k \\&=\left(\begin{array}{cc}0 & 1 \\-1 & 0\end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned}R_{z}(\theta)&=\cos \theta 1+\sin \theta k \\&=\left(\begin{array}{cc}\cos \theta+i \sin \theta & 0 \\0 & \cos \theta-i \sin \theta\end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\]

用欧拉公式写出

\[\begin{aligned}e ^{i x}&=\cos x+i \sin x \\\Rightarrow R_{z}(\theta)&=\left(\begin{array}{cc} e ^{i \theta} & 0 \\0 & e ^{-i \theta}\end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\] 四元数旋转矩阵的逆矩阵为: \[\begin{aligned}R_{z}^{-1}(\theta)&=\left(\begin{array}{cc}\cos \theta-i \sin \theta & 0 \\0 & \cos \theta+i \sin \theta\end{array}\right)\\&=\left(\begin{array}{cc} e ^{-i \theta} & 0 \\0 & e ^{i \theta}\end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\] 根据 \(v^{\prime}=q^{-1} v q\) 式旋转向量 \(v\);

\[\begin{aligned}v^{\prime} &=R_{z}^{-1}(\theta) v R_{z}(\theta)\\&=\left(\begin{array}{cc} e ^{-i \theta} & 0 \\0 & e ^{i \theta}\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}0 & 1 \\-1 & 0\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc} e ^{i \theta} & 0 \\0 & e ^{-i \theta}\end{array}\right) \\&=\left(\begin{array}{cc}0 & e ^{-i 2 \theta} \\- e ^{i 2 \theta} & 0\end{array}\right)\\&=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}0 & & \cos (2 \theta)-i \sin (2 \theta) \\-\cos (2 \theta)-i \sin (2 \theta) & & 0\end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\] 另一方面，向量 \(v^{\prime}\) 用四元数表示为:

\[v^{\prime}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}i v_{z}^{\prime} & v_{x}^{\prime}+i v_{y}^{\prime} \\-v_{x}^{\prime}+i v_{y}^{\prime} & -i v_{z}^{\prime}\end{array}\right)\] 比较可得:

  • \(v_{x}^{\prime}=\cos (2 \theta)\)
  • \(v_{y}^{\prime}=-\sin (2 \theta)\)
  • \(v_{z}^{\prime}=0\)

所以 \[\overrightarrow{v^{\prime}}=(\cos (2 \theta),-\sin (2 \theta), 0)^{T}\] 由上式可见从 \(\vec{v}\) 到 \(\vec{v}^{\prime}\) 确实进行了旋转

双覆盖

要注意，上式表示我们没有把 \(\vec{v}\) 旋转 \(\theta\) 角度，而是旋转了 \(2 \theta !\) 因此我们定义 \(\phi \equiv 2 \theta\) \[t=\cos \left(\frac{\phi}{2}\right)+\sin \left(\frac{\phi}{2}\right) u\] 这样定义的单位四元数与三维旋转矩阵之间的关系并非一一对应的，而是两个单位四元数描述同一个旋转，例如：

将向量旋转 \(\pi\)

  • \(t_{\phi=\pi}=u\)
  • \(t_{\phi=3 \pi}=-u\)

因此 \(S U (2)\) 群称为 \(S O (3)\) 群的双覆盖。一个 \(S U (2)\) 中的群元对应 \(S O (3)\)的哪个群元是很明确的，反过来就不行，因为 \(S O (3)\) 中的一个群元对应 SU(2) 中的两个。这并非仅有数学意义，稍后就会看到，在物理上，一个能覆盖别的群的群往往更加深刻。

  • 衔接

给定某个群，为了找出能覆盖这个群的群，我们需要学习 Lie代数 - Lie 理论的利器，下一节就讲 Lie 代数。

Lie 代数

Lie 理论是研究连续对称的理论。

圆的对称群（对称变换组成的群）是连续的，因为变换参数（旋转角）可以取任意（连续）的值。用数学符号来表示: 无限接近恒等元的群元 \(g\) 可表示为: \[g(\epsilon)=I+\epsilon X\] 其中

  • \(I\) 恒等元
  • \(\epsilon\) 表示小量（数学上总是用 \(\epsilon\) 表示小量）
  • \(X\) 称为生成元，稍后就讨论它。

这样一个轻微的小变换作用在对象上几乎舍也不变，有时称 \(g(\epsilon)\) 为无穷小变换。把无穷小变换重复许多次就能得到一个有限大小的变换。 \[\begin{aligned}h(\theta)&= (I+\epsilon X)(I+\epsilon X) \ldots(I+\epsilon X)\\&=(I+\epsilon X)^{k}\end{aligned}\] 其中 k 表示无穷小变换重复的次数。

例子

如果 \(\theta\) 表示有限大的旋转角，则无限接近于恒等变换的旋转变换可表示为：

\[g\left(\frac{\theta}{N}\right)=I+\frac{\theta}{N} X\] 要使上式表示的变换尽可能小，则让 \(N\) 尽可能大，令 \(N \rightarrow \infty\) 。为了从这样一个无穷小变换得到一个有限变换，需要把无穷小变换重复无限多次，即: \[h(\theta)=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty}\left(I+\frac{\theta}{N} X\right)^{N}= e ^{\theta X}\] 上式有 \(X\) 生成了有限变换 \(h(\theta)\) 的感觉，因此 \(X\) 成为生成元。

生成元

考虑某个用矩阵表示的连续变换群，对任意群元，在恒等元 \(I\) 处做 Taylor 展开 \[h(\theta)=I+\left.\frac{1}{1 !} \frac{d h}{d \theta}\right|_{\theta=0} \theta+\left.\frac{1}{2 !} \frac{d^{2} h}{d \theta^{2}}\right|_{\theta=0} \theta^{2}+\cdots=\left.\sum_{n} \frac{1}{n !} \frac{d^{n} h}{d \theta^{n}}\right|_{\theta=0} ^{n}\] 利用指数函数的级数展开可将上式的级数表示为更紧奏的形式 \[h(\theta)=\left.\exp \left(\left.\frac{d h}{d \theta}\right|_{\theta=0} \theta\right) \equiv \sum_{n} \frac{1}{n !} \frac{d^{n} h}{d \theta^{n}}\right|_{\theta=0} ^{\theta^{n}}\] 这与之前的描述有联系。比较 \[X=\left.\frac{d h}{d \theta}\right|_{\theta=0}\]

编含在上述推导中的思想是：通过研究群中重要的无穷小元素一生成元 \(X\) 就能获得群的许多重要信息

矩阵 Lie 群的 Lie 代数

矩阵 Lie 群（记作 G）的 Lie 代数就是下面的集合: \[\left\{X \mid if \quad{\tilde{G}}{ e }^{X} \in G\right\}\] 即如果 X 满足 \(e ^{X}\) 是 \(G\) 的群元，则 \(X\) 就是 \(G\) 的 Lie 代数（它是一个集合!）中的元素。这个简单定义只对矩阵 Lie 群管用。之后我们引入 Lie 代数的一般定义。

上面的矩阵 Lie 群的 Lie 代数的定义用数学语言表述为 : \(n \times n\) 矩阵 \(L i e\) 群 \(G\) 的 \(L i e\) 代数 \(g\) 是满足如下条件的 \(n \times n\) 矩阵 X 的集合: \[e ^{t X} \in G, t \in R\] 根据群的定义，群无非是一些变换的集合。群乘法 \(g \circ h\) 告诉我们群元之间怎样结合。矩阵 Lie 群的群乘法就是矩阵乘法，我们可能naive 地认为 Lie 代数的元素之间采用相同的方式结合（$ $）

BCH 公式

但这并不正确！诚然，(矩阵 Lie 群的) Lie 代数的元素都是矩阵，但两个 Lie 代数的矩阵乘法的结果往往不再是 Lie 代数的元素。Lie代数元素间有另外的结合规则，当然它与原来群的群乘法直接有关。

Lie 群乘法与 Lie 代数结合法则之间的关系由著名的 Baker-Campbell-Hausdorff 公式（以下简称 BCH 公式）给出 \(^{39}\) : \[\left. e ^{X} \circ e ^{Y}= e ^{X+Y+\frac{1}{2}[X, Y]+\frac{1}{12}[X,[X, Y]}\right]-\frac{1}{12}[Y,[X, Y]]+\ldots\] 其中 $ X, Y g ,$ 即 \(X, Y\) 是群 \(G\) 的生成元。 \(e ^{X}, e ^{Y}\) 是 \(G\) 的群元，把它们分别记作 \(g, h,\) 这样上式写成: \[ {g} \circ {h} = e ^{X} \circ e ^{Y}= \left. e ^{X+Y+\frac{1}{2}[X, Y]+\frac{1}{12}[X,[X, Y]}\right]-\frac{1}{12}[Y,[X, Y]]+\ldots \] 上式等号右侧是群的一个群元，可见两个群元\((g, h)\)相乘可表示为一些 Lie 代数元素的和（再取指数）。上两式出现的新运算 [, ] 称为 Lie 括号，对于矩阵 Lie 群, \([X, Y]\) 称为 \(X, Y\) 的对易子。 \[[X, Y]=X Y-Y X\] 注意 \(X Y\) 和 \(Y X\) 一般不是 Lie 代数的元素，但它们的差一定是！

由 BCH 公式可知 Lie 代数元素间的乘法规则是 Lie 括号 [, ]而非最初认为的矩阵乘法。就像群在群乘法。运算（矩阵群的 o就是矩阵乘法）下封闭那样，我们称 Lie 代数在 Lie 括号运算下封闭。集合在某运算下封闭的含义是集合的任意两个元素进行该运算所得结果仍在此集合内。

  • 衔接

在学习一个 Lie 代数的例子之后，我们将讨论 Lie 代数的现代定义。现代定义是从群的生成元在 Lie 括号运算下的行为来定义的。利用更广泛的现代定义就能看出哪些不同的群具有相同的 Lie代数，只从上面的 Lie 代数定义出发看不出这一点来。因此 Lie 代数的新定义能让我们更深刻地认识一种变换的基本特征。同一 Lie代数可对应许多 Lie 群，Lie 理论的一条重要定理告诉我们这其中有一个特别的 Lie 群。引入 Lie 群的现代定义之后上面所说的就具体起来了。

下面我们就举一个从给定的群导出相应 Lie 代数的例子。

\(S O (3)\) 群的生成元与 Lie 代数

\(S O (3)\) 群的定义 \[O ^{T} O \stackrel{!}{=} I, \quad \operatorname{det}( O ) \stackrel{!}{=} 1\] 任意群元 \(O\) 用相应的生成元 \(J\) 表示为:

\[O = e ^{\phi J}\]

把 \(O = e ^{\phi J}\) 带入群的第一个定义条件得: \[O ^{T} O = e ^{\phi J^{T}} e ^{\phi J} \stackrel{!}{=1} \\\rightarrow \quad J^{T}+Y \stackrel{!}{=} 0\] 带入第二个定义条件，再利用等式 $ ( e ^{A})= e ^{(A)}$ 得

\[\begin{aligned}&\operatorname{det}( O ) \stackrel{!}{=} 1 \\& \rightarrow \operatorname{det}\left( e ^{\phi J}\right)= e ^{\phi \operatorname{tr}(J)} \stackrel{!}{=} 1 \\& \rightarrow \operatorname{tr}(J) \stackrel{!}{=} 0\end{aligned}\]

群的生成元的基

满足 \(J^{T}+J \stackrel{!}{=} 0\) 和 \(\operatorname{tr}(J) \stackrel{!}{=} 0\) 的三个线性无关的矩阵 \[J_{1}=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}0 & 0 & 0 \\0 & 0 & -1 \\0 & 1 & 0\end{array}\right)\\J_{2}=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}0 & 0 & 1 \\0 & 0 & 0 \\-1 & 0 & 0\end{array}\right)\\J_{3}=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}0 & -1 & 0 \\1 & 0 & 0 \\0 & 0 & 0\end{array}\right)\] 这三个矩阵构成 \(SO (3)\) 群的生成元的基。即群的任意生成元 \(J\) 可惟一表示为这三者的线性组合: \[J=a J_{1}+b J_{2}+c J_{3}\] 其中 \(a, b, c\) 表示实常数。 \(J_{1}, J_{2}, J_{3}\) 可用 Levi-Civita 符号更紧奏地表示 : \[\left(J_{i}\right)_{j k}=-\epsilon_{i j k}, \quad i, j, k=1,2,3\] 其中 \(j, k\) 表示生成元 的\(J_{i}\) 分量。例: \[\begin{aligned}\left(J_{1}\right)_{j k}&=-\epsilon_{1 j k} \longleftrightarrow\left(\begin{array}{lll}\left(J_{1}\right)_{11} & \left(J_{1}\right)_{12} & \left(J_{1}\right)_{13} \\\left(J_{1}\right)_{21} & \left(J_{1}\right)_{22} & \left(J_{1}\right)_{23} \\\left(J_{1}\right)_{31} & \left(J_{1}\right)_{32} & \left(J_{1}\right)_{33}\end{array}\right) \\& =-\left(\begin{array}{ccc}\epsilon_{111} & \epsilon_{112} & \epsilon_{113} \\\epsilon_{121} & \epsilon_{122} & \epsilon_{123} \\\epsilon_{131} & \epsilon_{132} & \epsilon_{133}\end{array}\right)\\&=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}0 & 0 & 0 \\0 & 0 & -1 \\0 & 1 & 0\end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\] 这些生成元可以生成有限大小的变换矩阵。

例子

以 \(J_{1}\) 为例，我们可以只关注非零部分 一 右下角的 \(2 \times 2\) 矩阵，把它记作 \(j_{1}\) 。 \[J_{1}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}0 & \\ & j_{1}\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{cc}0 & \\ & \left(\begin{array}{cc}0 & -1 \\1 & 0\end{array}\right)\end{array}\right)\] 计算可得 \[j_{1}^{2}=-1\] 接着: \[j_{1}^{3}= j_{1}^{2} j_{1}=-j_{1}\\j_{1}^{4}=+1\\ j_{1}^{5}=+j_{1}\] 一般情况为: \[j_{1}^{2 n}=(-1)^{n} I\\ j_{1}^{2 n+1}=(-1)^{n} j_{1}\] 利用上式可计算 \(j_{1}\) 的指数函数的级数展开： \[\begin{aligned}R_{1} &= e ^{\phi j_{1}}=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{\phi^{n} j_{1}^{n}}{n !} \\&=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{\phi^{2 n}}{(2 n) !} {j_{1}^{2 n}}+\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{\phi^{2 n+1}}{(2 n+1) !} j_{1}^{2 n+1}\\&=\left(\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{\phi^{2 n}}{(2 n) !}(-1)^{n}\right) I+\left(\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{\phi^{2 n+1}}{(2 n+1) !}(-1)^{n}\right)j_{1} \\&=\cos \phi\left(\begin{array}{ll}1 & 0 \\0 & 1\end{array}\right)+\sin \phi\left(\begin{array}{c}0 & -1 \\1 & 0\end{array}\right)\\&=\left(\begin{array}{cc}\cos \phi & -\sin \phi \\\sin \phi & \cos \phi\end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\] 再利用 \(e ^{0}=1\)计算左上角的 0 对应的元素，得到完整的有限变换矩阵: \[R_{1}=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 0 & 0 \\0 & \cos \phi & -\sin \phi \\0 & \sin \phi & \cos \phi\end{array}\right)\]

导出生成元

我们己经得出 \(SO (3)\) 群的生成元显式的矩阵形式 \[J_{1}=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}0 & 0 & 0 \\0 & 0 & -1 \\0 & 1 & 0\end{array}\right)\\J_{2}=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}0 & 0 & 1 \\0 & 0 & 0 \\-1 & 0 & 0\end{array}\right)\\J_{3}=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}0 & -1 & 0 \\1 & 0 & 0 \\0 & 0 & 0\end{array}\right)\] 这样就能直接计算生成元之间的 Lie 括号了，不难得到： \[\left[J_{i}, J_{j}\right]=\epsilon_{i j k} J_{k}\] 其中 \(\epsilon_{i j k}\) 是 Levi-Civita 符号。

出于物理层面的考虑，在 \(S O (3)\) 生成元 \(e ^{\phi J}\) 的审附加一个虚 单位 \(i,\) 即 e \(^{i \phi J},\) 生成元的基变成: \[J_{1}=i\left(\begin{array}{ccc}0 & 0 & 0 \\0 & 0 & 1 \\0 & -1 & 0\end{array}\right)\\J_{2}=i\left(\begin{array}{ccc}0 & 0 & -1 \\0 & 0 & 0 \\1 & 0 & 0\end{array}\right)\\J_{3}=i\left(\begin{array}{ccc}0 & 1 & 0 \\-1 & 0 & 0 \\0 & 0 & 0\end{array}\right)\] 于是 Lie 代数为: \[\left[J_{i}, J_{j}\right]=i \epsilon_{i j k} J_{k}\] 将生成元加 \(i\) 是为了让它们是厄米生成元，厄米生成元的含 义是 \(J^{\dagger} \equiv\left(J^{*}\right)^{T} \stackrel{!}{=} J_{\text {。 }}\) 加 \(i\) 是从物理意义考虑的: 厄米矩阵的本征值都是实数，这在量子力学里面极其重要，因为生成元的本征值是实验的可观测量。如果不加 \(i\)，生成元就是反厄米的了: \(J^{\dagger}=\left(J^{*}\right)^{T}=-J,\) 反厄米矩阵的本征值是虚数。

另一种导出生成元

还有另一种导出生成元的方法, 利用 \[-X=\left.\frac{d h}{d \theta}\right|_{\theta=0}\] 以及三维旋转矩阵的形式 \[R_{1}=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 0 & 0 \\0 & \cos \phi & -\sin \phi \\0 & \sin \phi & \cos \phi\end{array}\right)\] 可得: \[\begin{aligned}J_{1}=&\left.\frac{d R_{1}}{d \theta}\right|_{\theta=0}\\&=\left.\frac{d}{d \theta}\left(\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 0 & 0 \\0 & \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\0 & \sin \theta & \cos \theta\end{array}\right)\right|_{\theta=0} \\&=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}0 & 0 & 0 \\0 & -\sin \theta & -\cos \theta \\0 & \cos \theta & -\sin \theta\end{array}\right) \\&=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}0 & 0 & 0 \\0 & 0 & -1 \\0 & 1 & 0\end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\] 第一种方法更加普遍，因为像这样已知有限变换矩阵具体形式的好事不太常见。对于之后的Lorentz 群，我们先根据群的定义导出其生成元的基，然后才得出 Lorentz 变换的显式形式。当然如果已知变换矩阵形式那么这种就能最简便地导出生成元。

Lie 代数的抽象定义

前面介绍了简化版的 Lie 代数定义。群 G 的 Lie 代数是满足如下条件的 X 的集合: \(e ^{X} \in G_{\circ}\) 下面我们会看到，群的重要部分 一 群乘法（规定群元之间怎样结合），可以从 Lie 代数元素的Lie 括号运算中导出。 就像定义 Lie 群那样，我们把 Lie 代数的关键特征表示为公理，这就形成了 Lie 代数的抽象定义:

Lie 代数是一个向量空间 g 配备一个二元运算 \([,]: g \times g \rightarrow g ,\) 且二元运算 [, ] 满足如下公理：

  • 双线 $ a, b R$ 及 \(\forall X\),$ Y$, \(Z\in g\)，\([a X+b Y, Z]=a[X, Z]+b[Y, Z]\)，\([Z, a X+b Y]=a[Z, X]+b[Z, Y]\)

  • 反交换律: \(\forall X, Y \in g ,[X, Y]=-[Y, X]\)

  • $ J a c o b i$ 恒等： $ X, Y, Z g ,$\([X,[Y, Z]]+[Z,[X, Y]]+[Y,[Z, X]]=0\)

之前我们把矩阵的对易子作为 Lie 代数的二元运算 [, ]，不难验证对易子满足上面的要求。其实有许多和对易子丝毫不同的二元运算照样满足这些公理，比如经典力学中著名的 Poisson 括号。

注意 Lie 代数的抽象定义完全不依赖群，这十分重要要。

\(S U (2)\) 的生成元与Lie 代数

前面我们历经磨难终于找到描述三维旋转的第二法 - \(S U (2)\)群，并且发现 \(S U (2)\) 是 \(S O (3)\) 的双覆盖 。

SU(2) 的生成元:Pauli 矩阵

\(S U (2)\) 群的群元是具有单位行列式 的幺正的 \(2 \times 2\) 矩阵，即： \[\begin{aligned}U ^{\dagger} U &= U U ^{\dagger}=1 \\& \operatorname{det}( U )=1\end{aligned}\] 从群元满足的条件可导出其生成元满足的条件。设生成元为 $J_{1}, J_{2}, $ 将群元用生成元表示，带入上两式 ： \[\begin{aligned}&U ^{\dagger} U =\left( e ^{i J_{i}}\right)^{\dagger} e ^{i J_{i}} \stackrel{!}{=1} \\&\operatorname{det}( U )=\operatorname{det}\left( e ^{i J_{i}}\right) \stackrel{!}{=} 1\end{aligned}\] 结合 \(\left( e ^{i J_{i}}\right)^{\dagger} e ^{i J_{i}} \stackrel{!}{=} 1\)，BCH 公式和 \(\left[J_{i}, J_{i}\right]=0^{}:\) \[\begin{aligned}\left( e ^{i J_{i}}\right)^{\dagger} e ^{i J_{i}}&= 1\\e ^{-i J_{i}^{\dagger}} e ^{i J_{i}}& \stackrel{!}{=} 1\\e ^{-i J_{i}^{\dagger}}+i J_{i}+\frac{1}{2}\left[J_{i}^{\dagger}, J_{i}\right]+\ldots &\stackrel{!}{=} 1\\-i J_{i}^{\dagger}+i J_{i}&=0\\J_{i}^{\dagger}& \stackrel{!}{=} J_{i}\end{aligned}\] 满足 \(J_{i}^{\dagger}=J_{i}\) 的矩阵称为厄米矩阵，由上可见 \(S U (2)\) 的生成元必须是厄米的。

利用恒等式 $( e ^{A})= e ^{(A) } $ 和\(\operatorname{det}\left( e ^{i J_{i}}\right) \stackrel{!}{=} 1\)式可得: \[\begin{aligned}\operatorname{det}\left( e ^{i J_{i}}\right)= 1\\e ^{i \operatorname{tr}\left(J_{i}\right)}=1 \\\operatorname{tr}\left(J_{i}\right) \stackrel{!}{=} 0\end{aligned}\] 综上， SU(2) 的生成元一定是无迹的厄米矩阵。\(2 \times 2\) 无迹厄米矩阵的一组基为： \[\sigma_{1}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}0 & 1 \\1 & 0\end{array}\right)\\\sigma_{2}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}0 & -i \\i & 0\end{array}\right)\\\sigma_{3}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}1 & 0 \\0 & -1\end{array}\right)\] 也就是说任意 \(2 \times 2\) 无迹厄米矩阵都可唯一表示为上面三个矩阵的线性组合。这三个矩阵称为 Pauli 矩阵。

对易关系

把 Pauli 矩阵扬进 Lie 括号中进行计算可得: \[\left[\sigma_{i}, \sigma_{j}\right]=2 i \epsilon_{i j k} \sigma_{k}\] 其中 \(\epsilon_{i j k}\) 是 Levi-Civita 符号。上式右侧的 2 很多余，因此通常将 \(S U (2)\) 的生成元的基定义为 \(J_{i} \equiv \frac{1}{2} \sigma_{i},\) 这样 Lie 括号计算结果为: \[\left[J_{i}, J_{j}\right]=i \epsilon_{i j k} J_{k}\] 注意这与 \(S O (3)\) 的生成元形式 ( (3.73) 式)相同!因此我们说 \(S U (2)\) 与 \(S O (3)\) 有相同的 Lie 代数，因为 Lie 代数是通过 Lie 括号定义

利用 Lie 代数的抽象定义可以用不同的方式描述 SU(2) 群对应的变换，即，\(S U(2)\) 群对应的变换可以不用 \(2 \times 2\) 矩阵表示。为了做到这一点，我们还需要知道 Lie 群的抽象定义。因为一直以来就是用 \(2 \times 2\) 矩阵定义 \(S U(2)\) 的，换一种表示方法(例如用 \(3 \times 3\) 矩阵表示) 则不知所云。Lie 群的抽象定义能够让我们发现同一变换的不同表示之间的关系。抽象定义将 Lie 群与一种几何结构 一 流形相等同，利用这种抽象结构来定义一个群。这一想法初看十分怪异，但在学习两个例子之后就会发现它是超级有意义的。

Lie 群的抽象定义

\(U (1)\) 与 \(S O (2)\)

纯良的 U(1) 群，它由全体单位复数构成。定义为 \(z^{*} z=1,\) 设 \(z=a+i b,\) 则 : \[\begin{aligned}z^{*} z&=(a+i b)^{*}(a+i b)\\&=(a-i b)(a+i b)\\&=a^{2}+b^{2}\\&=1\end{aligned}\] 这也是单位圆的定义条件。可见单位复数的集合正是复平面上的单位圆。此外，我们知道 \(U (1)\) 与 \(S O (2)\) 群间存在一一映射 。 因此这两个群可以与几何对象 一单位圆 一 视为等同。群的抽象定义并非将这个群用 SO(2)，或着是不同的 U(1) 体现，因为它们都是由特定维数的对象定义的。可以将该群直接利用单位圆定义。即二维旋转变换（对应的 Lie 群）等同于单位圆，然后我们可以用\(S O (2)\) 群表示这个变换（\(2 \times 2\) 矩阵)，也可用 U(1) 群来表示（单 位复数）。

$ S O (3)$ 与 $S U (2) $
